content.description: On any given night (or morning) this coffee shop is packed to the rafters, a favourite spot to swing by for supper or post-clubbing/pre-dawn fuel. Happy and hungry punters tuck into favourites like the perfectly crisp tosai, plates of tasty nasi goreng or delicious nuggets of chicken tikka, butter chicken and prata, before finishing it all off with a super-sized Milo dinosaur or teh cino.

This family-run confectionery dates back 55 years and gives a nod to the good old days with its retro-tiled floor and antique cabinets. On a day-to day basis, their muffins (13 flavours including durian, cheese, coffee and strawberry) fly off the shelf like hotcakes, as do the fluffy, light egg tarts ($0.70 each) and chunky chicken mushroom pies ($1.30 each). But what keeps the customers coming back year after year? The old-style flaky tau sar pia and delicious wifes biscuit ($0.60 each), and the traditional Teochew pastries customary for betrothal baskets.

content.vendor-category: Well & Good | Deals of the month

content.description: From the restaurateurs of Food Republic comes Food Opera, an upmarket spin on the food court, whose 22 hawker stalls come complete with chandeliers, commissioned art, acrylic chairs and marble tabletops. Hawker fare in hoity-toity surroundings may feel contrived, but the ambience is set to match that of the equally smart new mega-mall.

In Spanish, pinchos means small bar treats, those little finger foods that friends and family typically order en masse to share and sample a lil bit of this and that. Spaniards have certainly made a name for themselves as a fun lot, and now that lively ambience is replicated in Rochester Park @ one-north in the alfresco premises of Pinchos tapas and wine bar. Check out live music sessions on Mondays, trivia on Tuesdays or magician acts on Fridays.

entry.name: Mr & Mrs Smith The Couple Store

version.name: Mr & Mrs Smith The Couple Store

content.description: Looking to spice up the bedroom antics? Head up to this newly opened adult store. Inside, products such as Sasmars Conceive Plus lubricant (formulated to provide optimum conditions for sperm survival) and the Endless Pleasure vibrator are bound to thrill. The stores trump card, however, is its exclusive range of Liberator Shapes, a collection of wedges, ramps, cubes and scoops think Lego blocks, but these are used to create the perfect platform for every sexual position you can imagine. If youd rather not be seen walking out toting boxes and bags of goodies, the store also provides a home-delivery service for orders above $200.

Tucked away in the back corner of the old Bukit Timah Fire Station, owners Javier and Sharon have turned this hidden gem into a restaurant with soul. Starters, including ceviche with a tangy twist and crispy calamari, are the real standouts, but mains are equally outstanding. The Make Love Not Raw Burger is a solid offering and a special of succulent prawns grilled to perfection is served alongside gleaming black rice in squid ink. The piece of nori-wrapped salmon is a touch overcooked, but the sides of wasabi mash and mushrooms in white wine and balsamic vinegar make up for it. A chocolate fondant is a little underwhelming, but deep-fried cheesecake balls provide a decadent finish.

A relic of Singapores history, the words Killiney Post Office conjure up nostalgia and memories of a different era. But today, its glass walls and steel architecture offer a completely different ambience for sophisticated yuppies who desire the combination of history and modern design offered by KPO (named for its location at the junctions of Killiney, Penang and Orchard Road). The two-storey bar feels like a modern home, with comfy sofas strategically placed at the corners, and even a greenhouse on the second floor. There is a balcony where one can watch the traffic whizz by while sipping a martini, and slow ambient beats set the mood for a laidback, louche evening. Drinks are well priced, with decent promotions (Sapporo and Asahi at $7 per bottle). A wider-than-usual bar menu offers great bites try the barbecue pork ribs for a latenight snack.

Food and drinks price range: $7 to $20
content.openingtimes:
Mon-Thu 11am-1am
Fri and eve of PH 11am-2am
Sat 9am-2am
Sun 9am-1am

content.description: At 1 Caramel, you can have your cake and eat it too. With 27 freshly baked cakes to choose from, youre bound to find a slice that satisfies your sweet tooth. For tangy, sugary craving, the lemon roulade with light mascarpone cream is recommended; for the tropical fruit lover looking to indulge, a slice of the mango mascarpone cake with a delicious coconut crumble bottom is pure heaven. Shaking things up a little is the densely textured Red Velvet cake with a dark chocolate frosting and the ultra-girly rose mousse and lychee jelly combination; both perfect with a cup of tea. There are a few more concoctions were dying to try on our next visit: the impressive-looking dome-shaped Sachertorte, a red miso soufflé and the DCaramelita, which we hope tastes as yummy as its sensuous sounding name. Costs: From $2.50 (mini cupcake), $7.90 (slice of cake)
Learn to salsa, salsa casino rueda, merengue, bachata and street cha-cha-cha with June and Jackson.
A studio where natural healing activities such as yoga, accupressure, naturopathy are conducted on an ad-hoc basis. Go to their website for more information.

'O2Plants is the innovative provider of interior landscaping for offices, events, restaurants, hotels, and shopping centres in Singapore. Our mission is to bring you the best quality plants and serve you with exceptional service.' from the website.
For special photographs that deserve wall space.

If you are looking to see and be seen, this is most definitely not the place. However, if you just want a spot to shoot some sh*t (or, more specifically, some darts), this may be a new hidden gem. What used to be just one of the many Asian furniture stores, spread all along South Bridge Road, has now been converted into a bar. While many beautiful chests and paintings are still for sale the owner has a passion shes not willing to give up the focus has definitely shifted to the bullseye and cheap booze. A pitcher of Tiger runs for $18 and is served with sembei and prawn crackers. Show up on a Friday night and theyll even toss in a free plate of whatevers cookin. We scored a bowl of chicken curry that one of the patrons claimed as the best in Singapore. The music fits the crowd; they were probably hip in the 80s, but have been layin low ever since (think Dancing Queen and Money for Nothing).

This cosy, dimly lit pub calls attention to its Korean fried chicken providing a more delicious meaning to the acronym KFC. Look out for the eclectic food this kitchen pumps out, like spicy pupa (honey bees), and fried kimchi with Spam and tofu; but fear not, you will still get your quota of the typical fare as well, such as Korean rice cake and ginseng chicken soup. Standouts are the garlic-sauce-fried chicken, spicy chicken stew and instant noodle soup with a medley of sausage, tofu and vegetables. Drown it all down with their refreshing cucumber and lemon soju.

Within the bustling enclave of The Rail Mall, Ramen Ramen is regularly filled to the brim with diners devouring both traditional and modern Japanese soup dishes and sides. Owner Lim Wei Gien prepares the milky tonkotsu broth every day, allowing flavours to simmer for more than 20 hours. Recommended are the meaty Burger-men and Lum-Lum-men (braised beef in zesty herb sauce). If your taste buds have you wanting something off the menu, requests for specific concoctions can be accommodated. Side dishes are also bountiful: try the piping hot pumpkin korokke (Japanese croquettes) and karashi ebi (prawns garnished with a mouth-gasping mustard mayonnaise). Service is prompt and the mood is upbeat.

South-East Asias first art gallery to dedicate itself exclusively to contemporary glass art and showcases emerging artists alongside established talent such as Australian artists Daniela Turrin and Robert Wynne. The combination of hardwood floors, modern interior and outdoor deck provides a unique setting for an art show.

Mr Prata, located near Evans Lodge and a stones throw from the Botanic Gardens, churns out prata and rich curries to many a hungry soul in need of a 4am food-fix. The modest alfresco-dining establishment may be lacking comfort, but makes up for it with its diverse menu and brisk service. At the last count, more than 40 prata festooned the menu, complemented by both meat and vegetarian curry dishes from all over India, naan bread from the tandoor, and Singaporecentric fusions (see Mee & Meehoon Mix Goreng). Wash it all down with a manly Milo Godzilla and youll be complete at least till tomorrow, same time, same place.
Founded by artists Steve Chua and Ernest Chan, this gallery showcases the owners work alongside that of other artists. It also offers a range of art classes for adults and kids.
content.openingtimes: Daily 12.30pm-7pm; Public Holidays by appointment only.

content.description: This truly is a meat-lovers paradise. Vegetarians, be prepared if you happen to be dragged along by insensitive friends, as the giant skewers of beef wrapped in bacon, glistening sausages and ribs falling off the bone may not sit well. However, the carnivores in the crowd can just sit back and get excited as all sorts of juicy pieces of cow, chicken, lamb and fish are carved onto their plates. Tip: avoid gorging yourself on the hearts of palm, mixed beans and potatoes at the salad bar this is just their way of filling up your belly before the good stuff arrives. In addition to the parking-lot location and drab setting, there is also something very wrong with the service ethos. The friendly wait-staff festively prepares caipirinhas at the table to complement the all-you-can-eat meats doused in salt, but when they deny diners a glass of tap water it leaves a very dry taste in the mouth. The Brazilian tiramisu sprinkled in coconut helped provide a sweeter flavour to finish the meal. All-you-can-eat lunch $32++, dinner $39++.
This bicycle shop specialises in Swiss road bicycles. If you're thinking of a carbon frame from the Alps, here's the place to get it!

At TR Bikes, you'll get fully customised bikes that use only the very best parts! They deal with some of the best custom builders in the bicycling industry such as Sycip, Retrotec, Inglis Cycles, Aherne Cycles and Kent Ericksen. Contact lynten@trbikes.com for more information.

address.street: Liang Court Shopping Centre, 177 River Valley Road, Clarke Quay
Liang Court Shopping Centre, 177 River Valley Road, Clarke Quay

content.description:
What magic do they weave with the ramen in the kitchen to make it so bouncy and lush? Each big bowl is already a meal in itself, the earthy broth (there are only three soup options chicken, spicy chicken or nuts) spiked with either pork balls or boiled pork slices. Its the connoisseurs version of Maggi Mee. And if youre feeling hungry, there are additional toppings to be had, ranging from an almost-coddled egg to omelettes and dominos of soy pork belly braised in soy sauce. Reservations are not taken.

This restaurant was featured in 'The High Five: Bowls or Ramen' (TOS Feb 2010)

Its a sign that a zhi-char joint is beyond good when you look around and find almost every table is filled with white-shirted cab drivers. The raucous, frat-house atmosphere settled a little when the tiny kitchen sent out crisply battered prawns draped in a creamy pumpkin sauce flecked with curry leaves, followed by a bronzed fish infused with sambal. The tender chunks of pork ribs marinated in Marmite (yes, you heard right) was stellar, though it was a tough finish for first place against the long beans sautéed with dried shrimp.
content.public-transport: Buses: 16, 75, 85, 195 (Drop off at Kim Seng Road)

content.description: Stylish sister restaurant of Min Jiang at Goodwood park. Try their Beijing Duck and don't forget to gawk at the Ernesto Bedmar decor.

Sarang (Korean for love) distinguishes itself with a smartly thoughtout menu that doesnt try to be too esoteric or clever. The musically named mukeunji galbi jjim is a dish of meaty, sweet ribs stewed in a mellow kimchi broth that seems a little lost in the tropics, but which you imagine would go down a treat in snow-swept Seoul. Dwaejigogi bossam is the Korean version of a sang choy bao: thickly cut, sliced and boiled pork is rolled up with lettuce and fresh kimchi, and slathered with chilli sauce and garlic discs; while dolsotbap is a yummy mix of smoky rice and a soybean-sauce stew strewn with straw mushrooms and tofu. Kimchi the national treasure of cabbage preserved with entire fields of garlic is featured prominently in just about every dish, so it may help to temper the pungency with the delightful yuja cha, a lightly tart lemon and honey brew.

If fancy French fare is your thing, Absinthe delivers in spades. The sage-green wallpaper is a subtle nod to the colour of the liquor that lends its name to Our essential guide to Singapores best restaurants and bars, old and new updated every month the restaurant, and the open window to the kitchen offers a glimpse of the bustle behind the scenes. The lively jazz soundtrack provides an upbeat vibe, while candles flickering on each white-clothed table shout romance. The entrée of foie gras is meltin- your-mouth delicious and the addition of tiny hibiscus flowers gives it a perfect acidic punch. The roasted black cod is also a standout: served on a bed of saffron risotto that is far lighter and less creamy than expected and more successful as a result its the addition of a dill-scented jus that takes it to another level. A highlight among the skilfully made desserts is the absinthe sorbet accompanying a blueberry crème brûlée. But Absinthe is not just about the food; the restaurant has a charm that justifies the high price tag.

I am Team Sparkleskins, so when I read about this non-invasive 30-minute treatment that promised fairer skin, I leapt to it.

The treatment is administered in a small but ostentatiously decked-out room furnished with European silks, Mandarin anatomical posters and Arabian-style crystal tea sets. This confusing mish-mash of styles begins to make sense when you learn Cristalle de Paris (CdP) counts the royal families of Malaysia and Saudi Arabia, and Indonesias first family as long-time clients.

Feeling rather special, I took my place on the bed while the beautician began by removing my makeup. The special feeling went away very quickly with each swipe of stiff gauze; this discomfort was thankfully over soon enough, and a soothing layer of freshly concocted organic serum infused with essence of pearl was brushed on.

Soon after, the beautician smothered a layer of the mild, milk-coloured liquid onto my face, left it to settle for what felt like fi ve minutes, and then put another layer on. Unfortunately, she gave no explanation of what was happening, but her swift and quiet movements allowed me to doze off to the muzak that was being piped through the room. Just as I was drifting off into REM sleep, I was jerked awake to the serum being wiped off with another round of stiff gauze they really need to rethink this part of the process.

Another layer of moisturiser slathered on and a quick head-and-shoulder massage later, and I was done. I walked away, noticing in the salons walls of mirrors that I looked slightly fairer, and that my skin was neither red nor irritated moreover, when I got back to the office later, my colleagues remarked that I looked younger and fresh-faced. Success!

Now, if only Edward was here to pay for my transformation.

This story first appeared as Shady Characters: NPC In-Nano Whitening Treatment (Aug 2010).

Its difficult to remember a time before Dempsey Hill became a byword for gastrofab. This moodily lit, high-raftered space has been used to dramatic effect with giant birdcage lamps, a shimmering curtain of glass, soaring filigreed screens, and tall, wing-backed sofas crowded with pillows in Khun Jims fabled silks. The tom ka ghai combines the sweetness of coconut with mellow, perfectly cooked chicken strips. The mussaman curry is served with small cubes of beef and potato steeped in a creamy, burgundy sauce of cinnamon, galangal and cardamom. The green chicken curry is warmed by mellow notes of lemongrass, and it is difficult not to inhale the fried kway teow thats stained black with soy sauce. Dessert should definitely not be skipped, an incomparable tab tim grob the diced water chestnuts, stained a lipstick red, swimming in a light coconut bath with yellow flashes of jackfruit and a perfectly judged mound of warm sticky rice to accompany the mango pieces create a grand finale.

Its not the citys smartest bar, and definitely not the coolest. But where the Lizard scores low on hip quotient, its genuinely lovely waitstaff goes to great lengths to foster a family atmosphere, and succeeds. Large screens carry sporting action, but are positioned discreetly so conversation flows as freely as the draft Euro beers (Leffe Blonde, Hoegaarden) and San Miguel. A chillout area and stash of magazines towards the rear makes a comfortable retreat for leisurely (or lazy) lounge lizards; meanwhile pinball machines and a pool table keep restless types occupied. But what really stands out aside from the earthy, genial ambience is the menu. Though this seems an unlikely destination for gastropub gourmets, the bar food isnt just unfeasibly cheap but of excellent quality.   The Lazy Lizard was featured in Convival Pursuit: Wild West Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Sun noon-1am; Sat & holiday eve noon-2am.

content.description: Persepolis was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
M Bar was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
Lot, Stock & Barrel Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
The CountrySide Cafe was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
Beds was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
Ming's Cafe & Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
Happy Daze Café was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
Dolphin Tavern was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
content.public-transport: Near station: Yio Chu Kang | Buses: 70

content.description: Bliss Restaurant @ Punggol Park was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
Admiral Bar & Grill was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
The Marina Barrage was built across the mouth of the Marina Channel to create Singapore's newest reservior. On weekends, expect to see kayakers (find out more) paddling within the reservior.

A great alternative to pumping iron or jarring jogs, fencing provides a full-body workout and a chance to master a sport that very few people are good at. One-on-one lessons with experienced coaches will have you parrying and thrusting with all the grace of a professional in no time.     Check their website for class schedules.
Vie Bar was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Fri 4pm-1am; Sat & eve of public holiday 4pm-2am.

content.description: El Toro Paradiso was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.
The Dog & Bone Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 5pm-midnight, Sat, Sun & eve of public holiday 5pm-1am.

content.description: Like Brauhaus Restaurant & Pub, Charlie's Corner was bringing in beers from around the world long before it became fashionable. What's cool about this corner of Changi Village Food Centre is that time literally slows to a crawl while you can sit back, quaff a beer(s) and dig into their Fish & Chips (Hainanese Western style of course). Charlies Corner was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.
Main courses $18-$42.

The Little O'Zone is a family edutainment centre with an indoor playground geared for the little ones. There's a toddler area with soft, colorful, interactive equipment and props. For older children there are cliff climbers, the teeth bridge and boxing sandbags. There are playgroup programmes (for ages 1-3) and a drop-off service (for ages 1-6). Costs: $8/hour (Orchid Country Club Members pay $6, NTUC card holders pay $7).

Located in Pasir Panjang, taking a step into this funkadelic London-loft-style warehouse is like being transported back in time. Stacked up to the ceiling with homeware and knick-knacks from yesteryear, you find yourself manoeuvring your way around '40s art-deco ashtrays, '70s cantilever dining chairs, '60s remote-control tin toy cars, an Eames-era plastic champagne container, a '60s pod chair with inbuilt speakers, and an avant-garde fiberglass chaise longue all the while trying not to knock over standing cylindrical lamps. There's something for everyone: the old dears will be reminiscing about the good ol' days and the young folks, well they'll lap up the second-hand retro-chic on offer here.   Lorgan Wong started restoring colonial furniture with his father when he was just a child. As he got older, his appreciation for vintage furniture grew, the knowledge he accumulated from myriad design books allowing him to recognise the original make-up of the piece. 'I take pride in the ability to restore things as close to their original state as possible.' Most of Wong's pre-loved possessions-for-sale are flown in from Germany, the Netherlands, Denmark or Norway, with others found right here in Singapore.   As for what to buy and how much to pay, Wong recommends going on eBay as a pricing guide and referring to magazines like ELLE Decoration (UK) as a guide to trendspotting. But if you're still in need of affi rmation, Wong who is usually found at the store meddling with a broken transistor radio or restoring a broken lampshade will be there to point you in the right era.

Fans of the Ultimate Fighting Championship can now do more than indulge their aggression online serious Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) training is finally available in Singapore. Touted as South-East Asias largest and most comprehensive MMA gym, Evolve offers Brazilian jiu-jitsu, muay thai, boxing, submission grappling, street self-defence, wrestling and other classes amid state-of-the-art facilities which include the first official MMA Octagon ring in the region. It even boasts world-class champion instructors, as Evolve is the only gym in the world to be affiliated with both the Renzo Gracie Academy (named after noted Brazilian jiu-jitsu and MMA fighter) and the Sityodtong Muay Thai gym in Thailand. Membership starts from $189 per month.
Singapores place to go for contemporary Laotian art, M Gallery has exhibited work by many of the nations top talents, including the likes of Mick Saylom and Anousa P.

You get to tour Singapore's local brewery, taste beer straight from the tap and buy souvenirs of your brewery visit.   Email corpcomms@apb.com.sg or call 6860 3005/007 to book a tour. Prior booking necessary to participate in the Tiger Brewery Tour.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri, tours at 10.30am, 2pm, 4pm & 6.30pm. Each tour is about 90 mins.

content.description: The former Café Les Amis has been made over, this time with Buko Neros Oscar Pasinato on board as consultant. The vibe is homey, comfort Italian chow (like Parma ham with sweet rock melon or a smooth green pea soup with diced prawns) with a sideshow courtesy of the towering wood-fire oven from which emerge rather pedestrian pizzas. The home-made pastas, on the other hand, are terrific, including penne tossed with shredded and braised veal-shank ragu flecked with a mix of garlic, parsley and lemon peel.

Surely, its name is uninspired and so is its hawker location. But dont be sceptical about the quality of freshly prepared pasta and pizza that buddies Max and Melvin whip up as you order. The $6 set meal is great value for intense carb-craving. It comes with an extremely soothing mushroom soup cooked with heaps of garlic bits, a slice of garlic bread and the pasta of your choice. Go for the seafood spaghetti with chilli crab sauce, cleverly pairing the egg, tomato and sauce with pasta instead of the usual Chinese buns, and adding a generous serving of fresh shrimps, clams and fish. The pizza is not spectacular, but do leave room for dessert. The home-made tiramisu doused in rum is light and delicious.

Your dollar certainly goes a long way at Java Java Spa. Book a 60-minute Royal Javanese Massage ($50) and receive a one-off complimentary Ginger Herb Body Wrap ($25) or Body Mask ($30) for the entire month of February. Note: the promotion is not applicable for first-time trial customers who already enjoy the fabulous price of $35 for the lot.
Tucked away in Old School, this gallery promotes primarily Chinese Contemporary Art in all kinds of media.

Along with the obvious Spanish tapas olives, salami, calamari Zsofi gets creative with a ham and cheese croquette that closely resembles a deep-fried grilled cheese sandwich, skewers of asparagus wrapped in crispy bacon, and deviled eggs sprinkled with caviar that bursts in your mouth. This is an excellent addition to Little Indias cosmopolitan restaurant scene, but make sure not to show up starving we waited 45 minutes for our food to arrive. It pays to order a drink (free food!) and have some patience it will pay off in the end. Free tapas with every drink. Tasting platter of six different tapas $14.

Yes, authentic Mexican food is hard to come by in Singapore, but Viva Mexico part of the recently renovated Cuppage Terrace comes the closest, starting with a bona fide Mexican chef in the kitchen and ending with a rich pumpkin dessert baked with cinnamon, sugar and cream. Things bode well when free corn chips and two kinds of salsa arrive (literally) seconds after you sit down, with a salsa verde thats good enough to drink. Though theres an eclectic side to the menu, stick to the standards, particularly the chicken enchiladas boneless chicken breast wrapped in soft corn tortillas, with a side of refried beans looking a bit forlorn without a side of rice. Also notable is the depth of the drink menu (another authentic trait if you ask us), which includes more than a dozen kinds of 100 per cent Agave tequila plus reasonably priced $10 Jose Cuervo shooters and a delicious, smoothie-style blackberry margarita. Service is top-notch, attentive and knowledgeable; we now know the difference between sangria and sangrita.

Tucked away in a shophouse smack in Singapores alternative precinct, newcomer Dim Joy promises much in the novelty department, but the differences are largely cosmetic. Hong Kong chef Feng Song Tangs 15 years of experience show in his standards his roe-topped siew mai has just the right texture and juiciness, while the century egg porridge is satisfyingly smooth and fairly bursting with flavour. Slightly dry barbecued pork somewhat marred the chee cheong fun and char siew pow; but the custard buns rich sweet-salty goodness and Fengs own durian snow pearl, where he displays a remarkable mastery of the fruits pungency, were perfect endings. The open-concept kitchen, airy and naturally lit dining area and non-intrusive bossa nova/jazz score add just the right twist to an otherwise traditional experience. Service is brisk and attentive.

Dim sum $3-$8.
content.openingtimes: Mon, Wed-Fri 11am-3pm, 6-10pm; Sat & Sun 10am-3pm, 5-10pm; closed Tue.

entry.name: Climb Asia Climbing Centre @ Civil Service Club

version.name: Climb Asia Climbing Centre @ Civil Service Club

content.public-transport: Near station: Farrer Park, Boon Keng
content.openingtimes: Mon 5pm-11pm, Tue-Fri 12pm-11pm, Sat, Sun & public holidays 10am-9pm

content.description:
Go for a jaunt through Pasir Ris Park with the kids in tow. While the coastline view is a plus, tours of the mangrove swamp (every third Saturday), kitchen garden (every fi rst Saturday) and maze garden make up a trio of educational opportunities for all. Playgrounds, pony rides, and bird-watching towers keep the kids entertained, while nearby barbecue pits, nature trails and fitness equipment ensure parents can keep an eye out for their little ones.

This story first appeared in 'Park life' (TOS Apr 2010)

content.public-transport: Near station: HarbourFront | Buses: Sentosa Express

address.street: One-Two-Six Cairnhill Arts Centre, 126 Cairnhill Rd
One-Two-Six Cairnhill Arts Centre, 126 Cairnhill Rd

content.description: So successful is this smart and well-stocked shop that sibling proprietors Elaine and Sharon also offer Designer Studio which includes Fontwerks classes and Scrapbook Design University (SDU) courses in their quest to spread the love for the scrapbook. If youre too busy to make your own, make use of their Private Design service to personalise your very own book of souvenirs.

What began as an online store now has a physical presence thanks to its friendly, enthusiastic owners. A handmade feel permeates its range of boutique USA and Japanese craft products. Workshops are conducted lovingly by the owners themselves.

Try Miracle Garden Holistic Spas Miracle Radio Frequency Face treatment ($150), a non-surgical facelift which applies a high frequency to tissues and converts into biothermal energy to stimulate the breakdown of fats. The Cytokine Meso Facial ($150) is another new offering it employs the Epidermal Growth Factor and Basic Fibroblast Growth Factor to increase the skins own collagen and elastin levels, resulting in enhanced radiance and smoothness. Then, have a healthy meal at its adjoining Blue Basil café, which specialises in fresh produce prepared with homegrown herbs.

Residents around Bedok Reservoir will be happy to know that a new hair and nail salon has popped up in their neighbourhood. Classic manis and pedis go for $38, while express mani and pedis are a steal at $5/$8 (colour only, no filing and shaping). Call ahead for appointments.

(). [MRT]

Judging from the tables full of eager diners during our recent Tuesday lunch, you wouldnt know that PeraMakan is buried in the bowels of a country club. The twin attractions here are the price and the more-than-decent cooking. (Just dont bring any Peranakan friends theyre bound to find something to criticise.) There are fatty tiles of pork thick with a coconut satay-like gravy; a more-ish ayam sio gently infused with ginger and coriander; fat sambal prawns; and tender chap chye perfumed with star anise. The desserts arent bad: try the inky black and glossy pulot hitam, and the unusually plump apom discs paired with a caramelly banana sauce. Main courses $10-$18.

Mustard a key ingredient in Bengali and Punjabi cuisine makes its presence known in this restaurants menu. The maacher cutlet, which tasted like an upmarket version of fish fingers, was nicely breaded and fried, and paired with a warm mustard dip. The small pot of eggplant gently sautéed in mustard oil was delicately paired with luchi (Punjabi puffed bread), while the fluffy mutton biryani was just the thing to soak up the yoghurt sauce of the unusual rose-water scented chicken rezalla curry. The place fills up in the evenings with locals and young travellers from neighbouring hostels, so book ahead. Main courses $10.90-$15.90.

Its amusing to find a terrific French kitchen in a non-airconditioned shophouse in the middle of Little India. Open only for dinner, the place fills up quickly with locals and French expats who want to enjoy their caramel sweet onion soup and fragrant cut of duck pâté. Nicely oiled lamb chops are perfectly paired with sautéed herbed potatoes and aubergines, while the richness of the roast duck is cut with a creamy risotto. We found the honey cheesecake too milky and the chocolate cake oddly textured, though. Then again, the diners at the next table practically inhaled their profiteroles.

Is it a reassuring sign wheneven hawker stalls are starting to go natural on us? The Chicken Rice Company in bustling Lau Pa Sat, for example, uses chicken thats reared in a climate-controlled environment and free of growth hormones.The pieces are tender and sweet, though the portions are a little meagre. The side dishes, which are served with a fragrant ginger and garlic dip, are excellent and include bean sprouts smothered in egg floss and a generous serving of golden, deep-fried tofu.

The salacious innuendo in this bars name is hardly representative of what it really is. Sure, the waitresses are wearing bikinis, but theyre not the skimpy, stringy kind. Plus the girls are more cute than smokin hot Brazilian goddesses they will clearly not tolerate any itchy fingers so anyone hoping to get fresh should forget it. What you can look forward to are sweet deals for Asahi beer (three for $25) and an ample selection of hard liquor, including Jägermeister. Food is also served but unfortunately, poor ventilation means youll leave the bar smelling like your lunch. One can only hope that some hardbodies coming off the beach find eau de roast duck attractive.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu 2-11pm, Fri & PH eve 2pm-1am, Sat 11am-1am, Sun & PH 11am-11pm.

content.description: Squirrelled away in the heart of an HDB warren is this in-the-know zhi-char joint, where generations come together to feast on old-fashioned fare like smoky coffee ribs, thickly sauced tofu braised with tiny pinheaded mushrooms, butterpork ribs and excellent salted fish fried rice thats showered with fried anchovies. The dishes which come in super-sized portions, even the small orders come out fast and furious, while the matronly and scarily efficient Cantonese- speaking staff could teach everyone in town a thing or two about service.

Located in charming Joo Chiat, Black Earth Art Museum specialises in oriental art such as calligraphy and traditional Chinese ink and wash. Owner Ho Kee Pau also likes to champion both Singaporean and East Asian artists.

Inject some character into your home with a Tetris-inspired display rack, a Pantone chair or an elaborate spice table (yes a table, not a rack). This lifestyle store stocks a range of unusually creative items that will jazz up any home.
There are regular shuttle bus services from nearby Clementi MRT station, universities and neighbourhoods, directly to West Coast Plaza.
The Cage is Singapore's "First indoor football stadium" with six 5-a-side pitches.

This modern bistro grill opened in late August 2008 at Pan Pacific Orchard (formerly the Meritus Hotel Negara), serving contemporary European cuisine. Although early reviews say its pricey, it still worth the visit just to satisfy your craving for Blackmore full-blood Wagyu beef or free range and organic Kurobuta pork. We know someone, somewhere out there is craving organic pork.

Lunch $ 16-$28, dinner $24-$150

This reliable zhi-char joint comes with the added bonus of warm smiles from the bosses, Ah Lek and Ah Hong. But the main draw here is the deep-fried crab marinated with a thick crust of salted egg yolk. Equally good are the bubbling claypot of liver infused with the intense earthiness of chives and onions; the braised tofu topped with minced pork; and the huge chunk of river fish head perfectly cooked in bean sauce a steal at $18. When the weather gets warm, head indoors to the air-conditioned building across the courtyard.

Pudong puts paid to that old chestnut about location, location, location. Buried in the drab, echoing bowels of a shopping centre, its almost always packed. On weekends, bookings are essential. At first glance you do wonder why, given the surly service and peeling wallpaper, but after the first bite of the lushly fatty, fabulously braised pork thats accompanied by small hard-boiled eggs, you wonder no more. Then the perfectly cooked noodles arrive, fragrant with nothing more than onion-flavoured oil, and theyre just delicious. This is not refined food, but its honest and homey. Main courses $12-$38.

This is such a pretty room: a little bejewelled nook framed in warm timber, its walls of hand-painted tins and glass jars are filled with just about every tea imaginable, as well as plenty you couldnt have conceived. The man behind it all is the former master tea blender at celebrated Parisian salon Mariage Frères, so its credentials are impeccable. The teas more than 200 varieties and blends are the main draw, but the sweets are tempting too. The macarons, in a variety of tea flavours, are delicately wrought, while the cakes are effortlessly refined.

Teas from $8 a pot.

After so many years, this self-styled English Rose Café still turns out a substantial afternoon tea. But its the à la carte menu that holds some nice surprises (inasmuch as English food can surprise) among them a generous serving of niçoise salad with moist French beans, perfectly done eggs and anchovy strips; fat pork sausages served with crisp bacon and a pile of caramelised onions; and a satisfying round of cottage pie. The French fries are addictively good, while the just-right apple pie sets the standard for this town. A live singer entertains with golden oldies from Wednesday to Saturday nights. What more could you want from a restaurant?

Though Bora Bora is located at the unsexy end of Sentosa on Palawan Beach, what you lose out in eye candy is more than compensated for with excellent service, tranquil surroundings (read: no annoying high-pitch giggles), and deckchairs that dont cost extra to use and come splinter-free.

The beach bar, which faces the ocean, attracts a regular clientele happy to avoid the Sunday see-and-be-seen tradition of KM8 and Café del Mar; theyd rather be surrounded by good pizzas ($16), burgers ($12), ice-cold beers ($8-$14) and power-packed mojitos ($10) instead. For the sun-shy, there are hammocks and a pool table ($2 a game) available.

Kitchen closes at 8pm. Last order for drinks is at 8.30pm.
content.openingtimes:
Sun-Thu 11am-9pm
Fri, Sat & eve of PH 11am-10pm

content.description: Admission is free but heritage tour fee applies: $10 (adults) $8 (55 years and above) $5 (18 years and below) $3 (NUS students)

Another Harry's joins the pack, this time at newly refurbished location Cuppage Terrace. Perfect to escape the hordes of Orchard Road, have a drink and listen to Harry's regular guitarist Paul Ponnaduria.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thur 11.30am - 2am; Fri, Sat and Eve of PH 11.30am-3am, Sundays 11.30am-1am.

content.description: Singapore has a handful of Irish pubs already, but The Toucan ranks alongside Muddy Murphys as one of the best (its location in the somewhat seedy Duxton Hill notwithstanding). The look of an archetypal old-school boozer is ably re-created indoors, complete with a cosy lounge area, big-screen TV and pool table. Outdoors, though, is the real draw: heres a proper pub garden dotted with ample bench seating, plus the occasional barrel, wooden barrow and wishing well. It all sounds terribly tacky but, remarkably, it works. And on a warm Singapore evening is there any other type? a pint of Guinness ($11) here is exactly what a thirsty, mildly homesick expat hankers for. Drinks $9-$35.

This genial joint, tucked away in a food court off Bukit Timah Road, is more than a pub its a one-stop shop. The busy bar fronts three affordable eateries serving northern Indian, Thai-Vietnamese and Western fare. Meanwhile, the 50-50 mix of locals and chilled-out foreigners sups European beer in a landscaped garden complete with a mini-fish pond; the whole enterprise feels like a Goan-style resort bar. The kitchens close way too early, and the bar staff is charmingly amateurish, but with its low bar prices (a pint of Stella Artois is just $7), heavy-drinking patrons and infectious ambience, this is the least Singaporean bar in Singapore. Drinks $5-$10.

In a stretch with such a dense concentration of eateries as Holland Villages Lorong Mambong, it takes something extra for a place to stand out. In Al Qasrs favour is Lebanese head chef and owner Ghazi Georges Khanashat. Astonishingly, he uses no salt in his cooking herbs and spices are cleverly mixed to create flavour; though in the case of the eggplant, garlic and walnut salad, this translated into a rather bland dish. But most flavours are clean and pure, whether its the astringent green of rice wrapped in vine leaves, a creamy hummus fragrant with toasted pine nuts, a fresh halloumi cheese salad or the fluffy pita wraps of shredded lamb scented with cloves. Main courses $10-$25.

Who knew that such a good northern Indian restaurant was squirrelled away in the basement of a Holiday Inn? The ornate, upmarket setting of heavy fabrics and a fountain with a pond sets the scene for first-rate curries and tandoori meats. The flavours are intense, with many items not normally found in local Indian restaurants like the salty, oddly addictive ka panna drink made of crushed roasted pineapples tinged with cumin and mint, and the buttery naan embossed with dried fruits. The servings are large: our doggy-bagged fried ladies fingers dusted with mango powder, a pile of curried roast potatoes, and baby eggplant braised with tamarind made for perfect snacks the next day.

Luxury F&B company onelifestylegroup scores a hat-trick with its third restaurant, 24-hour Unopuro. Hungry ravers can tuck into a hearty post-clubbing meal of pizza and Roman- style Wagyu steaks courtesy of chef Salvatore from Naples.

Pizza and pasta from $8.88 from 11.30pm-6am; breakfast from 3-11am on weekdays and all day on weekends.

content.public-transport: Near station: Tanjong Pagar or Chinatown
content.openingtimes: Lunch 11.30am - 2.30pm (last order) Dinner 6.30pm - 10.30pm (last order) Closed Sunday

content.description: Youll find a myriad of knick-knacks in this nook, from magazines like Wallpaper* and Believer to independent handmade zines, animal-shaped rubber bands and even utensils. Located on the third storey of a shophouse along New Bridge Road, this new bookstore would appeal to those who are into Japanese aesthetics (read: its cutesy). It also has an online storebut if youre looking to actually buy books, Casual Poet might be a little too casual.
Not so haute cuisine in Rochester Park

From the IndoChine group comes Savanh, a bistro/lounge/restaurant that serves Asian tapas (read: the familiar spring rolls from IndoChine which is, not surprisingly, next door). Though some of the décor is questionable (pink chandeliers?), the starters are reliable and the bar area with its three-storey waterfall enjoyable.

Amsterdams famous restaurant/club has finally opened an outlet in Singapore. If you dont feel like lounging in white daybeds like some latter-day Roman shtick, you can just observe the drag queens working reception, the sassy gals serving drinks or the people making out in the unisex loo. Better try Dutch chef Ulpho van der Zalms smokin fusion cuisine first after all, the party only starts after dinner. There is only one 8pm seating for dinner. 4-course menu (vegetarian option available) $65++.
Mr Bean's Cafe was a Runner-up in Best Late-night Dining in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

Make your way through the usually crowded ground-floor pub and head upstairs to the suede-swathed banquettes and white table linen of The Brasserie. Popular with the Raffles Place suits, this is a great place for eavesdropping (a job interview was taking place at the next table during a recent lunch). The menu deals in modern French brasserie food, with a well-priced, three-course set lunch available for about $40. Particularly well done are the refreshing Waldorf salad (paired with thin slices of perfectly smoked duck) and the thick cuts of tuna steak nuzzling black olives in a pesto sauce.

This upmarket pizzeria serves Italian cuisine at affordable prices, from classic Italian salads and appetisers to 24 speciality, thin-crust, wood-fired pies each playfully named after famous Italian women. The open kitchen gives diners the opportunity to witness the preparation of pizzas, a feature thats especially popular with kids. Reasonably priced Italian wines can be selected to complement each of the dishes. Spizza also offers an islandwide delivery service (Hotline: 6377 7773).

Spizza was a Runner-up in Best Pizza in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Rocky's was Runner-up in Best Pizza in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Ya Kun was a Runner-up in Best Breakfast in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Astons was a Runner-up in Best Burger in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

Tucked away from the bustle of Orchard Road, this art museum at the newly built Luxe building, with 700 square metres of exhibition space, is bent on propelling contemporary Chinese fine art to the forefront of the South-East Asian art world and beyond.
Red House won Best Chilli Crab in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
content.openingtimes: Eaast Coast Mon-Fri 3.30-11.30pm; Sat & Sun 11.30am-11.30pm. Robertson Quay 5-11.30pm (last order 11.15pm). Sat & Sun 11am onwards.

content.description: Eastsiders will be thrilled to know that they dont have to travel to Orchard Road or Holland Village anymore to visit Toni&Guy. Located in a refurbished Peranakan shophouse amid the gastronomical delights of Katong, the East Coast branch officially opened earlier this year. Helmed by directors May Eng and Dawn Soo, you can also catch another popular stylist, director Connee Law, who shuttles between the East Coast and Holland Village salons. In keeping with the neighbourhoods ambience, the vibe is raw and relaxed, with timber panelling and exposed brick interiors. Aside from offering the usual cut-colour-wash-blow dry services, you can also indulge in the System Professional treatments and colouring services using Wella products on the second floor. Then, head to the room next door for a manicure and pedicure to complete the whole pampering experience. What we love most perhaps is the complimentary pick-up service thats exclusive to this branch; the salon arrange rides for clients living in the east, even if youre coming directly from Changi Airport.
Moomba Tuckshop won Best Sandwich in our - Who is top of the Table? feature.

Its not easy being a jeweller here, what with competition coming from all sides. No wonder Goldheart Jewelry has been leveraging on local star power of late, collaborating with celebrities Eunice Olsen and Lisa Ang, and now forging a partnership with renowned bridalwear designer Ted Wu. The Orient Bliss collections borrow from a number of Asian cultures; the Chinese collection focuses on flowers in bloom designs, with dark pink sapphires (from $1,568) that complement Wus Chinese-collared gowns perfectly. The Japanese range features purple-gold sakura floral motifs in a necklace-and-earrings combination, as well as a belt and pretty hair attachments (from $1,628). Meanwhile the Indian pieces zero in on piercing blue topaz, in the form of white-gold peacock tails (from $1,048). Launched just recently, these original creations will not be sitting on the shelves for long. Word to the wise for all bling-less brides-to-be: head to the nearest Goldheart outlet now.

Though pronounced Strange-lets and not Strangel-ets, this quirky little nook will definitely choke the hell out of your credit card. Offering creations by chic designers like Nils Holger Moormann and David Restorick, the store is a delight for fans of luxurious furnishings think beautiful lamps, sleek bookcases and other peculiar decor items like fertility dolls. Strangelets also has a lovely collection of Xhosa crafts by the Imiso design collective, thanks to co-owner Joshua Comaroffs South African roots. Clockwork beetles (available in three sizes) from Insectlab and Moormanns mutant chair-cumbookcase piece are a couple of must-see curios, but impulse buyers beware: the bill is going to hurt.

Duxton Hill in the daytime is a fine example of traditional shophouse architecture and a good place for a stroll. In the evening you can enjoy dining at the increasing number of fine restaurants, while surrounded by karaoke joints and lively bars overflowing with very friendly ladies from around the region. Restaurants and other venues in Duxton Hill Berjaya Hotel (Duxton Road) - hotel Broth - Western restaurant L Cube Music Studio - live Music Venue Cumi Bali (Duxton Road) - Indonesian restaurant Kay Ngee Tan Architects - gallery Uluru - Australian restaurant The Universal - Western restaurant
content.public-transport: Near station: Tanjong Pagar or Chinatown

content.openingtimes: Mon - Thurs 5pm - 1am Fri - Sat 5pm to late

content.description:
The playful and energetic band interacts well with customers who are busy requesting songs, tipping and bidding for music, or just scribbling notes on the wall. Just like the original Howl at the Moon in the US, the band is highly skilled and plays multiple instruments and nearly every song imaginable. As audiences will always make different requests, each revisit promises a new experience. On the downside, the band likes to perform ‘I Will Survive’ a little too much. Its speciality is a duelling piano challenge. Different drink specials are offered every night.
Read our review of 1 Nite Stand Comedy Nights at Howl at the Moon.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Sat 6pm-3am, $15 (includes drink); comedy nights last Thu-Sat of the month, $50.

content.description: In a fickle town like Singapore, it means something when a restaurant has been in business since 1953. The home-style cooking here is lush and intensely flavoured. Best of all, prices are extremely reasonable for the portions: an $8 small serving will easily feed two. Among the dishes to try are fried discs of squid, with the evocative taste of smoky belachan, and eggplant braised in soy sauce. Fluffy fooyong is streaked with tiny prawns and crabmeat, while pork strips sautéed in chilli and assam are the perfect comfort food. For dessert, the chendol, drenched in a white blanket of coconut cream, is unforgettable.

The Too is a reference to Chat Masalas other outlet on the East Coast; clever that theyre covering both ends of the island. The ochre and rustorange splashes on the wall set the mood for a perfectly cooked meal of curries, crisp naans and pilaffs flecked with fried shallots. And service is brisk. When the bowl of sautéed ladys fingers arrives mildly chilli-hot, and not at all slimy you know youre in safe hands, a feeling confirmed as you mop up the creamy and nutty chicken korma, a saffron-tinged fish tikka showered with onion crescents, and a tomato-y curry of prawns and eggplant.

So you think Geylangs seedy? Well, not any more the areas getting a facelift. Kaki Kaki, the latest offshoot of the Bussorah Street stalwart Wayan Retreat Balinese Spa, is now open at Malay Village (Wayan in Balinese means first in the family). Combining two concepts into one, customers can choose from massages, foot reflexology, facials, manicures and pedicures. Opening offers include foot reflexology ($10 for ten minutes; $28 for 30 minutes); back, shoulder and neck massages ($10 for ten minutes; $48 for 45 minutes); and 45-minute Balinese-style body massages for $50.

This museum features the most comprehensive collection of Peranakan artefacts in the world, displayed through ten galleries that explore the various facets of this vibrant culture. Peranakan Museum was also featured in Straight out of the past.   Things to See   Conversations Gallery As Peranakans re-examine their culture and identity in the face of modernity, this gallery serves as an introduction for the public by showcasing a myriad of Peranakan clothing, food, jewellery and artefacts.   Nonya Gallery Domesticity has always been a prominent trait of the Nonyas. The importance of the sarong kebaya, the traditional Nonya attire thats exhibited in this gallery, will be revealed as it not only highlights the skill involved in beadwork and embroidery, its also a preoccupation of the traditional Peranakan woman.
content.public-transport: Near station: City Hall, Dhoby Ghaut

entry.name: National Archives of Singapore Lobby Gallery

version.name: National Archives of Singapore Lobby Gallery

content.description: Established by an act of parliament in 1968, the NAS has moved beyond its traditional role as national record keeper, responsible for the collection, preservation and management of Singapore's public and private archival records, some of which date back to the early 19th century. It now also holds exhibitions showcasing the nation's history and heritage in its lobby.

content.public-transport: Near station: Newton, then take a taxi.

content.description: Verve has moved into the ground floor of the two-storey colonial building that used to house the Turquoise Room. The lush surroundings of Gillman Village that serve as its setting still lure, while the kitchen keeps things low-key with simple Italian bistro fare. Whether done aglio olio-style or tossed with hunks of plump slipper lobster in a white wine-reduced broth, the pastas are crowd-pleasers. The crowning glory, however, is the thin-crust pizza section. Our Barzoni (bacon, mushroom, garlic mascarpone and shredded basil) and Santino (pepperoni, chorizo, baby spinach and jalapeño) were outstanding. Main courses $24-$36.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu noon-11pm; Fri & Sat noon-midnight; Sun noon-10pm

content.description:
The cocktail is king at this speciality bar that says no to bubbly, wine and beer, and a big yes to mixed drinks especially those made with freshly squeezed fruit juices and premium alcohol. But before you sigh and say, Not another one of those bars, consider this: its new, fresh and still relatively hipster-free. Housed in what used to be a caretakers lodge, this 30-seater boasts works by local artists hanging on the walls and a baby grand piano (complete with singer) parked in a corner. It wont be long before this upmarket neighbourhood bar becomes the latest spot to see and be seen so go now.

Drinks $16-$20.
content.public-transport: Near station: Buona Vista, then take a taxi.

content.description: What a delightful little bolthole this is, especially in the evening out on the verandah tables. The dual menu is French and Vietnamese and we suspect the pull is the latter option. Especially delightful is the wonderfully named cha ca la vong, a sizzling fried sea bass smothered with a paste of golden turmeric and fresh dill. Pair that with a superb pomelo salad studded with prawns and peanuts, and beef pho drenched in an earthy, rich broth. Gold wallpaper, timber panels and starched linen complete the muted IndoChine vibe, though service can be a little patchy.

Right at the corner of two busy roads, Sum Kees homey zhi-char is worth braving the traffic fumes for. We love the har-jeong chicken coated in a crispy batter, and pork strips stir-fried with bitter gourds in a black bean sauce. Sensational too is the fu yu with sweet potato leaves, and the cubes of fried tofu embedded with a thin layer of cereal. Meanwhile, the glistening pork ribs and fried beef noodles never disappoint. The late opening hours are a bonus, especially after a night carousing at nearby clubs and bars. A home delivery service for the River Valley Road area is also available with a minimum order of $20.

The Lee clan has been making sar hor fun since its Ipoh days back in 1948. Tender loops of snow-white noodles are draped in a variety of sauces and toppings and theyre all worth trying, whether its prawns, mushrooms and bean sprouts; broiled chicken shreds; or just tangled with globes of wonton. The side dishes are equally good, including golden bricks of fried tofu, and piles of kai lan soaking in thick oyster sauce. Minus point: they charge for tap water.

Newly touted as a business lounge away from the office, this year-old lifestyle/F&B site has undergone a major revamp. Thanks to a recent partnership with the Copthorne and Millennium hotel group and JetQuay terminal, Geek Terminal moves beyond emailing and dining to serve as a hub for business travellers. Press the flesh with clients in a space that has rearrangeable soundproofing (sections can be cordoned off for private meetings). Wi-Fi is free (and Cisco-secured) and the latest Panasonic, Eubiq and Canon gadgets are available for you to make presentations. After youre done, a limousine will whisk you back to your hotel or the airport; you can even check in from Geek Terminal itself. With geekdom coming full circle in the heart of the CBD, its certainly still hip to be square.

Artist Jason Wee has flown the New York coop (for now) and turned his apartment into an intimate gallery directly opposite the hulking Great World City. Wee hopes this will provide a space for international and local artists, as well as aspiring curators, to dabble in. This is one place that eschews a commercial imperative and an institutional agenda to fuel an alternative art scene.

Mr Han is his name, and experimenting with raw materials is his game. With outlets in Chinatown, Bishan, Yishun, Ang Mo Kio and the West Coast, this art therapist and his creative team organise workshops for families and kids.

Arty Art Gallery has a wide range of Burmese collections alongside selections of Asian and international artists artworks from around the world.   Email viewing@artyartgallery.com or call 6729 9203 for an appointment

Artesans focus is on promoting undiscovered talent and it has successfully launched a number of peripheral artists. Exhibitions feature a mix of local and international talent; together with residency programmes, these help the gallery build artistic links as well as raise the profile of Asian art. Directions:
Newton Station is the nearest MRT; take bus 171 from the station and alight at Sixth Avenue Centre (Artesan is located along the same row of shop houses just before the junction of Sixth Avenue and Bukit Timah Road, just above Standard Chartered Bank).
content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat 11am-6pm Closed on Sun and Public Holidays

content.description: The consultants at Art Insight provide the artistically challenged with advice on how to best showcase any artwork in a wide range of venues they work in art galleries, public spaces, as well as homes and offices.
content.public-transport: Near station: Outram Park | Buses: 61, 166, 167, 196 and 197

content.description: The store behind more than 600 cultural books and comics, Asiapac Books strength lies in covering philosophy, history and literature. Not only does Asiapac sell the books, it publishes most of them. Its titles have reached readers across the Asia-Pacific region and Europe as well as the US. You may purchase them at their showroom or simply order online. Go to the website for full details.

After two years in business, the artsy label has moseyed its way down to Bali Lane with a slight shift in focus to a more eco-conscious theme, turning recycled fabrics into 70s-style fashions, scarves and pen holders. The new digs will also function as an installation space displaying works by talented local artists. The concept of the not-so-ordinary store is to set up a creative platform for the local arts scene. Only time will tell whether the shared vision is mission impossible or a sure thing. Either way, you can save the environment and jazz up your closet with exclusive pieces from $65 upwards.

The popular lifestyle store hawking authentic Kyoto products has opened its fourth outlet at the Singapore Flyer. In-store, youll find strong-coloured, textured-fabric products handcrafted by authentic Kyotoites: looped bags, zippered mobile-phone cases, tissue holders, mobile-phone straps, dome-shaped coin purses, and a range of accessories in rabbit and butterfly motifs. Not satisfied with just hawking kimono-themed wares, theres now a snug café selling cakes, pastries and matcha-cino tea, proving you can have your cake and eat it, too.

Busiest on dry weekends, the ambience of unregulated disarray is an enjoyable antidote to the Lion Citys much-too organised malls. Vintage lovers can expect to trawl for rich pickings. On a typical afternoon, youll find rarities like vinyl records, a boxed set of retro Iittala glassware from Scandinavia ($10), and a charming cuckoo clock ($5).

A modern Thai restaurant blooms in Hort Park. With a menu designed by Australian consultant chef David Hamilton responsible for Phukets The Banyan Tree and Trisara, and Bangkoks Dream Hotel signature dishes include hor muk salmon (spicy grilled salmon soufflé), yam nua Wagyu (grilled red curry-rubbed Wagyu beef, papaya salad, yoghurt and chilli jam) and khao nuew dam (black sticky rice and date pudding with tamarind caramel sauce and mango ice cream).

Read our full review of Kha here. Kha won Best New Restaurant in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

The interiors arent much to look at, but you know the place is serious about its vegetarian menu when you see Buddhist monks tucking into the salads. Theres nothing terribly sophisticated about the offerings (no mock meats, for instance). Instead, dishes are simply flavoured and served up in a flash, though the wait is a little longer during lunch hours. The avocado mousse is smooth as velvet, while the gado gado is served with a terrific, crunchy almond dressing.

Its easy to see why loyal customers have followed this charming Thai family-run outfit from its original Farrer Wet Market location: every dish rings with flavour. Sensational are the betel nut leaves wrapped around crisply sautéed dried prawns, coconut flakes, peanuts and lemongrass shards. Pair a mound of sticky rice with golden-battered tofu and a mild green fish curry spiked with slightly bitter baby eggplants. End the meal with a bowl of not-toosweet, coconut-y red ruby dessert. The place also does a brisk takeaway trade.

No, its not an Aussie outfit. This enduring Peranakan favourite has relocated from the East Coast to fabulous new digs next to the Substation. The two-storey shophouse (private dining rooms are upstairs) is stuffed with Peranakan antiques. The menu introduces some new items like fluffy omelettes with wild pepper leaves. The standards such as the creamy rendang, lightly spiced banana flower salad, and fragrantly tender chap chye are superbly done, though a little expensive for the small portions.

Mention Brewerkz to any barfly and theyll think of the flagship gastropub at Riverside Point. The microbrewery also has strategically situated mini-outlets at the Indoor Stadium and Changis Terminal Three, and now the company that claims We do what Werkz has spread its tentacles further into Singapores suburbs with a new opening just off the Bukit Timah Road. 

On paper its a move so logical its inspired: the area is known for its predominantly Western population of thir(s)tysomethings with plentiful disposable income. Build it and they will come: a no-brainer, surely? But as the more traditional watering holes Bullfrog and Old Brown Shoe just down the road have already proved, the roadside boozer is not such an easy trick to pull off. 

For starters, unless youre a neighbour youre likely to find parking a nightmare; just combing the back streets for a space leaves you in need a drink. Once there, youll struggle to find a USP: rather cheap-looking seating? Check. EPL football on TV? Check. Extortionate bar-food menu? Triple check. And while the wait-staff are nothing if not accommodating, their continual habit of interrupting conversation with refill offers borders on maddening. With its Belgian/speciality brain-numbers and fruity fancies, the diverse Euro-style drinks list at least provides a laudable alternative to the yawn-inducing Heineken and Tiger staples. But a $15 bottle of Maredsous Blond seems scant reward for trekking out to this cramped tavern. Bar-hungry Bukit Timah-ites will likely be left once again with a bitter aftertaste (as I was after trying the Pilsner): BBT is too small to feel significant, too close to the main road to feel much more than a glorified alfresco bar. This afterthought of a micro-microbrewery only Werkz if youre (very) local and less than discerning. Brewerkz won Best Beer Bar in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thurs 11am - midnight; Fri, Sat & eve of PH noon - 1am, Sun 11am - midnight.

content.description: Sometimes whacking a few balls is the only real way to blow off steam after a particularly tough day (or week) at the office. Fortunately, this modern, well-equipped range will provide you with a bucket of balls, a club and a field of green where you can whack until youre spent. Speaking of spending, balls cost only $0.06 each during peak hours a small price to pay to become a true sultan of swing.

This fun-filled indoor entertainment area for kids has an interactive playscape, a soft play area for wee ones under the age of three, a café dishing up yummy salads, pastas and wait for it... a nail bar for mummies while their kids are hard at play. Ages 2-11.

$15 (weekdays unlimited play; weekends & public holidays for two hours); $3 per extra half-hour; $6 (under-twos, unlimited play); free (babies only).

This venue closed on 30 Apr 2010
Disappointing mod-French by the beach at Sentosa
Founded in 2004, the At Room Gallery showcases works by local and international up-and-coming artists specialising in a myriad of mediums including fine art, illustrations and even comic art.

Nestled snugly in the new up-and-coming lifestyle enclave of Turf Club Road is Sylvias Secrets The Oasis Day Spa. It has taken over the premises of a former stable with many of the original fixtures, including trademark wooden beams and an ultra-high ceiling. And heres an added bonus: there is ample (and free) parking space so long as you go during the daytime and avoid the dinner crowd congregating at its next-door neighbour, the acclaimed European-style bistro Picotin run by Sebastien Reullier.

We go to get our nails done in a bid to escape from it all, but for the harried lady executive, Polished Divas Nail Lounge is a godsend. Aside from offering in-seat blockbuster entertainment via portable DVD players, customers will also receive complimentary wireless access so they can continue surfing the web and keep on top of emails while getting their nails done were assuming pedicures more so than manicures. Holland Village's outlet features new Ogawa Koibito massage chairs (nice touch), including in-seat, on-demand entertainment.

After almost two years of residency in Raffles City, the shop cart has moved from the first level of the mall to the newly renovated part of the basement, in close proximity to Cocoa Trees and J&Co. What catches the eye immediately is the cutlery with the most adorable cake and pastry adornments. A six-piece set of stainless-steel fondue sticks comes camouflaged as cookie bowls, tomato baskets and party cakes. A mixed berry pie and coloured pastas become handles for cake servers ($16), and chocolate truffles and pralines are memo magnets in disguise ($13-$15).
Uninspired down-under-themed bar and steakhouse

An unassuming little biker bar off Alexander Road, Handle Bar resembles one of those highway stops you often see in American road-trip movies. Given its ramshackle surroundings made out of used motorcycle parts, its not surprising that beer dispensed from contraptions that look like recycled engines is its clienteles booze of choice ($24 for a jug of Heineken). And what goes better with beer than spicy chicken wings ($10 for six pieces)? And oh, while you are loading up, get your precious ride a good wash and polish for $30.

Little India isnt just all about eating dosais, shopping at Mustafa Centre or strolling along Desker Road. Increasingly, quirky, left-of-centre bars are finding their niche within the confines of the refurbished shophouses. One such spot is Domus Café & Bar located just off Race Course Road. Its name draws inspiration from the ancient Italian homes that often contain an indoor courtyard, just like this charming spot does, in which rustic benches and tables have been set up in tall bamboo surroundings to help create that alone in your own world feeling. Atmosphere aside, Domus boasts a curious concoction youve probably never had the pleasure of sampling before: vodka and Yakult cocktails ($12). The bar, which doubles up as a gallery space has a front indoor portion decked out with floral wallpaper and white acrylic seats.

New to the Club Street and Ann Siang Hill drinking scene is this Moulin Rouge-esque bar. All plush, warm and relaxed, its a soothing spot for a weekend tipple or after-work happy hour. Set yourself up at one of the outside tables to watch the world go by, or, with a glass of red in hand, claim one of the velvet-covered armchairs inside under the chandeliers.

Drinks from $12.

Like so many good eateries in this town, the no-frills interiors (fake flowers and hanging plants) provide the setting for fab (and cheap) Indonesian fare. The usual suspects of kangkong sambal, ruby-red chilli eggplant and sayur lodeh are reliable, but be adventurous. An entire log of squid is perfectly grilled in a sweet, black sauce; and its hard not to inhale the chicken satay, the thick cuts of meat marinated in an unctuous sauce made of Indonesian palm seeds. In the evenings, sit on the five-foot way and watch the prostitutes ply their trade while chomping on the excellent chendol drizzled with thick gula jawa.

entry.name: Punjab Da Dhaba/ Our Village / Colombo

version.name: Punjab Da Dhaba/ Our Village / Colombo

content.description: This place incorporates four different menus Sri Lankan, north Indian, Indian-Chinese and Punjabi. The latter is a fragrant and spicy tour of the subcontinental interiors. Purists will be thrilled to learn the kitchen uses no milk, ghee or lard, nor does it serve beef or pork. Theres plenty to savour including crunchy fritters of onion and chick-pea flour, and fenu greek-scented Koliwada prawns. The ladys fingers with caramelised onions are a wonder, as are the skewers of seer fish, all golden with turmeric. Mop up the tongue-searing lamb and spinach with some naan stuffed with cottage cheese. Best seats in the house are on the balcony. Main courses $16-$32 (minimum $30 p.p.).

The gaudy interiors complete with a dinky stage have not changed in decades, and thats the charm of the Red Star. The food, too, has not been updated so its all a little less refined than, say, Crystal Jade, but no one cares. Most of the regulars over three generations come for the weekend dim sum feast where trolleys of siew mai, braised chicken feet, char siew tarts, roast pork and century egg congee are wheeled around by loud, scowling aunties with hearts of gold. Come early on Sundays (around 10.30am), else be prepared to wait and risk the food going cold by then. Average per head $10-$15.
Greenhouse won Best Champagne Sunday Brunch in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
A famous sea-front group of seafood restaurants including the aptly named Jumbo and a branch of No Signboard.

content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat 10am-7pm except Wed 9am-7.30pm, Sun and holidays 11am-6pm.

content.description: NTUCs latest concept supermarket makes no effort to hide its focus on the higher-end tastes of condo dwellers and landed property owners. Wide aisles are stocked with the usual suspects as well as novelty, display-only square watermelons, caviar and shockingly expensive musk melons from Japan. Expect high prices for an average selection of fancy foods.

Established in 1940, this Hainanese stalwart is Singapores answer to New Yorks Soup Nazi. The elderly gentleman who we think is the owner stands at the counter, watches the room with an eagle eye and barks orders at the matronly staff while running the accounts on an abacus. Choping tables is verboten: apparently hes been known to kick people out. Several waitresses whispered to us, out of the corner of their mouths, not to wait for our dinner partners, and hurry up and order. As a result, everyone inhales the chicken rice and steam boat. Yes, youve had better elsewhere, but theres nothing like a delicious state of tension to stir the appetite.

If sizzling, butter-topped steaks are your thing, Lions Den is your place. The restaurant reeks of no-nonsense Soviet-era attitude (despite being run by a Hainanese) and cooking, so expect to walk out with food smells clinging to your clothes. The appetisers and desserts arent spectacular, but one sweet exception is the Russian staple flambéd bombe alaska the fiery relative of baked alaska Norwegian omelette or glace au four. Lions Den features a proper Bombe Alaska doused in dark rum and set ablaze at your table by a skilled waiter. Other than that, cross your fingers, stick to the meats and dont expect haute cuisine.

entry.name: House of Traditional Javanese Massage and Beauty Care

version.name: House of Traditional Javanese Massage and Beauty Care

content.description: Theres a new and exciting multi-purpose venture at the iconic Big Splash landmark. Touted as a lifestyle hub, Playground @ Big Splash features a wide array of dining and recreational amenities. Home to Carls Jr, KFC, Sushi Tei and Starbucks, parents who need a perk-me-up need not worry. Meanwhile the kids will be kept busy with a host of recreational options including the puntastically named LilliPutt (Singapores first themed, indoor mini-golf course) and Frisk n Romp Kids Playclub. Go to the website for the full list of facilities.

For wannabe Singapore Idols, Party World is the obvious place to hone your singing skills. Affordable room rentals and a hefty bilingual song catalogue should ensure hours of crooning entertainment, not to mention various discounts available to NTUC cardholders. With 11 branches spread across the island, Party World has become quite a karaoke institution.

content.openingtimes: Mon - Fri 11am - 10pm Sat, Sun & PH 10am - 9pm First Mon of the Month 2 - 10 pm

content.description: This is home to Singapores independent cinema scene. Featuring local and regional movies, talks by directors and discussions with actors, Sinema Old School offers daily specials like Tuesday Shorts, Action Wednesday, Love Thursday and Rojak Fridays.

Chemical exfoliation or pumice scrubs for callused feet? Thats just old news...how about giving the Doctor Fish method a go? Curious fish, imported from the highlands of Turkey, specialise in eating dead skin cells and, in the process, micromassage your feet. Yuck-factor aside, its an all-natural, painless and fun way to pamper yourself. And though the ticklish might shy away from it, it is worth trying for the novelty factor alone. You can also ask about the range of specialised treatments designed to treat skin conditions like psoriasis, dermatitis and eczema. Prices vary.

Experience the healing hands of Michelle Tessensohn, a practitioner of Zen shiatsu (finger pressure), and be rid of annoying backaches, insomnia and even a nasty temper. This non-invasive form of acupuncture also bio-energetic healing recognises the energy force called ki and uses it to unclog blockages and allow a smooth channelling of energy, thus achieving a balanced physical and psychological state. Sanctum also holds motivational talks every month; contact them for more information. By appointment only. 
$120 (initial consultation and therapy), $90 (subsequent sessions).

Heres a secret find for youLovely DeArt, a three-year-old store, is stocked from floor to ceiling with rustic knickknacks and country-style home furniture like a rosette magazine rack ($48) and Victorian lamps ($85). Other items include a three-foot-tall wooden drawer set and antique clocks that still work. Set aside a few hours to pore through every tapestry, painting and handicraft. The good news is the retail prices here are only a fraction of the usual prices found on Orchard Road, or at self-professed rustic specialists.
Ideal for business folk to enjoy drinks over lunch, dinner or post-dinner. Harry's Happy Hours: 11am to 8pm, Harry's Crazy Hours: 5pm to 7pm

The team behind One Rochester has gone from West to East with its newest offering at Big Splash. Injecting the former water park with a splash of luxe, the seafront restaurant serves up a menu of contemporary European fare with touches of Asian flavour. For wine lovers, there are more than 280 Old and New World wines (from $60) to pick and pair with 1 Twenty Sixs cheese platters (from $36).
content.openingtimes: A la Carte: Mon-Sun 6.30-11pm; last orders at 10.30pm. Sunday Brunch: 9.30am-3pm. Gastro bar: Sun-Thu 6pm-1am; Fri, Sat & holiday eve 6pm-3am.

content.description:
Checking into the Naumi Hotel isnt just another cookie-cutter hospitality experience. The 40- room business luxury hotel is equipped with some of the niftiest extras any traveller, business or otherwise, could wish for. Aesop toiletries, a Nespresso machine, designer furniture like Poltrona Fraus Dondo Rocking Chair and the all-important iPod docking station come standard in every room. Personally, we like it for the PS3, Nintendo Wii and X-Box 360 rental service. Lets face it: which business traveller couldnt use some quality game time? 

From $390-$1,200 per room per night.
Great expectations fall flat at Sentosa

Open since 1992, this pub has been overlooked since nearby Clarke Quay was made over its a lot quieter than it deserves to be. Situated within an atmospheric shophouse, the space is decked out with a pool table and dart board. On busier nights the action spills out onto the front porch, and if you ask nicely, the friendly staff will let you take over the music or even dance on the bar. If youre up for a big evening, theres a ten drinks for $38 offer (before 10pm, nightly).   Happy hour 5-9pm, two jugs of house beer for $38.

The austere interiors are a perfect backdrop for Shinryokus speciality: luscious yakitori sticks. The flavours of seafood and vegetables unfold beneath smoky top notes; try prawns wrapped in bacon and shiso leaves, and cubes of pork laced with sweet garlic. But the simplest skewers, like the earthy, meaty mushrooms, are the most memorable. The set lunches are particularly good value, especially the $10 tendon a huge bowl of rice topped with dark gold tempura prawns, fish and vegetables. 
Set lunch $10-$25, yakitori $4-$10.

This place lays claim to being the only restaurant in town serving Kashmiri cuisine. That fact translates into snow-white raita speckled with curd and walnuts, and rich, strongly flavoured curries like rogan josh. The eggplant, perfumed with tamarind, is a delight, as are the mutton curry bathed in a crimson red sauce and chicken marinated with aniseed. A good base is either a pile of crisp garlic naan, or rice slashed with saffron saffron streaks and studded with almonds and cheese cubes. The service tends to be inexperienced, but happily the chef comes out to chat and takes orders, so grab him instead.

Looks are deceptive the drab ante-chamber with takeaway counter looks just like any other eatery in Little India, while the dining room feels more like a school canteen. The wait-staff lug trays and pails filled with curries and lentil, and happily slop food onto your still-wet banana leaf before you eat it with your fingers. But it tastes just fabulous. From mutton curries and firm river fish fried to a charcoal-black to turmeric-hued chicken curries and sweetbreads, its all good and ridiculously cheap. The sweet, frothy chai is the perfect accompaniment. The predominantly Indian clientele is a testament to its success.
Average per head $7.

The Saint Pierre group has teamed up with Sebastien Reullier, of Sebastiens fame, to create an ambitious combination of bistro, bar and organic épicerie.
