The excellent homey menu (courtesy of recipes from the family of Adrian Zecha, the guy behind the AmanResorts) centres around daily set specials, which dont change all that often. The Tuesday set, for instance, is a superb beef stew the meat fork-tender and perfumed with salty-sweet soy sauce, alongside a huge mound of mash, cauliflower and broccoli stir fried with garlic and perfectly grilled peppers. Side dishes include fried chicken wings served with a terrific mango and cucumber salsa; crisp spring rolls with fresh basil and mint; and intensely flavoured carrot and potato soups. A special delivery service to nearby offices, in tiffin containers, is offered to members. Tiffin Club was the winner in our recent Eating Al Desko - Working Lunch feature. And was featured in our recent Comfort Food - Basic Instincts - Where to Eat feature.

Long ago, the Marmalade Group staked out the higher ground of casual Western meals, and its never really let go of the prize. Its Toast outlet at Raffles Place is a hive of lunchtime activity, with a predominantly expat clientele. Daily specials keep things interesting, though were always partial to the green soba noodles ($6.50) scented with sesameseed oil and enmeshed with crisp sugar snap peas and shiitake mushrooms. The wraps (around $7.50) are hefty rolls of imaginative fillings like spicy chicken, fresh mango and mint; though our recent roast chicken, roast peppers and Emmenthal combo could have done with a zesty relish. The home-made soups (from $5.50) come with a chunk of ciabatta. To finish, order one of the yummy lemon cupcakes ($3.70).  Toast was included in our recent Eating Al Desko - Working Lunch feature.

Simply Sandwich scores points for its smart packaging, and for the quantity and quality of their servings, though the fillings (roast chicken, tuna salad, ploughmans) evoke a sense of déjà vu. The bread, invariably (but not always) softer, tastes fresher than most. For variety, order the triple packs ($8), which hold three triangles of thickly cut bread with fillings such as avocado, alfalfa and blue cheese (barely any in our order); cheese and chutney; chunky egg salad; poached salmon; very salty smoked salmon and thick lashings of cream cheese; and ham and cheese. The sandwiches come in different breads grains, rye and brown though we were hard-pressed to be able to distinguish between them. Simply Sandwich was included in our recent Eating Al Desko - Working Lunch feature.

One of a pair duking it out with Pret A Manger (the other is Simply Sandwich, just across the road) for supremacy on the same stretch, The Sandwich Shop offers a comprehensive takeaway menu that includes vegetarian sandwiches, breakfast sets and platters for large groups. The chicken tikka ($7) is almost always sold out. Our ham and Brie baguette ($7.50) was clammy and dry thanks to its stint in the chiller (a fate common to many of the sandwiches we tried, so when ordering, insist on fresh portions that arent swiped from the chiller). Rather good was the Club TSS ($7.90) a chunk of onion bread embracing salad, large cuts of hard-boiled eggs and bacon strips. We were stumped by the chicken satay salad ($6.50). The generous tiles of moist, curry-flavoured chicken, crushed peanuts, tinned pineapple slices and leaves, we understood but what does lemon mayonnaise have to do with satay? The Sandwich Shop was included in our recent Working Al Desko - Working Lunch feature. Note - 8 Jan 08 - Pret a Manger has now closed its' branch in Singapore.

Theres such a charming Sydney vibe about Graze. Its bucolic location in a black-and-white bungalow in Rochester Park is a plus, as is the vastly improved service. The breakfast menu is wideranging, from eggs done to your liking and muesli to freshly squeezed fruit juices and inch-thick toast. But the star attraction is the fry-up ($18), here served in a castiron pan crowded with fat bratwurst, sautéed mushrooms, sunny-side-up eggs, baked beans and nicely oily bacon. Thoughtfully, a vegetarian version is also available. The few low notes were banana pancakes overwhelmed by the red currant sauce ($13), expensive mojitos ($18) that needed a lot more alcohol and none-too-clean mens toilets. Graze was included in our recent Morning Glory - best western breakfasts feature.

Who serves up prawn cocktails these days, let alone T-bone steak, chips and peas? Well, Colbar does, and loyal fans love them for it. The place, looking for all the world like a glorified tin shed, is locked in a time warp (circa 1956), and thats just fine with us. The cooking isnt great on a recent visit, the poached eggs ($5.50) were the texture of cotton wool, and the sausages ($9) a touch mealy, accompanied by wooden chips but its all cheap and good, and just what the doctor ordered after a hard nights partying. At our breakfast, the next table cracked open a bottle of beer to go with their omelette its that kind of place. Word to the wise: theres no air-conditioning, just lazy ceiling fans, so be prepared to shvitz a little when its warm outside. Colbar was included in our recent Morning Glory - best western breakfasts feature.

The Taoist Mission is an organisation that aims to develop the understanding of Taoism in Singapore. Open to anyone interested in Taoist culture and philosophy, the mission provides one-on-one support and links to local temples, talks and events.

The Darul Arqam Association promotes the Islamic faith and provides guidance and assistance to all Muslim converts in Singapore. There are weekly orientation sessions where interested participants are given an overview of Islam, and more than 15 additional courses on a wide range of subjects, including Quran recitation, Arabic language, and even a marriage guidance course.

entry.name: HSBC Tree Top Walk at Macritchie Reservoir

address.street: Venus Drive, off Upper Thomson Road

version.name: HSBC Tree Top Walk at Macritchie Reservoir

address.street: Venus Drive, off Upper Thomson Road

content.description:
The Tree Top Walk at MacRitchie Reservoir takes you through the different stages of a mature secondary forest. Its the first of its kind in Singapore and South-East Asia. The bridge part rises as high as 27 metres, and you can see as many as 80 bird and eight reptile varieties, and 18 rare species of trees. National Parks Board calls it one of the best hiking routes, but be sure to wear the right shoes; its graded moderate-to-difficult. Getting to the bridge, and walking it and back is a 10.5km journey. And, oh, beware of falling branches a man was killed by one earlier this year after a heavy rainfall. 
Contact the National Parks Board (1800471 7300) for more information on individual parks.
content.openingtimes: Tue to Fri: 9.00 a.m. - 5.00 p.m. Sat, Sun and Public Holidays: 8.30 a.m. - 5.00 p.m.

content.description: Formed in 1977, the Hindu Centre is a cultural organisation promoting the study and practice of Hinduism in Singapore. Located in a refurbished shophouse on Owen St, the Centre provides facilities and educational opportunities for its members, as well as introductory courses to anyone interested in understanding the Hindu faith. Please visit their website for more information about the courses conducted.

Mantra is a contemporary Indian restaurant that caters to the downtown crowd with a range of tasty vegetarian delicacies from all over India. For fans of tamarind-laced sauces and aromatic herbs, this is the place for you. They even take snackers into consideration with a $5 mini set menu and after 3pm, a selection of Mumbai chaats (savoury bites). Mantra was included in our Living on the Veg feature.

No Phil Collins jokes here Genesis offers a fully vegetarian menu without a trace of animal products. Espousing a firm belief in the healing power of plants, this health-conscious joint serves a variety of dishes from almond basil pasta to traditional zha jiang mian (noodles). Take a bite of their super-healthy home-made vegetarian cookies in flavours like lemon pumpkin flaxseed and cashew nut made without butter, eggs, milk or margarine. We know its hard to believe anything can still taste good without any of those ingredients, but give it a try. Genesis was included in our Living on the Veg feature.

Like its next-door neighbours, Tangos has been in its spot for over a decade and hasnt changed much at all. Its swanky, clean-cut aesthetic doesnt deter customers from rocking up in shorts and Havaianas. Bar snacks and beers are tasty and refreshing however, the high price tag will sneak up on you. Youll be surprised at how quickly you can put away four beers and end up with a fat cheque.

Not to be confused with the capital city of the Malaysian state of Selangor, this is a popular, no-frills haunt on Circular Road for ravenous clubbers and night owls looking to satisfy their appetites. Serving up favourites like prata and mee goreng (topped with a sunny-side-up egg), this place has outdoor smoking seats kept cool by powerful fans. Well known for its piping hot teh tarik and prompt table service.

Located at the junction of Upper Pickering Street and South Bridge Road, Hong Lim Park is Singapores designated area for free speech, where you can say anything you like: against the government, the PAP or Lee Kuan Yew, with no consequences. However, there are still some rules; we are in Spore after all. You cant just go up and talk when you feel like it. You have to register at the nearby police post and (surprise, surprise), no amplifiers or mic systems of any sort are allowed and with the din of the traffic, its nearly impossible to be heard (so you can forget about mass rallies). It might still be worth popping by for a look at night, because, as a bit of side history, it used to be the area for cruising. Even nowadays, you might still see the occasional guy looking for some, uh, inspiration.

Lau Kwong Fook, a freelance philosopher and editor, runs The Philosophy Café every third Wednesday of the month at the Gone Fishing Café.The issues discussed are more philosophy for a modern world, like poor artists versus rich bankers, abortion issues, whether religion is entertainment for the masses and the like, rather than the hard stuff, so anyone can jump right in and participate.

entry.name: Army Green Park @ Kent Ridge Park

version.name: Army Green Park @ Kent Ridge Park

content.description: Its a bit out of the way, but the decommissioned tank and two M114 artillery guns here are the best and ironically safest things for kids to play around and learn a bit of history. One of the last battles for Singapore occurred in this area.

Cameras and other gadgets are still very good value in Singapore. UK visitors will find 30% discounts on UK prices and can reclaim GST - 7% sales tax - at the airport. Funan has a lot of cameras, more cameras and all the other electrical items that the gadget or IT fan really needs. Try several shops before you buy, vendors offer varying packages and add-ons for different products. Funan is also the venue for one of our Critics Choice Thai Restaurants, A-Roy Thai, so pop in there when you have finished haggling.

Not only the oldest Catholic church on the island, but also the home of Singapores Archbishop.The most interesting fact, though, is that the church houses the oldest working organ, which dates back to 1912 (no small feat, considering our humid weather). Organ builder Robert Navaratnam plays the instrument at some church masses. Corner him, buy him a kopi and hell gladly give you a most detailed history of his passion.

This top-notch attraction contains 8,000 birds from 600 species. Theres a multitude of exotic and endangered South-East Asian species, alongside pelicans, penguins, flamingoes, ibises, swans, toucans, birds of paradise and more. Key attractions include the largest walk-in aviary in the world, where youll find a 30m (98ft) man-made waterfall and 1,500 birds from Africa and South America flying freely within the huge compound. After a $10m revamp in 2006, the park now has a exhibit modelled on the Okvango River in Botswana, complete with storks, cranes, fish, frogs and African-style huts. Bird shows and feeding sessions take place throughout the day. Joint tickets for the BirdPark, Night Safari and Zoo ($40; $20 children) are available.  What's on? FREE African Waterfall Aviary
Daily; 9am-6pm,
A more holistic African experience is now on offer within a simulated tropical rainforest. With a 35m-high net ceiling, 1,500 African birds have more space to roam, but theyre not the only animals reaping the benefits of a renovation. Enjoy a spanking new suspension bridge, observation posts and the new African hut for all your ornithological conquests. FREE African Wetlands Exhibit
Daily; 9am-6pm
A simulation of the St Lucia Wetlands in South Africa, this replica reflects the balanced wildlife ecology at its original site, allowing African birds like shoebills, crowned cranes and saddle-billed storks to grow accustomed to living in this part of the world. Early Bird Breakfast Show
Daily; 8.30-11am (breakfast), 9.15-9.45am (show)
Various prices (breakfast), free (show).
They say the early bird gets the worm, and you just might want to let them have it at this interactive breakfast. Instead, you can choose from a variety of delectable dishes off the Bongo Burgers Terrace menu while you make new feathered friends like Big John, the parks oldest cockatoo, and Merlin, a yellow-naped Amazon who tells fortunes. FREE Birds of Prey Show
Daily; 10am (Fuji World of Hawks), 4pm (Kings of the Skies)
Not only are they ferocious flying predators, these birds are also very disciplined. Watch the turkey vulture swoop past your ear, the Himalayan griffon vulture climb up a tree and the Brahminy kite eat from chopsticks (Fuji Hawk Walk). Feeding Frenzy
Daily; 10.30am & 2.30pm (Bee-Eater and Starlings), 10.30am & 3.30pm (Penguins), 2pm (Pelicans)
Birds (like Singaporeans) are at their happiest when eating. Time your visit to the park and youll get to see a variety of birds catching their meals literally (Waterfall Aviary, Penguin Expedition, Pelican Cove).

This wetland reserve of mangrove swamps, ponds and secondary forest is home to 140 species of birds. Thousands of egrets, sandpipers and plovers pass through in winter, but plenty of local species (kingfishers, herons, bitterns) are visible all year round. Early morning is the best time for birdwatching; there are observation hides, and you can rent binoculars. There are three nature trails (3-7km/2-4 miles long), and you can also spot mudskippers, monkeys and climbing crabs on the mangrove boardwalks. Free guided tours are available on Saturday (9.30am, 3.30pm). On Sundays the 925 bus stops at the entrance; the rest of the week you have to walk from Kranji Reservoir car park either via Kranji Way and Neo Tiew Crescent, or via the rugged and longer Kranji Nature Trail. Alternatively, you can catch the Kranji Express bus.

Get acquainted with Asian aromatics at the Spice Garden Walk and Tea Reception, offered three times a week by culinary school At-Sunrice. After learning how to identify plants and prepare spice pastes, youll be treated to a cup of lemon-grass tea and a few samosas. If youve got more time (and room in your stomach), sign up to stay for a hands-on culinary class . Tue, Thu, Sat 8.30-10am. Spice garden tour $30; with gourmet class $100.
Spize, The Makan Place was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.
The Settlers Cafe was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Now with five outlets across the island, this popular Hong Kong foodie joint is really on a roll. The menu has over 300 items (really) including the fancy-looking 8 Treasures Soup, traditional Hong Kong street snacks (condensed milk on toast is just one of them) and double-boiled birds nest. Theres even Western fare like burgers and sandwiches. At the Zion Rd outlet, a giant plasma TV takes up most of the wall space so you can enjoy old Hong Kong action flicks over your meal. Tong Shui Cafe was included in our One Night Stand feature.

Samar Cafe is an authentic piece of the Middle East in Singapore - the service can be bad, the food is not the main attraction and you cannot buy alcohol. If you do not want to sit on the floor then you should definitely mention that you want a table when you book. The music and atmosphere here is the u.s.p. - if you have never seen an authentic Middle Eastern band live then you must go to Samar soon. Samar Cafe was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Rev Distribution hosts different wine tastings every Friday (6.30-8pm) and Saturday (4-7pm). The $10 fee offsets any wine purchase made in its retail shop. Rev Distribution was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.
Va Va Voom Cafe was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Geylang often gets dissed as a seedy red-light district, but many people forget that its actually a fascinating neighbourhood full of cheap, good food. Drop by Yong He to try its specialities: beancurd, and you tiao (deep-fried dough) with floss the latter can be eaten plain, dipped in soybean milk or vinegar (dont knock it before you try it). Since its open 24 hours, its a popular supper place for both people-watching and straight-up feasting. Yong He Eating House was included in our One Night Stand feature.
CMK Restaurant was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

A Singapore institution, Mustafas is open round the clock, offering 75,000sq ft of bargains, not to mention a hotel, café and supermarket. Its a treasure trove of discount shopping, carrying everything from skincare and electronics to sports wear and luggage. Sumptuous sari fabrics can be found in basement 1, and beauty products and appliances at ground level. Mustafa Centre was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

entry.name: Chinatown Complex Temporary Market & Food Centre

version.name: Chinatown Complex Temporary Market & Food Centre

content.description:
This temporary food complex will return to its original location (335 Smith St) at the end of the year (supposedly), but for now, swing by and feast on local delicacies like ah boleng (glutinous rice ball dessert) and its famous claypot chicken rice. Wander around the stalls and watch everything from home-made fishballs to red-bean soup prepared fresh right in front of you

Chinatown Complex Temporary Market & Food Centre was featured in our One Night Stand feature.

Running out of places to rent costumes? Check out this fun and made-to-measure service (perfect for the small people) that is available for special requests and even has an online reservation facility you can use to beat the crowds.

This is probably Singapores only nightspot excluding karaoke lounges where blood-curdling screams accompany your drinks. While people get shot into the air at the neighbouring G-MAX Reverse Bungy, you can enjoy a well-made creative shot of your own perhaps a Red- Headed Slut? Whether used as liquid courage or post-ride relaxant, they go down just right. The open-air layout and singalong pop/rock soundtrack make it easy to mingle with onlookers from all over the world. 
Drinks $12-$20.

entry.name: NYU Tisch School of the Arts Asia

version.name: NYU Tisch School of the Arts Asia

content.description: Commonly known as Tisch, this is the schools first campus outside of New York. Founded in 1965, Tisch has since become one of the leading arts schools in America.Tisch School of the Arts Asia will offer an MFA in film production, animation and dramatic writing.

Kick back and sample cocktail concoctions like Kampung Freeze and Gingerbread Man surrounded by wooden interiors, a stained-glass ceiling and avant-garde installations by local artist Donna Ong. Inspired by Enid Blyton's children's stories, the fairy-tale themed gastro-bar also serves enchantingly-named $12 shooters like Apple Pie, Gold Strike, and 3 Fairies, complemented by equally enchanting bar food such as xo-sauce squid ink spaghetti, Japanese-style grilled squid and wasabi prawns.

You never have to worry about your beer going lukewarm at Eski Bar because, as the name suggests, the place (a converted 750-square foot industrial freezer) is so cold, the staff go about their duties wearing thick overcoats. But when the novelty of having misty breath wears out, or when your skinny ass can no longer tolerate the coldness (whichever comes first), its the booze that will keep you going. The menu of Grey Goose vodka-based cocktails, such as Snowflakes and Eski Mojo, and vodka shots delivered straight from pistols by the Eski Angels will keep you feeling all warm and fuzzy.

Ever wondered what happens to artworks after they have been in an exhibited at Singapores many museums? They are transported back to the citys answer to Fort Knox at the Heritage Conservation Centre, where they are kept under heavy security until the next time they are required for public viewing.
content.public-transport: Near station: Boon Lay and then taxi. Don’t bother walking. | Buses: 98
content.openingtimes: Tours by appointment only (subject to availability). Wed 10am & 3pm.

content.description: As its name suggests, this gallery aims to bring forth artwork that confronts and connects with audiences, featuring creations by rising talents as well as established artists. Forth explores artistic opportunities in most media, with a special focus on installation art and paintings.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Sun 11.30am-7pm; Mon & holidays by appointment only.

content.description: This exhibit allows you to interact with rays. Get up close and personal as you feed these sea creatures, affectionately known as birds of the sea. But be careful, as they have proven to be one of the oceans deadliest species.

entry.name: Kong Meng San Phor Kark See Monastery

version.name: Kong Meng San Phor Kark See Monastery

content.description: This hillside Buddhist complex, founded in the 1920s, contains classic Chinese temple structures, tranquil gardens, a tortoise pool, a crematorium and a majestic bell and drum tower. Housed in the Pagoda of 10,000 Buddhas are thousands of mini Buddhas (inside the main stupa) and one of the largest bronze Medicine Buddhas in South-east Asia. Bishan MRT stop is quite a distance away; you can catch a bus to the monastery, but the easiest option is to take a taxi.

If the scents of conventional perfumes are wearing you down, be sure to check out Jamal Kazura Aromatics. With glass shelves lined with jars of clear and coloured natural oils sourced from all across the globe, including the Middle- East, India and Europe this intimate fragrance boutique offers a wide range of attars (Arabic perfumes), Egyptian perfume vials, massage oils, scented body soaps and shower creams. First opened in the 1920s at North Bridge Road by the late Hinifa Kazura, Jamal Kazura Aromatics, with two other outlets, is now managed by his grandson Johari. Ask about customising your own signature scent Kazura will bring you a questionnaire asking after your favourite smells (citrus, floral, spicy, musky, etc), what type of occasion youre wearing the perfume for, and then proceed to select different scents to blend until youre satisfied. Bottled in 12ml vials ($30-$80), these are usually combinations of five or more oils mixed and shaken in a bottle. Custom-blended scents are also available ready-made; one popular choice is the Bella Rose, a long-lasting floral scent that starts off with citrus notes.

After being around for almost three years, hip lifestyle store EggThree is expanding its retail boutique and opening a new outlet in Joo Chiat. Its been designed as a boutique-cum-café space within a beautifully refurbished Peranakan shophouse. Expect bigger, one-of-a-kind furniture items borne out of EggThrees collaboration with local and international designers, and even an art gallery showcasing the works of Singaporean artists.

A dream come true for Cinderella wannabes, with a broad range of footwear ballet flats, pumps, mules, sandals and wedges and service for odd sizes. Currently, the store stocks sizes 4-11 (US) and plans on bringing up to size 13 shoes. Prices range from $80 to $700 and new stock comes in every week from suppliers that hail from the US, Italy, Korea and Singapore.

Serangoon may be a bit of a hike for some, but well go far for authentic Indonesian chow, chai-beng style. Prima Rasa takes up a little corner of a block of HDB suburban shops, but behind its glassed-off counter is a treasure trove of brilliantly executed dishes, including sweet-and-sour fish thats neither soggy nor cloyingly sweet; curry chicken swathed in a turmeric-scented golden gravy; and sambal kangkong with just the right amount of bite and chilli heat. Even the humble omelette is especially fluffy and fragrant with caramelised onions. Bonus: if you dont do au naturel dining, theres an air conditioned room to the side.

Sin Huat has made a name for itself among local and international foodies; Anthony Bourdain claims to visit at least once whenever hes in Singapore. So whats so special about this place? It certainly isnt the decor (standard coffee-shop plastic). Or the setting (on Geylangs busy streets). And it isnt the service (waiting times sometimes stretch to hours). Whats so special is chef Danny Lees wildly popular Sri Lankan crab bee hoon (prepared one dish at a time); his juicy Chinese escargots accompanied by an addictive chilli dip; and meaty prawns steamed with garlic and chilli.

At Seven, Mediterranean cuisine meets South America via a partnership with local stalwart Brazil Churrascaria. This translates into French, Italian and Spanish dishes, such as prosciutto and spicy poached pear, butternut squash and ricotta filled ravioli, roast rack of lamb, and sea bass with anchovies and dill pesto. Carnivores can fill up on lamb, beef, chicken and pork grilled on skewers, and cut straight on to the plate in slivers tableside.

Its no surprise that the compact menu is almost exclusively meat-based. The steaks are cooked and served on fragrant oak planks a technique favoured by South Americans and apparently the first of its kind in Singapore and accompanied by grilled vegetables and fries. With the most expensive item on the menu being the filet mignon $36 for a 160g slab and $42 for the 220g cut expect a fairly substantial meal that wont have you thinking nervously of your wallet the way an outing to Mortons does. The mushroom linguine, of all things, is unexpectedly good. See our feature on Prime Society.

The cooking is complex but not showy, with every dish an example of the fabulous chemistry of spices and aromatic vegetables Indian meals are famed for. Plan your meal around a carb-based dish like a pile of darkhued naan, flecked with mint, or a biryani. Pair the carbs with a coconut-infused Keralan fish curry; Lucknawi Burra kebab meaty lamb chops, marinated and cooked in a thick crimson gravy of tomatoes and ginger; and Ajwaini Machli tikka thick fish cubes, spiced and lashed with lemon before being plunged into a hot tandoor oven.

You have to love a café that claims to serve honest to goodness home cooked food, healthy salads and plenty of smiles. The Nutella cupcakes and flourless almond cakes at the entrance are a good start, and the compact menu is warmed by dishes inspired by local ingredients. Theres slowroasted shredded pork, crisp pork crackle and a sweet potato sandwich drizzled with barbecue sauce; lychee and sage freeze; a Chinese Caesar salad of ginger poached chicken, sesame soy dressing and dark soya-braised eggs; and a silky shiitake mushroom fennel soup. No service charges or GST.

Main courses from $6.50

The set-course menu allows diners to pick from Japanese- and European inspired dishes. Its all seasonal, but expect Tataki beef carpaccio with shaved parmesan, scallop with miso cappuccino and tempura soft-shell crab with sweet potato mash. Six-course lunch: $38.80; seven-course dinner: $58.80.

For a shop that calls itself Know It Nothing, the owners definitely know a thing or two about the hottest labels from around the blogopshere. Those of you who are familiar with NewDandyism.com will recognise most of the designers this shop carries. Located in the historic enclave of Kampong Glam, the first floor focuses on clothing and accessories. Art-fashion labels including COLAB Eyewear, Cutler and Gross, Surface 2 Air and Still Life NYC decorate its stark interior. On the second storey, a gallery of shoes by Kim Jones, Nike, Reebok and New Balance tempts you to run away with more than just one pair. While you’re browsing, strike up a conversation with friendly owner Suraj. He’ll be more than happy to clue you in on the brands he carries, as well as what’s up-and-coming.

If you covet vintage gear, but dont fancythe idea of wearing a piece that used to besomeone elses who has since passed on,Tokyo Costume Jewellery is a name youshould remember. Located at the recentlyrenovated Peoples Park Food Centre, thisstore stocks vintage-esque sunglassesimported from Japan that cost a mere$8 to $14 a pair. Choose from oversized shades a la Nicole Richie, make like TomFord with rock-star plastic aviators, orpick a pair of 40s-style tortoise shellrimmedsunglasses.

Get your fix of old-skool wallpaper from Pluck on Haji Lane. Sourced from Europe and priced between $60 to $100, most of the rolls are one-offs, so make sure that the one youve picked is enough to cover all your wall requirements. Also sells ice cream.

While bespoke suits, dresses and jewellery are becoming more common in Singapore,bespoke shoes are a tad harder to find. If youve got larger-than-a-yeti feet, or you know exactly what you want but cant seem to find them, Leapin Lizard maybe the solution to all your sole searching.Bring in a photo or sketch of what youreafter and together with their staff, you can pick out the material, colours and other accessories to match the shoe of your dreams. Prices start from $70, and shoes take about a month to make.

Started in 1995, Journey East has becomeknown as the go-to place for beautifully restored art deco and retro wood furniture sourced from Cambodia, Vietnam, Indonesia and Malaysia. For environmentally conscious folk, rest assured that every piece in Journey East is either old or built from FSC certified recycled wood. Wooden furniture aside, the shop also stocks home and garden accessories and can even customised mattresses to fit oddly-shaped bed frames. International shipping services are available if you cannot bear to part with your beloved piece of furniture.

Asias first indoor golf lounge provides a simulated round of golf on the worlds most famous courses. Try St Andrews or PebbleBeach, or just practise on the driving range with a PGA pro providing guidance. Your personal caddie will cater to your food and drink requirements. Throw in a TV screen for live sport and iPod facilities for your own musical selection and your session will fly by. Walk-in rates are priced from $125 per hour and personal memberships at $350 per month the venue is always privately booked for you. Individually or with a group of up to 30 people, just book in advance.
content.public-transport: Near station: Tanjong Pagar or Chinatown

content.description: This contemporary-art gallery specialises in Asian Art and represents several up-and-coming artists from Indonesia.

The largest unofficial centre of worship for local Muslims, but visitors are welcome to enter (except during prayer services, so avoid Fridays). Look for the curious features at the base of the dome, which is composed of many glass bottles.

The highlight of this privately owned orchid garden, established in 1951, is the stunning view of an orchid-filled hillside. Over 200 varieties, including the national flower Vanda Miss Joachim, are cultivated here, and its gift-wrapped orchids are cheaper than in the city centre. But its probably only worth a trip if youre a keen horticulturist or also visiting nearby Singapore Zoo.
content.public-transport: Near station: Chua Chu Kang | Buses: 927

content.description: There are more than 1,000 goats of various breeds at this goat-only farm. Milking sessions are from 9am to 11am, so come early for the main squeeze. Otherwise, you can also feed hay to the kids (the furry kind). Note: no entry to those who have visited European cow farms recently.

Established in 1852, the Gardens are a tranquil respite from the city buzz. Highlights include the National Orchid Garden with the worlds largest collection of orchids some 1,000 species and 2,000 hybrids, including the national flower, Vanda Miss Joaquim. There is also a swan lake where visitors can feed the black Australian swans, and the Evolution Garden Walk, a well-landscaped plot containing the fossilised remains of ancient trees. During weekends, tours to its rainforest patch are available, while outdoor concerts are often held at Symphony Lake. Botanic Gardens were included in our recent One Night Stand feature. Things to Do Orchid for Sale
Every first Sun; 8am-6pmA wide variety of orchids are displayed for purchase at the Library Courtyard.

FREE Edible and Medicinal Plants Tour
Every first Sat; 9am & 10am
Let volunteer guides lead you to exquisite plants that you can place on your dinner table. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre. FREE Rainforest Tour
Every second Sat; 9am, 10am, 11am & 4pm
This guided tour will expose you to the islands expanses of luscious tropical rainforest. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre. National Orchid Garden Tour
Every third Sat; 9am, 10am, 11am & 4pm (in Mandarin)
Find out facts that are every bit as colourful as the petals themselves on this guided walk through the garden. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre. ($5) FREE Evolution Garden Tour
Every fourth Sat; 9am
This tour tells the story of how plants evolve into the myriad and complex life forms we see today. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre. Photo courtesy of the Singapore Tourism Board

entry.name: Whatever Yoga & Healing Place - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED

version.name: Whatever Yoga & Healing Place - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED

content.description: (Entrance via 16A Haji Lane)

Nearly 200 years of the Singapore Police Force are presented in this centre, via cop paraphernalia, documentation of famous cases and multimedia displays. All visits are of an hour-and-a-half guided tour, and you have to make an appointment to set one up.

Located at the historic Istana Kampong Gelam, nine galleries trace the history of the Malay community from the days of the earliest settlers and the sea faring might of the Bugis villagers to the golden years of the Malay entertainment industry. Exhibits include regalia of Malay royaltyand artefacts. The centre also offers batik and pottery-making workshops ($10) and occasional cultural shows (adults $10, children $5).

Housed within three restored shop houses, 15 galleries feature the rich history and cultural heritage of Chinatown, including the story of Chinese immigrants who came to find work in Singapore during the colonial days. Highlights include rooms replicating coolies living quarters and clan associations activity halls prominent in those times.

This $59m, five-storey Buddhist complex is a house of worship and a few museums rolled into one. Located on the third storey is the Buddhist Cultural Museum, that displays a selection of rare artefacts detailing the history of Buddhism and the different traditions practised in Asian countries. On the same floor, located at the rear of the hall, you’ll find the Sacred Buddha Relics Chamber. This houses what are regarded as the Brains, Blood, Muscle and Flesh Relics of Buddha. According to the religion’s beliefs, these items are supposedly Buddha’s body in eternal form. They generally come in three sizes – akin to a mustard seed, rice grain or kidney bean – and are usually in the colours of white (denoting bone), gold (flesh) and orangey-red (brain). A must-see is the 15-foot Maitreya Buddha that sits on the ground floor of the main hall. Prayers are conducted at 8am depending on a specific deity’s birthday.
content.public-transport: Near station: Chinatown or Outram Park

content.description: Nestled within the hillside close to Fort Canning Centre in Fort Canning Park, the Battle Box was the largest underground military operations complex on the island during World War II. Now you can walk through its 22 rooms, some of which still contain the original bunkers, and see the re-creation of the British surrender to the Japanese as told via wax figurines, video and audio effects.To help you feel like you were there, air-raid sirens and bomb blasts go off around you.

Situated on the former premises of the British Sergeants Quarters, the Amara Sanctuary is Sentosas luxury accomodation choice. Set in a lush, tropical 3.5-hectare space, the resort stands out as a result of its hybrid architectural style, where modern glass, steel and blond wood elements exist alongside the premises original 1930s colonial features. The hotel offers three categories of rooms deluxe, courtyard/verandah suites and villas and has devoted a floor to wheelchair-bound guests. In addition to housing Singapores only Kushiage restaurant (traditional Japanese cuisine where fresh ingredients are coated in egg, breadcrumbs, deep fried and served on skewers), Si Bon, there are also three swimming pools scattered about.

This impressive Gothic edifice was built by Indian convict labourers and consecrated in 1862. The original church (another of George Drumgoole Colemans creations) was replaced by a neo-classical building that was pulled down in 1855. In 1870, St Andrews became a cathedral, and has played a central role in Anglican mission work in the region ever since. Despite the flashy new glass Welcome Centre, its not really a showpiece. The transepts are more redolent of small-town English church halls than a grandiose cathedral, while the nave, with its ceiling fans and scattered supplicants, gives the sense that this is a working church. Brass wall plaques tell tales of personal suffering and professional sacrifice (it is striking how many of those commemorated died young), and guided tours highlight distinctive features, such as the Coventry Cross behind the pulpit (made from nails from the bombed ruins of Coventry Cathedral in 1940).
content.openingtimes: Guided tours 10.30am-4.30pm Mon, Tues, Thur-Sun; 2.30-4.30pm Wed

content.description: The first and still the largest regional library, the Woodlands Regional Library is located within a stones throw of Woodlands MRT Station. Occupying four levels of the Woodlands Civic Centre, it also houses a 250-seat auditorium in the basement, as well as a performance stage and 20-seat AV appreciation for public screening of TV programmes. The library is nature-themed and has a special focus on children with their own features-galore Reading Park. It has the largest collection of Chinese and Malay books.

content.vendor-category: Books | Good spots to read and eat
content.description: This welcoming bistro is an independent hangout for all book lovers. Located just off the main Mohamed Sultan stretch, the spacious lounge is a good place to relax on overstuffed sofas and pore through the selection of magazines, travel guides and an eclectic bunch of fiction. Book Cafe won Cafe with the best reading material in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

content.public-transport: Near station: Ang Mo Kio | Buses: SBS 13, 86,162, 269

content.description: Since it was set up in 1998, the cultural wing of the Ngee Ann Kongsi has sought to promote awareness of Teochew heritage among Singaporeans through the medium of visual and performing arts. In their campaign to keep it old-school, the NACC has made its Annual National Teochew artists Art & Chinese Calligraphy Exhibition the highlight of its cultural calendar.
LaSalle has the regions only integrated arts campus offering a wide range of BA (Hons) and MA degrees.
Set up by *SCAPE as part of its plan to promote young talent, The Lab offers a venue that aims to provide young talent with a space to express themselves through performance and the arts.

Jalan Bahar Clay Studios is not only a part of Singapores pottery heritage, but also home to a community of potters, ceramic artists and clay sculptors. Every first Sunday of the month, the JBCS artists welcome anyone with an interest in pottery to make or paint a piece and take it home for a minimal fee. Coffee, tea, cold drinks, cakes and snacks will be on the menu. Events are also held at the studios, check the website for details.

Gallery Eighty strives to provide a platform for contemporary art to thrive on a global level. Boasting a selection of paintings, sculptures, photography and installation art, this space is constantly aiming to reach audiences beyond the shores of Singapore by fostering international partnerships through collaborations with foreign galleries.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Fri 10am-6pm, Sat 1-4pm. After hours by appointment only.

content.description: Photo: Grace Tan FOST lends itself as a space for showcasing some of the best photography and modern art exhibitions in Singapore, collaborating with various art bodies such as Timothy Yarger Fine Art from Beverly Hills.
content.public-transport: Near station: Somerset, Clarke Quay, Chinatown
content.openingtimes: Tue-Sat noon-7pm, Mon, public holidays & after hours by appointment only.

content.description: Abrazos the Spanish word for hugs is a dance facility for aspiring tangueros to hotfoot their way to stardom. Specialising in Argentinian-style tango, the Abrazos academy is spread over a 3,000sq-foot space including a dance studio, event hall and shoe boutique all of which are open to the public. With course names like Beginners Boot Camp and Improvers Seminars, this looks like muy serious stuff for the most dedicated of dancers. An up-to-date, detailed class schedule can be found on its website.  Abrazos was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.
See recognised international visual and new-media artists, as well as young artists from Singapore. This space is also affiliated with the Orita Sinclair Int'l Pte Ltd located next door.
Get your fix of contemporary Chinese art at Art Seasons.

The Padang ('flat field' in Malay) was marked out in Raffles' original town plan as a recreation area, and so it remains, being the site of regular cricket matches and big public events. At the southern end in the Singapore Cricket Club, at the north, the Singapore Recreation Club.

entry.name: Centre Stage School of the Arts

version.name: Centre Stage School of the Arts

content.description: Regular drawing classes, printmaking, papier mâché and book-making are all part of the curriculum to encourage a childs freedom of expression. Parents are more than welcome to join in the fun.
content.public-transport: Near station: Yio Chu Kang, Yishun, Sengkang | Buses: 86, 103, 103W

content.description: Focusing mainly on food-based activities, kids engage in learning through baking, icecream- making and other delicious tasks. Enrichment programmes range from popular Kidz Can Bake workshops to Tshirt designing and the ambitious Little Entrepreneurs Camp, which allows kids to experience running a real business.
content.openingtimes: Opening times vary. Go to the website for more information.

content.description: By using something as apparently insignificant as the humble stamp as a springboard into Singapores past, the Philatelic Museum is more successful at recounting the history of the country than other more wide-ranging museums. The displays some permanent, others changing are well presented, and interactive enough to keep younger visitors engaged. Its also a working post office: where better to fire off a few postcards of your own?

The Singapore story is vividly brought to life in this centres five galleries of interactive and multi-sensory exhibits. Highlights include the Visionarium, the worlds first and largest interactive design studio with a 360-degree wrap-around screen,and the iWERKS Theatre, a flat-screen theatre that projects conventional and 3D giant screen movies. You can also take a bus tour from here to the SAFTI Military Institute, the training ground for Army, Navy and Air Force officers.   Costs: $10; children $6
content.openingtimes: 9.00am-6.00pm (Closed on Mon, except public or school holidays)

address.street: 11 Third Hospital Avenue, Bowyer Block Clock Tower
11 Third Hospital Avenue, Bowyer Block Clock Tower

content.description: Housed in the majestic Bowyer Block, the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) museum documents almost 200 years of medicine and medical education. Besides an extensive artefact collection, noteworthy exhibits include a re-created façade of the King Edward VII College of Medicine Building and the Luminaries Section which pays tribute to the hospital’s top doctors.

address.street: National Univer45 Science Drive 2, Block S6
National Univer45 Science Drive 2, Block S6

content.description: This descendant of the original Raffles Museum established in 1849 by Sir Stamford Raffles (the founder of Singapore and a renowned naturalist) contains the oldest and largest animal collection from the South-East Asian region, with more than 400,000 catalogued specimens. Key attractions include a 19thcentury turtle from Siglap and a 4.4m king cobra from the Central Catchment area. More than 20,000 plant specimens found within the region are also on display.

address.street: 50 Bukit Batok West Ave 3, Bukit Batok Polyclinic
50 Bukit Batok West Ave 3, Bukit Batok Polyclinic

content.description: Live through the history of modern medical care in Singapore from the times of Sir Stamford Raffles to the present day. Health-related artefacts include the amazing travelling baby-weighing machine, glass syringes and platinum needles.

Ten per cent of the owners 50,000-strong collection of toys is on display for your viewing pleasure. See our feature 'Toy's story' Costs: Various family packages (two adults and two children $36; three adults and one child $42

Situated in a two-storey shophouse, the upstairs screening room is equipped with 20 sofas, Blu-Ray projection and surround sound. Spending a minimum of $5 at the first-floor cafe gives you access to the films. Check the website for specific screening times. Pitch Black was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Some things never change not much, at least. Formerly known as Club Momo, the spacious establishment has now reopened as Velvet Dragon. And as the name suggests (intentionally or not), there certainly is an ah-beng, ah-lian feel that permeates, much like before the refurbishment. From the long, winding line of under-25s outside awaiting entry to the Top 40 tunes that play inside, this place is clearly for the younger party-goer, which is not a bad thing if you appreciate fun dance music. The décor is more lush than before, with gigantic mirrors, mini wall lamps and velvet-wrapped maroon-coloured sofas (in honour of the clubs name, perhaps) at the booth-seating areas the latter providing great respite when you get tired of dancing or feel like canoodling. If you find your energy waning, top up your buzz with their house cocktail, Blue Velvet, which is a tasty mix of Blue Curaçao, gin and tonic. Then go shake it up in one of the two cages they have on the dance floor.

$20, includes two drinks.

Looked after by bookworms Kenny Leck and Karen Wai, BooksActually stocks both fiction and non-fiction titles. Narrative and theoretical books in the disciplines of philosophy, psychology, anthropology, political science, history, biography, mathematics, science, travel, food, art, photography and film.

For those who digests the likes of Murakami, Sweeney, Capote, Salinger and Nabokov, bring your appetites and dollars.

Theres also an assortment of desirably retro, non-literary oddities to peruse, including old-school film cameras and typewriters. Monthly exhibitions also take place so go to their website for regular updates.

This bookshop is a regular haunt for graphic designers and illustrators, stocking the best and newest in disciplines, from graphics and architecture to fashion and animation. There are regular discounts offered on specialised magazines and publications. And if you cant find what youre looking for, leave your name, number and desired title(s) and youll be notified once it arrives.

content.vendor-category: Books | Good spots to read and eat
content.description: Coffee and a fine selection of Taiwanese tea lubricate walk-in pedestrians looking for respite in Pasir Ris. They may find enlightenment before leaving this friendly cafe is run by the Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation to aid the spiritual development of society without preaching. Books for browsing and sale are by Still Thoughts Culture and other nondenominational spiritual publications.

entry.name: Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped

version.name: Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped

content.description:
Members of the Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped (SAVH) have access to braille and audio books, music CDs and Infomag, a weekly audio newspaper. Volunteers how about narrating books and news articles for the Audio Production Unit? 

Visually handicapped members $5, sighted members $15 per year.

Designated as a national monument in 2006, the first auto assembly plant in South-East Asia was also the place where British Forces surrendered Singapore to the Japanese army in 1942. Its now a museum which, through pictorial exhibits and film documentaries, details just how residents in Singapore and Malaya lived during the Japanese Occupation.

Ever wondered how Singapore's Chinatown is different from, say, Cuba's? Find out through the pictorial and interactive exhibitions at this centre, which specialises in the studies of Chinese communities outside China. The building it's in - the structurally stunning Administration Building of the former Nanyang University - has been designated a national monument.

One of Singapore's largest and most impressive museums, ACM Empress Place has 11 galleries showcasing more than 1,300 artefacts from the civilisations of China, South-East Asia, South Asia and West Asia. ACM Armenian Street, currently under renovation, will reopen as a Peranakan Museum in 2008.
Roast venison striploin with spices and cassis sauce, country vegetables and mushrooms ($60 as a main or $138 for five-course tasting menu).

Char-grilled kangaroo loin on sautéed garlic flower, mushroom and potatoes with a miso-plum sauce ($38).Spatchcock broiled mustard marinated baby chicken on a mushroom ragu with roasted potato, roasted Japanese pumpkin, haricot vert and vine-ripened tomatoes ($28).

EXCLUSIVE TO TOS READERS Enjoy these fantastic dining offers at any of IL Lido's restaurants. Just subscribe and print a copy of our latest newsletter (22-25 April edition), and present it before ordering.

Forlino
Enjoy a three-course lunch at $35++ (usual price $68++) or four-course dinner at $55++ (U.P. $98++). Valid till 30 Apr. Il Lido
Enjoy a three-course lunch at $35++ (usual price $68++) or four-course dinner at $55++ (U.P. $98++). Valid till 30 Apr.

Cafeteria Il Lido @ Suntec
Enjoy authentic, affordable Italian favorites with an exclusive 1-for-1 deal on main courses for both lunch and dinner. Valid till 30 Apr.

====

Il lido is also listed as a bar and lounge, click for information, and was featured in our recent One Night Stand feature. And also in our Season's Eatings feature. Il Lido won Best Meal with a View in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

Executive chef Philippe Nouzillat presides over a warmly lit dining room and a thoroughly French menu that covers all the traditional bases. Were talking beef bourguignon, steak tartare, coq au vin, lemon sole à la meunière and garlicky oiled escargots here. They have drawn up an impressive 29- page wine list too. But nothing is overdone, least of all the wonderfully fragrant blue cheese salad showered with apple cubes and walnuts; a fan of perfectly done roast duck slices on a raspberry reduction and puréed polenta; and the hunk of snowy white grilled pork chop. You wont go hungry like the Wolf here; Nouzillats brasserie ticks the boxes in all departments. Cest bon.   Main courses $22-$42.

Our recent Friday night visit to a packed dining room told the story, and the robust Italian chefs dashing about behind the glassed-off kitchen were a reassuring sight. Now that La Braceria has closed (while looking for new premises), Borgo is our new favourite spot for home-made pastas (including the rarely seen, ear-shaped orecchiette) and sausages. The menu is cheap, classic and no-frills, and served in hearty portions, like parpadelle with a rich wild boar sauce streaked with basil, a zesty eggplant parmigiana and wonderful thin-crust pizza topped with meaty discs of sausages. Round it all off with a perfectly done chocolate almond cake.

content.public-transport: Near station: Bugis or City Hall

content.description: Tucked away at the back of Holland Village is Indochines Siem Reap, otherwise known as Siem Reap I (not to be confused with Siem Reap II, which is on the waterfront). This cosy drinking nook has a dark interior perfect for unwinding away from the more bustling section of Lorong Mambong. Of course, thats only when its not soccer season, when the bar turns into a roaring madhouse. It houses Singapores first water bar offering customers a range of natural, sparkling and flavoured agua which strikes us as a little pretentious, considering itswell, water. One more strike against the planet.

Great for a casual dining or brunch either in the small-ish air conditioned inside area or at one of the shaded tables overlooking the river. At the reservations-only wine-and-cheese nights, held every second Thursday of the month, you pay just $30 for four full glasses or eight half glasses, plus cheese and antipasti. Epicurious was featured in our recent Morning Glory - Best Western Breakfasts feature. Epicurious won Best Breakfast in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Barely legal heartlanders converge at Dbl 0 for three things: cheap premium booze (housepours as low as $3 a pop), thumping dance tunes and lots of weekend action.

Tiki torches light the entrance to Dempsey’s Hut, where tables sprawl out on a wooden deck under a canopy of intertwined branches. Fans and the loud hum of crickets provide a more natural breeze than your run-of-the-mill, air-conditioned joints.Dempsey's Hut was included in our recent Eye on the ball feature.

BQ Bar is the post-work bolthole for boozing English banker boys, which in turn attracts an assortment of underdressed, giggly chicks who love that sort of thing. Dharma's Kebabs at BQ Bar were included in our recent Menu Updates feature.

Despite its low profile, Archipelago bears the distinction of being Singapores first commercial brewery, established back in 1931. The company now channels its efforts into making freshly brewed craft beers for the discerning drinker. With a roster of six signature ales including the dark, creamy Java and refreshing Straits Pale, award-winning brewmaster Fal Allen has raised the bar for local beer standards. Patrons are encouraged to appreciate the subtleties of each brew rather than the standard chug-a-jug approach. And with daily happy hours until 8pm, theres no time for sulking.

Owner Glennery Besson has shifted his artistic focus from personal expression to using art as a therapy to aid personal growth and relieve stress. Expect to get your hands dirty as you relax with paint and clay. Periodic exhibitions are still held at the Gallery.

Settle back for some of the best Thai food in Singapore at crazy, cheap prices. The food here is of restaurant standard, but at cafe costs. The menu is small, yet crammed with delicious green curries; tart tom yam made not from bottled paste, but with fresh herbs and seafood stock; crisp pork chops; mango salad and a really good belachan fried rice.

Its a little astonishing to realise that tiny Buko Nero still has such a long reservation list. But then, the biggest draw has always been husband-and-wife team Oscar and Tracy Pasinato, who run the tiny dining room like a trattoria: the Asian-inflected Italian menu changes regularly. Recent favourites included a ragù of pork sausages, an exquisitely buttery squid-ink risotto and the cloud of coconut foam over a pannacotta streaked with gula melaka. Our only gripe is the poor ventilation from the open kitchen.

address.street: 25 Scotts Road, Royal Plaza on Scotts
25 Scotts Road, Royal Plaza on Scotts

content.description: Another round-the-clock gallery, showing South-East Asian contemporary and abstract art.

This Chinese-themed foot reflexology retreat is a welcome alternative to the usual back-to-basics parlours dotted about Singapore. The extra-roomy massage chairs come specially imported from China and even have mini television sets attached. Nice. Before you begin your massage, your feet will be treated to a soak (instead of just a wipe down) and afterwards, youll receive a thorough neck and shoulder massage ($69).

Built against lush greenery on the slopes at the Civil Service Club, this retreat offers more than 50 ways to pamper yourself from head to toe, including TCM treatments prescribed by an in-house practitioner. Almost everything seems to come in XL sizes: dressing rooms, relaxation areas and even the lockers – they’re the largest we’ve ever seen in a spa. If you’re going for a massage, be sure to inform the therapist of your preferred pressure, as the standard strokes can be vigorous. The spa’s popular treatment, the Javanese Madilulur Retreat ($250 for 90 minutes), consists of a body scrub and massage, aimed to keep hydration levels in your skin sane. Book your treatment in advance to request the hilltop spa pavilion at no extra charge.

Best known for its Traditional Chinese Medicine techniques, chromatherapy (holistic healing through colour therapy) and Swiss herbology, this cosy haven has recently acquired the right to utilise the award-winning Comfort Zone brand of products and treatments. One recommendation is the Aromascrub ($150), which lets you choose the grain that fits your skin type, followed by a body massage. Bliss.

The first and only wine-themed spa in Singapore allows customers unlimited glasses of red before, during and after treatment. Based on vinotherapy, the different remedies are designed around grape seeds, grape-seed oil, skin, stalks and wine extracts. Its signature Vintage Spa Retreat ($108) starts off with a wine-infused bath soak, then includes a body scrub and massage. Along with the uplifting citrus scent, this package facilitates lymphatic circulation, aids detoxification and stimulates skin’s natural collagen production. After your treatment, you’re encouraged to take advantage of the wireless network and surf away, while unwinding to yet another glass of red (hic!). Respecting its location in the Arab quarter, non-alcoholic treatments are also available.

address.street: Tan Quee Lan Street, TQL Suites
Tan Quee Lan Street, TQL Suites

content.description: Getting an even tan can be tricky, but Fabulous Tan’s unconventional baking beds eliminate the guesswork. The high-pressure bunks give off just 0.01 per cent of UVB rays, less than the 12 per cent from the sun and 7 per cent from other beds. Anal types will no doubt still protest – any direct exposure to UVB is a bad idea. But if a tan is what you want, a tan is what you’ll get, and in just three sessions. The first trial session is free but comes with conditions. Call to find out more.

Instead of memorising dance routines, try Chakradance, a form of self-expression where you surrender to the music, dance in any manner and focus on how each chakra (energy centre) makes you feel. According to teacher David Cheah the only certified instructor in Singapore and Malaysia Chakradance is said to balance ones natural energy flows and help redis-cover unique body rhythms that have been suppressed or unexplored.

Boasting a panoramic sea view, Sky Fitness is by far Singapores most luxurious gymnasium. In addition to the wide range of exercise classes and equipment, members are entitled to use the Concierge Service, which assists in holiday bookings, dinner reservations and even laundry dropoffs. Theres also a Wellness Centre that provides antioxidant-level scans, detox programmes, personalised nutritional planning and an anti-ageing treatments offered by Singapores pioneering anti-ageing practitioner, Dr Y M Wong. Check if any of the 1,500 memberships are still available, but we suspect that with facilities like a sound-proof lounge, a health-food café and a wine bar, that wont be the case for long.

Skip the gym and pedal your way to work. The boutique offers a bike-lodging service with shower facilities, personal lockers and towels, so youll reach your office looking all clean and fresh. While youre at work, your two-wheeled beauty will be washed, de-greased and lubricated. The boutique also offers rentals and maintenance services and sells a range of related accessories and apparel.

On reaching Ubin jetty, walk straight ahead for the National Parks information kiosk (open 8.30am-5pm daily), where you can pick up a map. To the left is the town, with a wayang (theatre) stage, a small shrine and some ramshackle houses that have been converted into bicycle rental shops, humdrum eateries and provisions shops (with stock that looks as if it hasnt been replenished for decades). Other villagers depend on farming and fishing for a livelihood. Many used to own chickens, but poultry was banned on the island after the 2005 bird flu epidemic. The best way to explore is by bike; the island is too large, and the weather usually too hot, for walking. Bikes (available 8am-6pm) cost $3-$8 to rent; its wise to pick as new a model as possible. Less tiring (but less fun) is a taxi van unmetered; negotiate the fare beforehand. There are three cycling trails (on paved and dirt roads), which lead past old fruit and rubber plantations, mangrove swamps, water-filled quarry pits and old wooden houses. Toilets and shelters are located at key points. The Chek Jawa wetlands area on Ubins eastern tip is worth visiting, with marine life visible at low tide. Visitor numbers are restricted to protect the fragile ecosystem, so you have to pre-book a guided tour contact the National Parks Board for more information. If you want to stay overnight, permits are not required for camping, but note that the water from public toilets and wells is not suitable for drinking or bathing. The Marina Country Club Ubin Resort (6388 8388, www.marinacountryclub.com.sg) offers basic air-conditioned chalets.

Sentosas beloved musical fountain has been replaced by a new attraction: a $30-million water-and-light extravaganza of pyrotechnics, water jets, lasers, computer imaging and of course, loud music. The story and there is one tells of a young man who falls for a princess who is under the spell of an enchanted village.Cue singing sea creatures and voilà, you have Songs of the Sea!

Catch awesome views of the HarbourFront precinct, southern islands and the worlds busiest port as you take a 12-minute cable-car ride from the Jewel Box on Mount Faber to Imbiah Lookout on Sentosa Island. At night, the eyes of the giant Merlion and the Jewel Boxs façade change colours its kitschy (you can even dine in one with courses served each time you return to the top) but amusing.

We’ve got so many orchids in this city, there’s even one named after Ricky ‘Shake Your Bon-Bon’ Martin. It’s true! Pop down to the Singapore Botanic Gardens to check out the Renachilus Ricky Martin, along with the world’s largest orchid display (of course), with more than 1,000 species and 2,000 hybrids, including our national fl ower – the showy Vanda Miss Joaquim.

The revolving, air-conditioned cabin of Asias tallest observation tower rises to a height of 131m/430ft, providing the best 360° views of Singapores southern coastline, Sentosa itself, the Southern Islands and parts of Malaysia and Indonesia accompanied by a rather twee recorded commentary. Day and night views are equally striking, even when the weather is stormy. Despite the name, no alochol is allowed on board.

An East Coast institution for more than 20 years, Parkway Parade contains 250 shops spread over six levels. The boutiques are varied, charming and surprisingly urban. Rent a Kiddy Cab to appease the tots while you check out Katong Cuty, a quirky, old-school lingerie shop.

So named because of its proximity to the bridge that links Singapore to Malaysia, Causeway Point is a typical suburban shopping mall. Expect the usual formula: cineplex, gaming arcade and a sprinkling of clothes and knick-knack shops that drive the heartlanders wild. Local department stores Metro and John Little, and supermarket chain Cold Storage, are anchor tenants.

Formerly Singapores red-light district, Bugis has been cleaned up and redeveloped. Straits-Chinese shophouses were glassed in to form part of this mall (also called Parco Bugis Junction), which contains Japanese department store Seiyu and plenty of teen-friendly shops. Of particular interest is the Edge, a collection of Japanese-inspired streetwear boutiques; purists dismiss it as a poor imitation of popular youth fashion destinations the Heeren Shops or Far East Plaza, but there are bargains. Bugis Junction's outdoor fountain is where you will often see drenched, screaming kids having a whale of a time. As the water comes from the floor and in various shapes and patterns, guessing where the next sprout will spurt from is half the fun.

Where?
Up a cobbled path, behind the boutique Berjaya Duxton Hotel, in a conservation shophouse area, tucked away off  Chinatown.

History?
This space used to be an architects office, but now its a wine bar one that shares a name with a bar in  the owners native South Australia. Otherwise there are no similarities between the two. The people behind the scenes are the same people behind the Denise Wine Shops sprouting like mushrooms all over Singapore, which explains the prominence of  Kaesler and Two Hands wines on the list, as they are the importers for them. Whats it like?
A place where you can finish the latest Patricia Cornwell while enjoying a glass of  wine its that brightly lit. The window side of  this long, narrow space is taken up by hard, white formica-like  banquettes hardly conducive to hunkering down for the night and ordering that second, third or fourth bottle. The bar is really the focal point of  the space with its mosaic-like back wall with prominent liquor-bottle display. The wines are stored in a glass unit towards the back of  the bar, but its much easier to just choose from the list. Unless you stare at the diners across at Broth, theres not much people-watching to do. Or any other kind of  distraction either. Other than filling our glasses, the staff  pretty much left us alone, spending more time at the modern French restaurant upstairs.

Who are the regulars?
While the Universal has yet to be discovered by the masses we were the only table on a Saturday night the set-up seems to target professionals who are interested in the quality of  the drinks and the company.

The drinks?
The 500 selections (including 20 by the glass) cover a large part of  the wine-producing world Australia, New Zealand, France, Spain and range from a heart-racing $8,200 for the 89 Petrus to $45 (a steal) for the 06 Rolf  Binder Semillon Hellions. The best deals here are the Aussie wines the list has 105 to choose from, with Rolf  Binder and Kaesler wines leading the pack, and though the flavours are big and bold, the prices arent. If  cocktails are more your scene, the Universal probably isnt. However, you will find the general managers own creation on the menu: the Bennetini ($25), a concoction of  Absolut Blue, Citron, Mandarin, Bombay gin, Bacardi rum with lychee liqueur, lemon juice, lime cordial and lychee syrup. Sweet.

Wine by the glass $13-$24; bottles $45-$8,200; cocktails $12-$25.

entry.name: Hong Kong Seafood and Steamboat Restaurant

version.name: Hong Kong Seafood and Steamboat Restaurant

content.description: Sound steamboat in Kallang Waterfront

entry.name: The Gallery of Gnani Arts (Fortune Centre)

version.name: The Gallery of Gnani Arts (Fortune Centre)

content.description: This gallery is not only an exhibition space but also an establishment that specialises in curating and marketing art as well as actively participating in research and development on contemporary South Indian art.
Shaw Lido Cinema has 8 screens.
Shaw Cinema at Jurong has six screens.
content.public-transport: Near station: Jurong East | Buses: SBS: 51, 78, 79, 97, 97e, 143, 197, 198, 333, SS4

content.description: Shaw Cinema Balestier has 6 screens.
Golden Village Yishun has 10 screens.
content.public-transport: Near station: Yishun | Buses: SBS Transit : 800, 811, 812, 806, 804, 852, 853, 8

content.description: GOlden Village Tiong Bahru has 15 screens and 3D Digital halls.
content.public-transport: Near station: Tiong Bahru | Buses: SBS Transit : 16, 32, 33, 63, 64, 75, 123, 132, 14

content.description: Golden Village Marina has 6 screens and 3D Digital halls.
content.public-transport: Near station: City Hall | Buses: SBS Transit : 56, 75, 133, 171, 195, 36, 77, 97,

entry.name: Eng Wah Toa Payoh Entertainment Centre

version.name: Eng Wah Toa Payoh Entertainment Centre

content.description: Eng Wah Cinema Toa Payoh features the new Director's Club seating.
Eng Wah Cinema Sun Plaza features the new Director's Club seating.
Eng Wah Empress Cinema is currently being refurbished.

Artefacts, photos and documents from the old Woodbridge Hospital in Yio Chu Kang, the infamous mental institution, detail the history of mental-health services in Singapore. Highlights: a large model of the original hospital made by patients in the early 1970s, a straitjacket used to strap inmates down, and surgical instruments used to carry out post-mortems during the Japanese Occupation when the hospital was used by the military.

address.street: Blk 17 Upper Boon Keng Road Market and Hawker Centre
Blk 17 Upper Boon Keng Road Market and Hawker Centre

content.description: Mohamed Ganis sop kambing, or mutton soup, is a fragrant mélange of tender meat (the offal is offered separately), cloves, garlic and intense pepper heat all simmering in a thick soup that is almost borscht-like in its texture.

This filmmaking and photography hub was established in 2003 and has already garnered a huge following of enthusiasts wanting to further their knowledge in either craft. Besides holding regular courses and workshops, they also create awareness by organising photography exhibitions, film screenings and talks. And if thats not enough, this establishment spearheads Objectif Films in partnership with Infinite Frameworks and Shooting Gallery Asia. Together, they distribute the largest number of short films in South-East Asia and represent award-winning short films from our region. Go to the website for more information on courses and events.

An institute built for the cultivation of everything scientific. Features regular exhibitions promoting physical, life, applied, technology and industry sciences. The centre also has Singapores only dome-shaped theatre. The Omni-Theatre, is equipped with state-of-the-art IMAX dome technology. It is Singapores only dome-shaped, five-storey theatre with a capacity of 276 seats. Things to See at the Science Centre Amazing Electron
Electrons may be the things inside an atom with a negative charge, but their impact on our world has been hugely positive. Come find out how the humble particle has helped to create our first television set, telephone, radio and much more. Human Body
We use our body every day, but few of us know how it functions. This exhibition educates visitors on the complexities of our body structure, from the way the brain works to how the heart beats. While our intricate biology may be overwhelming to understand, you can make use of the interactive, audio and visual presentations for an engaging and comprehensive experience. Space Science
Intrigued by space, the universe and all things celestial? Journey through a galaxy of graphical representations of our solar system, as it provides you with an in-depth understanding of the world, outside the one we live in. The Minds Eye
Test your eyesight at this exhibition featuring a collection of optical illusions to see is to believe. Climate Change Exhibition
Visit the icy poles of the Earth, calculate your own carbon footprint, learn about eco-cities, discover the ingredients in the weather, and find out how our changing climate impacts farming, health and ecology at this exhibit. Living with Viruses
Through 3-D galleries, video documentaries and information panels, this exhibition fills you in on Singapores most notorious and potentially lethal viral afflictions of the last decade such as HIV, AIDS and SARS. Waterworks
Learn all you need to know about H2O in this fun-filled, open-air exhibition featuring 11 hands-on displays. iSpace
See what the world of tomorrow looks like today. This exhibition offers you the chance to see how hi-tech the home and office of the future will be.

entry.name: Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall

version.name: Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall

content.description: A pioneer of Chinas revolutionary struggle in the early 20th century, Dr Sun Yat Sen made numerous trips to South-east Asia; a sympathiser, Teo Eng Hock, turned over this villa to the cause. It was here in 1906 that Dr Sun formed the Singapore branch of the Chinese Revolutionary Alliance, and he would return several more times before his success in deposing the emperor in 1911 whereupon a new battle for the future of China began. The story told here fleshes out the political history of the Singapore Chinese, and makes a change from the more usual focus on migrant labour and World War II. While there are a few videos, replica objects and waxworks, the spacious halls and galleries are overwhelmingly reliant on captioned black and white archive photos. Next door is the Burmese Buddhist Temple, containing a 3m (11ft) marble Buddha, the largest Burmese Buddha image outside Burma.

Follow the history and development of various sports in Singapore from colonial times to the years of independence. In the Traditional & Indigenous Sports Gallery, you can learn all about local games such as Chinese hopscotch, Chaptek and Five Stones, while the country’s top sportsmen and women are honoured in the Our Heroes Gallery.

entry.name: Republic of Singapore Air Force Museum

version.name: Republic of Singapore Air Force Museum

content.description: This museum, which traces the development of the Republic of Singapore Air Force from its early days as the Royal Air Force in 1927 to the present day, has nine indoor galleries which feature air force artefacts and dioramas with audio-visual effects. The outdoor gallery showcases fighter planes such as the A4-C Skyhawk, the SF 260 Marchetti and the Hunter Hawker.

Formerly, this quaint Chinese museum was one of the oldest temples in Singapore, set up by Hakka and Cantonese immigrants in the early 1800s, before becoming a clan association clubhouse that served both dialect groups. Today, it is Singapores first street museum, where visitors can view artefacts donated by residents of Chinatown including an old ice kachang maker and the iconic Singer sewing machine of the 1960s. This building was originally a Buddhist shrine, built in 1824 and said to be the oldest Chinese temple on the island; it later became a centre for the Hakka and Cantonese communities. The religious functions were eventually moved elsewhere as the building became dilapidated, and in the 1990s the place was restored and converted into a street museum. Dont expect much theres some historical information, a few artefacts and a small glass-cased model portraying 19th-century street life.

The most iconic of Singapores World War II sites, even though the museum is housed in a purpose-built venue, and the chapel is a reconstruction (the original was shipped to Australia after the war). The main interest lies in the stories of industry and ingenuity within the POW camp. The civilian and military internees essentially established an alternative, if somewhat surreal, society, catering for everything from entertainments to the manufacture of thousands of everyday items. Contact with the outside world was maintained through handmade and carefully disguised radios. The chapel, located in the courtyard of the museum, encourages quiet reflection. It also houses copies of the kitschy but affecting Changi murals, recreated by the original artist, Stanley Warren, after a widely publicised international effort to find him; the preponderance of blue and white is because of his reliance on billiard cue chalk. The $8 audio guide is pricey, but it is comprehensive and complements the displays well.
content.public-transport: Near station: Tanah Merah or Tampines | Buses: 2

content.description: This former 19th century Baba Methodist Church is located at an impossibly noisy traffic junction, but is nonetheless an ideal spot to gather inspiration. The one-off and limited edition three-dimensional art on display within (and -out) its 9-metre-high walls are also available to be purchased.

Singapores old Parliament House is converted into a home for the arts and has been bustling ever since its inception in March 2004. The 180-year-old building now plays host to many multidisciplinary art exhibitions, performances and showcases.
content.public-transport: Near station: City Hall or Raffles Place

content.description: The home of TheatreWorks, this former rice warehouse wears different masks to accommodate and play host to various arts events, be it a gallery, a cinema or a theatre. Through the International Centre of Asian Art (ICAA) and the Singapore Creative Arts Nucleus (SCAN), 72-13 is a space to encourage partnerships and residencies, and spark creativity by Singaporeans.

Possibly an artists best friend, Utterly Art is an exhibition space hosting a diverse assortment of local and regional artists, as well as world-renowned photographers whose works can all be viewed for free. Previous exhibitors include established artists such as Loh Jahan, Robert Freeman, Chng Seok Tin and Ansel Adams.

Set up by Chris and Charlotte Churcher, Red Sea Gallery is the culmination of the expatriate British couples decade-long passion for art from around the region. The gallery showcases a variety of ceramics, sculptures, paintings and glass works from countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia, India and New Zealand.
content.openingtimes: 10am - 9pm daily, including public holidays (closed Christmas Day)

content.description: With the increasing demand for, and interest in, contemporary Asian art, Linda Gallery, an active player in the industry for more than a decade, strives to regularly showcase works by China and South-East Asia's sought-after creative individuals.

address.street: Whitchurch Road, Workloft 1 (Aden) off Portsdown Rd
Whitchurch Road, Workloft 1 (Aden) off Portsdown Rd

content.description: Mixed modernand contemporary art, as well as concertsand other cultural events.
Established in 2004, this gallery provides Singapore artists an alternative and affordable art space.
