An institute in its own league, the STPI is a expansive art space housing printing equipment and facilities, and has exhibited some of the biggest names in the print industry.
content.public-transport: Near station: Clarke Quay or Dhoby Ghaut
content.openingtimes:
Tue-Sat 10am-6pm
Closed on Sun
Mon by appointment.

content.description: This Indian import opened in Singapore in 2004, seeking to capitalize on the burgeoning popularity of the subcontinents vibrant contemporary art scene. Since then, Indigos quaint shop house on Neil Road has played host to everything from the modern to folk and tribal art, showcasing new talent as well as household names. Past exhibitions include Dhaneshwar Shahs collection of animal paintings and Thotha Vaikuntums series on the native Telengana women. Exhibitions are on all year round and the 2,500 sq ft, two-storey gallery space is available for rent.
content.openingtimes: 11am-6pm, Mon-Sat; Closed Sun and Public Holidays.

content.description: Yisulang’s roster covers artists from all over China. Works of art here embrace various genres, including traditionalism, modernism and postmodernism. Mo Tan Works by the Paris-based Singaporean landscape painter. 13-27 Mar.

A gallery and private museum containing more than 1,500 modern Asian and European artworks. Its permanent exhibition, Ink and Oil Painting, boasts a collection of exclusive and distinctive pieces by one of Chinas greatest and best-known artists of today the octagenarian Wu Guanzhong.

entry.name: Art Galleries at Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts

version.name: Art Galleries at Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts

content.description: Known for churning out some of the finest local artists and designers, NAFA is also home to lovingly and proudly displayed award-winning works.

Singapores oldest gallery is run by one of the industrys most colourful characters, Marjorie Chu. She has been instrumental in the art scenes development, helping to found the Art Galleries Association of Singapore and the ARTSingapore fair. The work is by predominantly regional artists.

This former Catholic boys school, a striking white building with two wings and long verandas, was revamped in the early 1990s when there was a policy of converting old colonial buildings into public museums. Because of its small, unusual and hidden gallery spaces, it has never held blockbuster shows. Instead, it specialises in smaller exhibitions, mostly 20th-century Asian visual art, often drawn from its own collection of South-east Asian pioneer art.

This two-storey shophouse space is filled to the brim with delicately designed vases and other glassware items that make perfect housewarming gifts and are sure to smarten up any mantlepiece or bar counter. The new summer collection will be available in eye-popping turquoise and emerald green hues

This homewares and furniture shop isknown to stock bespoke pieces like handcutcrystal from David Redman, printedandmirrored-glass furniture by Knowlesand Christou, and Limoges porcelainfrom Harlequin. And it recently startedselling a range of Claus Porto soaps,which have been made in Portugal forover 117 years. Also new to the store arephotographs by famed lensmen RusselWong. A fi rst for the photographer whohas snapped Asias biggest celebrities,Zhang Ziyi, Ken Watanabe and JackyChan to name a few, were sure this will beone more reason to pop down to the store.

As well as stocking Scandinavian fashion labels like Nudie Jeans, Pour and Rodebjer, Style: Nordic has just recently opened its top floor to home-made HAG Seating Solutions and slick, oh-so-modern Alvar Aalto stools. Showcased in a beautifully mocked-up office space, complete with desks and all sorts of office paraphernalia, itll serve as inspiration for anyone looking to makeover a living space in chic, minimalist style. Also, keep an eye out for the collection of funky wallpaper with graphic prints, colourful candle holders and other miscellaneous decorations for the home.

While the striking plywood display shelf at the entrance of the newly opened Objet is not for sale, their unusual light fi xtures are. The shop can custom-make almost any other piece of furniture. So yes, owning an extra-long pony hair couch with suede panels is entirely possible

Stocked with designer kitchen-accessory brands like Chilewich from the USA and Eisch from Italy, the store hawks simple yet stylish items that clearly cater to individuals whose aesthetic tastes run to unfussy silhouettes. A notable mention are the Alussi cabinets, which have doors that open up instead of out – a nifty feature that will surely work well in shoebox- size apartments

Specialising in furniture manufactured in a distinct baroque style – or ‘classical- modern’, as they like to call it – this is where to go if you’re after burgundyhued velvet quilted sofas and gothic-looking armchairs. Other home accessories include crystal candlestick holders, quirky red acrylic goblets and modern crystal chandeliers that have been sourced from around the region, which means wallet-friendly prices.

Perhaps one of the most underrated flea markets in Singapore, Home Clubs Flea Fly Flo Fun returns to lure us with a potent mix of fantastic bargains, good music and cheap booze. Spend your Sunday afternoon sifting through second-hand clothes, bags, CDs and oodles of other trinkets that may be the key to a fabulous outfi t in a fl ash. Dont be afraid to bargain hard, as the sellers are mostly people getting rid of old stuff to make space in the wardrobe.

Weve already registered Actually as the place to go for quality street chic fashion in Singapore, including Elvis Jesuss funky Ts flown in from the UK; street label Headquarter by three Thai designers;18th Amendment from Australia; and RVCA, a collection of uniquely designed casual wear from the USA.

Founded by a pair of brothers in 1993, Freitag creates cult bags made from tarpaulin. Not only is each item unique, the line is also selectively distributed: the boutique Actually is one of just three exclusive retailers of Freitag in Asia. The bags have inspired many copies like Demano and Kultbag (see below), but thats a good thing it signals that more people are recycling. A word of warning about the burned-rubber odour. Its unlikely that youll ever get rid of the smell, says Paul Khor, owner of Actually.

Named after one of the best tennis players of the twentieth century, the Fred Perry clothing label is enjoying a revival of sorts. Inside the store on Ann Siang Road, youll find everything except its Comme des Garçons collaborative line. While the labels polo shirts have long been considered a wardrobe staple, the question is why they became so popular in the first place. The answer lies in its signature laurel logo based on the Wimbledon symbol which is stitched rather than ironed on; after all, beauty is in the small details. And, of course, its tennis gear is matchless.

Quirky and at times downright unbelievable, Rustic Nirvana has somehow found a following with its unusual chopstick-wielding spa techniques. Theres also a range of body massages that use semi-precious stones like smoky quartz and agate. But thats not their oddest offering: the Aventurine Green Claypot Prata therapy claims to lock in the heat using prata (yes, the crispy dough bread), while jamu herbs work on the body to reduce aches and pains. There are [fb01] ve locations, including one at Gleneagles Hospital, but the original at Cantonment road is still the best.

Tucked in the suburbs of the Redhill housing estate and loved by the artsy and fashionable folks, this small boutique currently stocks pieces from both the men’s and women’s spring/summer 2007 collection. Check out the contrasting textured jackets, colour combinations of red, pink and mauve, and items sporting hardware details like studs and chains.

Fans of the quirky UK footwear label can finally thank the fashion gods for bringing the brand to our sunny shores. Primarily sold on popular online stores like Schuh.com, Irregular Choice is a favourite of Gwen Stefani and other stars. The brand is famous for its Split-Toe design, bright colours and funky add-ons.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri by appointment only, Sat & Sun noon-6pm.

content.description: Same, same but somewhat different is Spanish label Demano, which creates carry-alls out of recycled billboard material and non-recyclable PVC polyester promotional materials from Barcelona’s cultural events. With more than 1,600 happenings taking place in a year and almost 300 banners produced for each, the label is hardly short on supplies. Started in 1999, Demano has established agreements with all of the city’s major cultural venues to use their residual materials. Made by three designers, each bag is cut to showcase the most interesting aspects of the banners’ original designs, like cutting out the [fb01] sh in a ‘Lisboa em Festa’ banner to use on the front of a bag.
content.public-transport: Near station: Eunos or Paya Lebar

content.description: It’s safe to say that the male race has an easier time deciding what to wear on a day-to-day basis. Pull on a pair of pants, button up a shirt, slip on some shoes and walk out the door. Boring? Perhaps, but simplicity can be beautiful. Just look at what Swedish label Filippa K has achieved with its menswear. The classic fi ve-pocket jean has been given a twist thanks to a little stretch added in. Knitwear remains classic but jazzed up with a graphic – not plain – patch at the elbow. It is, after all, the details that count.

For the bride who wants a gown with a slightly indie edge, there’s Blu Mesh. Located on Bali Lane for more than fi ve years, owner and designer Corinna Kek prides herself on customising bridalwear at reasonable prices. In the past two years she’s also started dabbling in making one-off dresses ($90 to $180) with vintage fabric – the results, delectable.

Stretch out and relax on the comfortable armchairs as you reflect on your day with a pint in hand. One of the cosiest outlets of the lot, where boozers can sit back, relax and just enjoy the evening. Happy Hours from 11am to 9pm everyday 
Crazy Hour*: Mondays to Fridays from 5pm to 7pm *Not applicable on Public Holidays
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu: 11am to 1am, Fri & Sat: 11am to 2am, Sun: Closed

content.description: This joint is an unabashed meat market on weekends. Sweaty bodies dominate the dance floor, gyrating to Top 40 remixes. Dont assume all the men here love Dorothy though, because plenty of women bring their boyfriends along for a boogie.

Located at the heart of the colonial district, the Victoria Concert Hall has long played a prominent part in Singapores cultural scene. With its neoclassical architecture and impressive interior, it manages to be spacious yet intimate, and provides the sort of warm acoustics which musicians and music lovers crave. Pianist Alfred Cortot, cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and the Emerson Philharmonic are a few of the names to have graced the hall over the years.

A century ago, Telok Ayer Street was right up against the sea. And this temple, known as the Temple of Heavenly Happiness, was popular with newly arrived immigrants, who came here to burn incense in thanks to Ma Cho Po (a Taoist deity and protector of seafarers) for their safe arrival. Some of the materials used in the temple were taken from the boats, including the rooftop mosaic. Inside, the main altar features a statue of Ma Cho Po, and other deities of luck, war and punishment

entry.name: Conservatory Concert Hall, Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music

version.name: Conservatory Concert Hall, Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music

content.public-transport: Near station: Clementi or Buona Vista

content.description: If you like live music performances (10pm until late), you can join the hordes of people packing this place. Practically bursting at the seams on weekends, youll be hard-pressed to even find a decent spot to stand in. But if you can manage the discomfort of feeling like a sardine in a can, start filling yourself up with some of the brews (five bottles of Erdinger, Corona Extra or Tiger go for $50, all night long) and youll be partaking in the rowdiness in no time. While the performers differ nightly, its songbird Michaela who always rouses the folk with her throaty vocals and mature deliveries of both crowd favourites and current chart-toppers. On quieter nights, when you can actually find a stool to rest your bum, kick back and bob along to the jazzy house tunes, at the same time appreciating the lovely and understated Peranakan-style decor.

Singapores largest museum re-opened in December 2006 after a $118 million makeover and comprises two main galleries: the Singapore History Gallery,which traces the history of Singapore from its beginnings in the 14th century to the present day, and the Singapore Living Galleries, which focus on four life-style themes food, fashion, film & wayang, and photography. They also have occasional film showings.
Image copyright National Museum of Singapore
content.public-transport: Near station: Dhoby Ghaut, City Hall | Buses: 7, 14, 36, 171, 174
content.openingtimes: Singapore History Gallery daily 10am-6pm, Singapore Living Galleries daily 10am-8pm.

entry.name: Dragonfly at St James Power Station

version.name: Dragonfly at St James Power Station

content.description:
Oft-described as the bar where ah lians and ah bengs gather, this assumption is only half-true. The performers at this live-music room actually play a good mix of English and Mandarin favourites until the end of happy hour. Then dancers, aerialists and guest performers throng the stage and transform the place into something resembling a getai, albeit classier.
Sun-Thu: men $12, women $10; includes one drink. Fri & Sat: men $20, women $15; includes one drink. 
Happy hour: 8pm-9.30pm; minimum age: 18 for women, 23 for men. Dragonfly was included in our  Canto fight this feeling article.

Holland Village has had quite a makeover over the past few years, but its old-faithful watering hole Wala Wala affectionately known as Walas to locals remains ensconced on Lorong Mambong. On the ground floor, enjoy a cold one at the distinctive yellow-lit bar and catch the game on one of several flat-screen TVs. The bar upstairs hosts a variety of local music and comedy acts, with an acoustic happy hour from 7 to 8.30pm. The only annoying change at Walas is the new smoking policy only a limited number of seats are available for smokers outdoors, so the remaining cigarette-puffing patrons have to hang around the adjoining alley like delinquent teenagers.
Hard Rock Cafe won Best Burger on our Who is top of the Table? feature.

Its a universally acknowledged fact that a sure-fire way to get your date in a romantic mood is to take him/her to a lovely seaside locale, loosen things up with good booze and a whole lot of atmosphere, and voila youre set for the night. Essentially, that sums up this classy joint. With views over the lolling greens of Sentosa Golf Club and the stunning seascape south of the island, the restaurant-bar exudes a contemporary vibe with its interesting glassware and brightly coloured seats. Kudos to the attentive wait-staff, who know exactly when to blend into the background, and when to zip over and speed up your bill before your date loses the mood. 


Il Lido is also listed as a restaurant, click for information. Il Lido was included in our recent One Night Stand feature. And was also was featured in our recent Honey, we need to talk - Best bars to make up in feature.
content.public-transport: Near station: HarbourFront then Sentosa bus.

entry.name: The Empire - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED DOWN

version.name: The Empire - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED DOWN

content.description: An all-girls bar (although men are welcome) located on the top floor of a shophouse. Be prepared to climb as there isnt an elevator service, but if you want a cosy spot to enjoy music and good company, its a worthy ascent. Play pool in the private room, drink up at the bar or sway on the rooftop terrace (there are fans to keep you cool while you turn on the heat). If you want to hold your own private soirée, call ahead and book the private room at no extra charge. The music here is mainly Top 40 and R&B, but if you have a favourite playlist on your iPod, bring it along and the service staff will be more than happy to hook you up. Drinks are some of the cheapest in town: housepours at $6 and a magnum of Hoegaarden at $15.

It is likely that by the time you end up at Rav, it is past 2am and you are already half-pissed, if not more. And thats just a conservative guess. Most of the folks who come here are the same ones refusing to go home even after all the other clubs have shut their doors. Luckily, theres Rav and its playlist of unadulterated fun dance and house grooves, which is the best kind of music when you are all liquored up. Attracting a mix of trendy types, yuppies and gay men, this is the place where everyone lets their hair down and their inner dance-demon out. There are often drink promotions by the pitchers not to mention a happy-hour deal that gives you your second housepour for just ten cents (Mon-Fri, 6pm-midnight) so theres no need to worry about losing your buzz. If you really want to have fun, go late; get there too early and youll be standing around waiting for the night owls to arrive.
$20, includes one drink.

Singapores largest alfresco dining space has expanded, upwards: Oosh now has a modern European restaurant on the second level. The French-influenced menu offers extravagances like seared frog legs ($19) and a thick but well-cooked hunk of grilled Australian tenderloin topped with seared foie gras and a slice of black truffle ($48).

This unpretentious, yellow-painted pub and backpacker hostel is a slice of Down Under. The sunny decor features touches of red gum timber; Aussie draught beers include Gippsland Gold and Brewers Pilsener. Outside, find wooden benches, barbecues and revelry. More information for travellers on a budget and backpackers in Singapore.

Stacks of wine bottles from more than 100 labels line the dark wood-panelled walls of this shophouse-turned-Spanish provisions store. Ambience is a major player here, with dusty wooden barrels crowding the corners, a casual lounge room with armchairs upstairs, and a front deck thats ideal for enjoying something from the cigar menu. The wine-by-the-glass selection is decent (about a dozen on offer), while oenophiles may be more interested in the library collection an exclusive selection of bottles acquired from private collections (although charged at exclusive prices). The tapas menu is superb marinated olives, cheeses and mushrooms are must-tries, along with the paper-thin-crust pizzas.

Drinks $12-16.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thu 5.30pm-2am; Fri, Sat and holiday eve 5.30pm-3am.

content.description: This smoking yet non-smoky bar serves up some of the best happy hour deals in Chinatown. (The name means Chinatown in Spanish, by the way.) And after nagging from punters, its now open during the day. Whereas you used to have to rely on other restaurants for sustenance, Barrio has now opened up its own kitchen. Try the bruschetta ($10 for a dozen), which will more than keep the hunger pangs at bay until dinner. A happy-hour glass of wine is $6, rising to $12 during regular hours. Barrio Chino was included in our recent Eye on the ball feature.

Theres a reason why this place is packed every night of the week with English bankers: its right in the heart of the Boat Quay end of the CBD, and is more British than tea and scones with the Queen.

Owners Gaelic Inns, whose stable also includes Muddy Murphys, have decided to dispense with such fripperies as ambience and comfortable, ample seating; with a plum location right next to the river, they couldnt fail even if they pulped durians to make fruit juice.

If youre visiting from the UK, a trip to this mock-Victorian tavern is about as adventurous as pulling a beer can from the fridge, and approximately ten times more expensive.

In every possible sense this is a facsimile of a night out in London (in fact the humidity and local bar-staff are the only reminder that youre still in Asia); and just like the Big Smoke itself, a Friday-night stint here will wage war on your wallet.

Inflated prices, stentorian patrons and cramped environs can take the shine off the Penny Black experience, and you cant escape the feeling that youre part of a blatantly profiteering enterprise, but for convenience and location alone (not to mention a happy hour lasting eight and a half hours) it still gets our, ahem, stamp of approval.
content.openingtimes:
Mon-Thu 11.30am-1am
Fri, Sat & eve of public holidays 11.30am-2am
Sun 11.30am-12am

content.description: Mel's Place Bar & Bistro was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.

The imaginative minds at Imaginings (owners of KPO, Wala Wala and Balaclava) are good at creating bars with personality and they havent disappointed fans with Bar-Stop, a blink-and-youll-miss-it, three-in-one restaurant, bar and live jazz venue tucked away on Devonshire Road. This deceptively spacious two-storey spot is home to an outdoor restaurant and indoor bar, as well as an upstairs lounge filled with funky furniture. For those looking to dine, the quiet garden-like seating outside should be your choice for the night. Those with an eye for a well-stocked bar and an ear for live jazz can sit up close to the stage and take in all the (very loud) action. The polished cement floor, exposed brick walls, floor-to-ceiling windows and exceptional service make this space one of the coolest spots in town. It is indeed a bar to stop at.

Drinks price range from $6 to $17.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu 5pm- 1am; Fri, Sat & public holidays 5pm-2am. Happy hour 5pm-8pm.

content.description: Top 40 hits fill the room and a Filipino acoustic musician belts out standards by 70s soft-rockers James Taylor and Bread. Some Saturday nights see the occasional band performance where local blues musicians gather and play surprisingly decent 50s and 60s American blues, but the infrequency of the blues nights makes you wonder if they even get paid for getting on stage to play.

This place has the honour of being designed and built in Ireland, then shipped to Singapore and re-assembled at Circular Road. So no wonder you feel immediately transported from the humdrum of Singapore life the moment you step through its doors. Youll appreciate how everything is so straightforward and simple, from its draughts to its Irish stews no gimmicks to distract you from having a truly Irish experience and resident musican Gerry Cox, who performs live acoustic renditions of Irish folk songs and contemporary hits Monday to Friday, from 8.30pm onwards.

See also The Brasserie.
content.openingtimes: Mon & Tues 11am-1am, Weds, Thurs and Sat 11am-2am, Fri & Eve of PH 11am-3am, Sunday 11am-12am, Food Served 7/7 11am - 10:30pm (11pm on Fri)

entry.name: House of Rock - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED

version.name: House of Rock - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED

content.description: Apart from the name, which means in touch with me in Spanish, not much has changed about the former Club 95. Theyve moved some furniture and the walls now sport a few new paintings as part of a monthly showcase of creative talent (when we went it was Peenut and Pat Lawsartwork). Relaxing lounge tunes make this a popular spot to chill with the girls or to romance your latest love.

This karaoke pub has been around since the early 1990s and has always proudly bared the rainbow flag. Contrary to its name, you wont find cows or coolies here. Instead, youll get a queer mix of women in their early twenties and thirties, with men in office-wear singing Mando-pop tunes. The men and women may not sing in the same choir, but everyone gets along famously. The guys know full well they wont have girls harassing them to buy drinks, so the unspoken arrangement works for everyone the ladies can enjoy their cocktails and conversation, and the lads can sing to their hearts content. Bar owner Joey knows most of her regulars by name and is often seen mingling with the happy campers. Its all fun and merry-making here with good conversation and often not-so-good singing.

Living up to its name, this gem of a bar can be a tough one to find. Once youve nailed down the location Circular Road is the parallel street behind Boat Quay and made it up the three flights of stairs without running out of breath, youll be delighted by what you find. Inside, the mismatched furniture, low lighting,and oddly soothing pink and burgundy walls strip the bar of any airs. Hideouts patrons are not there to be seen or make PC small talk all they want is to sit back, relax and shoot the breeze with their friends. Indie bands play on Wednesdays, DJs spin house beats on Fridays,and on all other nights the DJ rotates between hip hop, funk and jazz.

A lush garden bar perfect for casual drinks on lazy evenings and quiet nights out. Hacienda's specialties include Fresh Fruit Martinis, the Frozen Blackberry Margarita and The Perfect Mojito a plus-sized and refreshing take on the classic drink.

You cant miss this bar with the rainbow flag noticeably perched above its entrance. Regulars come here forthe strong Long Island Iced Teas (just like at its sister bar, Tantric), double-shot drinks and also for the kitsch paraphernalia of semi-nude male pictures and musical-theatre posters that decorate the walls. The staff are friendly, personable and flirtatious, as is the crowd a mix of older Caucasian men and younger locals, tourists and expats. 

Happy hour: Daily from 7-9pm with drinks discounted by 20 per cent.

address.street: 40 Siloso Beach Walk, Siloso Beach, Sentosa
40 Siloso Beach Walk, Siloso Beach, Sentosa

content.description: Despite its international affiliation, Café Del Mar doesnt blow you away like you thought it might after making the trek to its beachside spot on Sentosa. Maybe its the lacklustre drinks or uninformed service, all of which contribute to a less-than-perfect experience. To its credit though, the bar boasts a nice setup with its strategically positioned pool that allows you to appreciate gorgeous dual views of both the sunset and beachwear-clad pilgrims whove come seeking a taste of Ibiza. Its spot-on repertoire of languid tunes on slow afternoons and more upbeat tracks at its Saturday foam parties also keeps things exciting.

Imagine having a restaurant so busy that you refuse to answer the telephone at all. Well, here it is. PS Cafe only takes bookings by SMS and does not take bookings at all for brunch on Sunday. But it is worth the wait just check out the huge pieces of home-made rocky-road on the counter as you walk in. The menu is quite restricted but delicious, and the service is brisk. Sit indoors near the open kitchen or outside overlooking the leafy environs. On Sundays, expect a 30-minute wait dont fret as we have seen some others doing, just put your name down and stroll around Dempsey Road for a while. Actually, that should help to ensure that you can manage all three courses. Other branches: PS Cafe at The Paragon and PS Cafe at Palais Renaissance.
content.openingtimes:
Dinner Mon-Thurs & Sunday 6.30pm-midnight Last food order 10.30pm; last bar order 11pm
Fri-Sat 6.30pm-2am Last food order 10.30pm; last bar order 1am
Lunch Tues - Fri 11.30am - 5.00pm Last food order 3.00pm Last tea & cake order 4.30pm
Brunch
Sat - Sun 9.30am - 5.00pm Last food order 3.00pm Last tea & cake order 4.30pm

content.description: Imagine a restaurant business model where, at the end of lunch, diners pay what they think the meal was worth. A risky proposition, to be sure, but one that has been put into practice at Annalakshmi and seems to have done them no harm. The buffet counter is entirely vegetarian dhals, soups, cauliflower curry, yoghurt dips, papadums with everything cooked daily. Its low-fuss, home-spun cooking that wins our vote for its earnestness and complete lack of pretension. At the end, payment amounts to a donation to the restaurant (and its support for sister organisation, the Temple of Fine Arts), but really, anything less than $5 per head would be a disgrace.

A mid-sized hawkers centre on the corner of Telok Ayer and Boon Tat roads, 121 is a favourite lunchtime haunt for Chinatown workers from all walks of life, from the well-groomed expatriate to the motorbike courier. The biggest queue emanates from Nur Nasi Padang, known as the finest purveyor of Indonesian food in the vicinity. Expect a generous portion of melt-in-the-mouth beef rendang, addictively garnished chicken drumsticks and a colourful range of meat curries and spicy vegetable dishes. Other food-stall highlights include the omnivorous Kingsland Vegetarian stand which proudly proclaims, No pork or lard, and serves a mean duck laksa and Paratha Treat, for the last word in chepati, daal and samosas. For pudding, make a beeline for Frankies Peanut Pancake, a winner of the Green Book of Food Awards 07/08.

The stars of the show here are the slabs of sizzling hot (400 degrees!) volcanic stone from Australia on which the steaks, seafood and veggies are cooked by customers at the table to their liking. No oil or other cooking fat is used so its all good. But if that sounds too messy for you, theres also an excellent value $10.99++ ($9.99++ for students, $8.99++ if you are 55 years and above) set lunch comprising soup of the day, main course, and dessert or hot drink.

Hes a long way from New Orleans, but for American Bernie Utchenik, home is where the stomach is. Wedged incongruously between a rojak and fishball noodle stall, he serves up monstrous portions of American diner fare - gumbo, burgers, steaks, fries and the like - at really low prices. Best cheap meal bet: the Swanky Franky hotdog ($9), is a log-like chicken sausage wrapped in bacon, blanketed with melted cheddar and onions, and served witha giant side order of fries and coleslaw.
content.public-transport: Near station: Ang Mo Kio | Buses: 138, 266

content.description: The restaurant is tricked out in Peranakan furniture and decorations, which can be a tad garish, but the menu, which is personally planned by executive chef Patricia Lee, more than makes up for it. Many regulars swear by the ayam bua keluak (small $7.80, big $10.80), the essential Peranakan stew made from chicken and Indonesian black nut in a thick, spicy gravy that combines all the different taste sensations: sweet, salty, bitter and sour. But we say try the kepetin bak wan ($8.80), a rich broth which comes with generous helping of juicy balls of crabmeat, tofu and minced pork, sprinkled with grated bamboo shoots.

Hearty, warm fare served by a hearty, warm woman – that’s what we want from Russian food. Evgenia Polesnaya, more affectionately known to local patrons as Jane, delivers both. The place is staffed by Russkie natives (Polesnya is from Belarus herself) and doles out perfect pirozhki (appetiser bun with cabbage) for just 70 cents. Other fi lling fare includes draniki (potato pancakes, $5.50), blinchiki (pancakes stuffed with snow apple, icecream or honey; $6), kotleta kartofelnaya (mashed potato pie with mushrooms, $7) and kvas (sparkling bread drink made with yeast, $3).

Featuring an al fresco dining space, this restaurant offers huge portions of Moroccan specialities at a tiny price. A fusion of European and African food, the cuisine is known for its extensive use of North African spices (such as cumin, coriander, saffron, chillis and cinnamon) in tandem with almond and pistachio nuts. The most expensive dish is just $6.50, and most can be had for less than $5. Run by a local Malay lady and her Moroccan husband, the Deli offersfriendly and prompt service and piping hot food served in a traditional earthenware tagine (the name for both pot and dish). Don’t miss the Moroccan apple drink – a sweet, cold, blended shake with milk and cinnamon – and the traditional hot apple tea, which is considered an art form in Morocco. Pair either with Koofta tagin (beef stewed in an earthenware pot, $5.50) or the Moroccan beef kebab ($4). 30

The nondescript façade belies the rich Penang fare offered here, some of the best this side of the Malaysian border. Plus point: friendly and helpful staff who will even give you a drink as you wait for your takeaway. The flavourful hor fun duck soup ($8.50), with its huge braised duck leg, can actually feed two light eaters.

Try the mou hin ga ($5.50), a ubiquitous noodle soup served as a light meal. The version here is richly curried in thick orange fi sh gravy, fi lled with thin rice noodles and a hard-boiled egg, and pungent with lemongrass and lime.

A dyed-in-the-wool local institution, Samys is as low-maintenance as they come. Its more of a mess hall than a restaurant with its high ceilings, shuttered windows and ceiling fans. In place of plates are banana leaves, onto which servers slop mounds of aromatic, richly flavoured and head-hurting hot curries. Cool down with some fresh lime juice.

The shelves of organic goodies may be gone, but the former Yogi Hub still brings in a mixed crowd of aunties, Buddhist nuns and the arty set all smacking their collective lips at the eclectic vegetarian menu and organic fruit juices (try the red cabbage and grapes). The petai fried rice is an unexpectedly wonderful blend of bitter nuts, carrots, brown rice and sambal, while the tofu claypot filled with gingko nuts, bamboo shoots and asparagus is the best kind of comfort food. As is the walnut cheesecake.

Everything about Ka Soh – Cantonese for mother-in-law – shrieks 1950s. But the daily crowds don’t come to this Chinatown eatery for the décor. The bustling, motherly staff dish out stern love and terrifically homey Canto-classics in equal measure. Bestsellers include deep-fried chicken marinated in prawn paste, deep-fried cubes of salted tofu and a milky, fish-head beehoon noodle soup.

Singapore’s Arab quarter is a peek into another world: a little community jammed with crumbling architecture, carpet sellers and little eateries like Alaturka where the air moves lazily and you can’t shake the feeling that you’re not in Singapore anymore, Toto. Share the karisik kebab, a large copper platter of combination kebabs including charcoal-grilled lamb chops and served with tender chunks of grilled chili, pilaf and rich buttery vegetables. For a postprandial treat, sit outside and puff a strawberry-flavoured shisha.

The hardy Peranakans have a cuisine thats justly famed for its splendid blend of sweet, spicy and sour flavours. Since the 1970s, the Princess Terraces Peranakan buffet has been booked solid, especially at weekends, luring gourmands with its irresistible spread of Penang-styled laksa, char kway teow, rust-coloured prawn noodles and colourful, coconut-infused desserts. Skip breakfast and tuck in.   Costs: $38 (adults), $23.80 (children).
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri noon-2.30pm, Sat & Sun noon-3.30pm; Daily 6-10pm.

content.description: The breakfast experience doesnt get any more authentic than this. For 60 years, generations of loyal, local residents have been turning up at Chin Mee Chin for their morning kick-start of jet-black coffee (served in the traditional porcelain cups, thank you) and soft-boiled eggs. Dont miss the thick slabs of toast that are slathered with butter and a side slathering of kaya. Take a taxi.

With its new and more visible location, its business as usual at Sage. The dining rooms grey palette and small but well thought-out mod French/Italian menu attract a mix of suits and ladies who lunch, though the rather uncomfortable chairs dont encourage lingering. The crab salad sits in a pool of gazpacho and is made of avocado, olives, firm and chunks of meat, cut with the crunch of celeriac and onion. Though the prawn carbonara is more a prawn mee thickened with egg and prawn oil than a carbonara, its a nice twist to the usual version. Especially good is the veal cheek braised in a thick and rich porcini sauce. The set lunch starts from $38.
content.public-transport: Near station: Dhoby Ghaut, Clarke Quay

content.description: Outside Hotel 1929 lies the notorious red-light district of Keong Saik Road; inside, the mood is more serene as diners peruse the eclectic Mod Euro menu from the talented Sebastian Ng. The food is consistently good and imaginative, including pan-seared scallops with parma ham in an orange and tarragon vinaigrette; and sea bass with smoked bacon ragout and truffleyuzu butter sauce. Like the food, the decor is neither fussy nor pretentious.

Its hard to believe that behind such an unimposing façade lies an eatery with such a fierce following. The fare here is redolent of a different time and place; of rustic villages and hand-pounded herbs and spices, and recipes passed from mother to daughter. There are tender chunks of beef braised in a creamy coconut sauce, chicken curries, grilled meats and a technicolour spread of puddings.

The small dining room – when you finally find it in the rabbit warren of Cuppage Plaza – is claustrophobic, the seats aren’t very comfortable and bodies are squashed together, but on most nights, you can’t get a spare table for love or money. The draw here is yakitori – deliciously fresh ingredients barbecued on bamboo spears. Try the lightly salted foie gras, chicken meat balls blended with chunks of black mushrooms, moist chicken wings dipped in salt and marbled Wagyu beef. Reservations are essential on the weekend.

Diego Chiarinis short menu changes monthly. Its strengths lie in its variety and authenticity, with soft accents from the Tuscan and Piedmonte regions. There is much that delights, not least the attentive service. The pasta dishes are a triumph; standouts include robust rigatoni bathed in a deep red sauce of thyme, black olives and tender rabbit.

Deep in the suburbs, Valentinos is a family-run trattoria where the squid-ink pasta, golden carbonara and paper-thin slices of pork loin braised in a stock of white wine, garlic and bay leaves are served up with brio. The Milan-born chef spent many years cooking in Tuscany and something of the Tuscan penchant for food with sunny colours, dense with flavours and simply prepared vegetables obviously wore off. That said, the dessert trolley, while looking temptingly luscious, is usually a let-down.

Rijsttafel is a Dutch-Indonesian hybrid of a buffet, but served to guests at the table all at once. Rice Table loads up on a never-ending flow of little plates filled with an astonishing range of meats, vegetables and flavours: satay, tahu telor, turmeric-tinged chicken curry, otah-otah, fried potato dumplings, thick rust-coloured beef rendang and more. At lunch, expect around 14 dishes, and a gut-busting 20 at dinner. The service is fast and furious, and its easily one of the best value meals in town. 

Lunch buffet $14.80++, dinner buffet $23.80++. Rice Table won Best Food for value under $25 in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

Chef Milind Sovani has created a show-stopping pan-Indian meal in a charming Scotts Road black-and-white bungalow. On the menu, which criss-crosses the subcontinents regional cuisines, youll find melt-in-the-mouth Keralan-spiced lamb shanks, tandoori prawns bathed in a pomegranate marinade, and the Lucknavi classic of Gilawat kebabs pan-seared ground lamb patties perfumed by cardamom, ground rose petals and raw papaya.

The laksa may share equal billing here, but its the prawn noodles at this stall that steal the limelight. The flavours ring as pork slices, crisp pork rinds, tiles of fish cake and ruby-streaked prawns are piled into a bowl of clear prawn stock.

This family-run restaurant has been rattling around since 1929 and is still going strong. Classical and comfortingly familiar, it takes few wrong turns: the suckling pig, Peking duck, chili Sri Lankan crabs and crisp roast chicken all fly from the kitchen at a dizzying pace. A must-try are the golden cereal prawns: huge, sweetly salty crustaceans encrusted with oatmeal flakes.

Long Beach has been there since anyone can remember, and judging from the weekend crowds of multi-generational families, it will be around for the long haul. Dont be distracted by the other goodies piled high on surrounding tables. Just concentrate on the huge Sri Lankan crabs doused with a molten, eggy, tart, tongue-singeing gravy. The other favourite is the black pepper crab, here doused with jet-black gravy. Mop it all up with crisply fried mantou dumplings.
content.openingtimes: Daily 11am-3pm, 5pm-12.15am; Sat and eve of holidays 11am-1.15am.

content.description: If you dont have a reservation on the weekend, forget about getting a table here after noon. The menu can be intimidating, so let the staff guide you. Scrumptious dim sum includes deep-fried yam pastries, sautéed snake beans and rice-flour rolls stuffed with prawns. On the à la carte menu, the steamed fish is excellent. Ask for a booth seat; the other tables are exposed to heavy traffic. Imperial Treasure (a rival to the Crystal Jade group) has four other restaurants around town, each specialising in a different Chinese cuisine.

Outdoor venue located on the Singapore Grand Prix F1 tracks.

By shuttle service: The FunVee shuttle bus takes you directly from City Hall MRT station to the Singapore Flyer at $2 per pax (return trip). Shuttle is available at every half hour interval from 10am to 10pm daily. Pick up from bus stop located in between between St Andrews Cathedral and The Adelphi at Coleman Street.

By car: Limited parking is available at the F1 Pit Building or at the Singapore Flyer. Drive along Raffles Boulevard and turn into Raffles Avenue on the right. F1 Pit Building car park is on the left and Singapore Flyers car park entrance is on the right. Respective parking charges apply.

If youve got money to burn ($198 per head) and an adventurous palate, dive into the seven-course dinner at Fifty- Three. The use of molecular gastronomy in the cooking is superb and can be tasted from beginning to end. How about this for a menu: start with the crispy chicken skin chip with oyster emulsion, move on to pan-seared lobster served alongside apples garlanded with pieces of chopped duck tongue, and finish with chocolate mousse sprinkled with Jerusalem artichoke shavings. Youre left completely satisfied. After signing the enormous bill they surprise you with a gin and tonic sweet that dissolves after a minute or two on your tongue into a G&T at which point youre finally convinced it was money well spent.  Costs: lunch $48-$78, dinner $198.

If you think a restaurant committed to serving no meat, no seafood, no eggs, no onion, no garlic and no MSG would be a no-go, youd be wrong. Somehow despite all thats not used, Naïve dishes up intense flavours and textures. Much of the magic is accomplished through the copious use of monkey head mushrooms that taste more like meat than vegetables. Youll find them soaking up flavours such as sweet and sizzling kongpo sauce; braised in an aromatic five-spice broth; or sliced and sautéed thin and crispy. Of course, tofu makes an appearance, but the plain old curd is transformed into a star with a tangy barbecue baste worthy of a pork rib, or sharp tamarind, lemongrass and chilli sauce. The warm pumpkin and sago soup was a dessert highlight. And the blessing of the sesame seeds (BLOSS) is a surprise youll have to ask the helpful staff about. Costs: Lunch sets from $9.90, dinner sets from $14.90.
content.public-transport: Near station: Paya Lebar, then take a taxi

content.description: Despite its far-flung location requiring a few bus transfers, a patient taxi driver or GPS to get there Buckaroo is packing them in and youre advised to book ahead (be wary of the smoking tables). Serving Western staples such as salads, steak and finger-lickin ribs, by far the biggest pull for the uninitiated is the famous hotter-than-hot buffalo wings. Ranging from a mild level one, through to a suicidal level ten, these secret-recipe wings will have you sculling beer or lime margaritas before even contemplating the main event. Douse the flames with towers of crispy onion rings or creamily delicious coconut gelato. With no service charge or GST, it means the only thing not burning will be your pocket.

This 41-year-old Teochew restaurant is one of the last of its kind in Singapore; think fluorescent-lit dining room, bright-pink foldable chairs and faded wood-panelled walls. Occupying three units of shophouses, Lee Kui is also known as Ah Hoi or crab in Teochew. As the name implies, people flock here for one thing the famous cold crabs. But if the hefty price tag of about $70 per kg hurts, consider wallet-friendly alternatives from the extensive menu of stir-fries, stews, deep-fried and steamed dishes. We highly recommend the crisp and moist oyster omelette, served with refreshing sprigs of coriander; savoury eight-treasure vegetarian stew that includes melt-in-the-mouth cabbage and moss in a oyster-sauce laced gravy; and the braised duck wings served in a claypot bubbling with a dark and rich brew. Complete your meal on a high note with the sweet and unctuous ambrosia of or nee (yam paste), crowned with gingko nuts and creamy mashed pumpkins.

Bontás new stablemate gushes in its web-blurb about its beautiful surroundings, a setting which embraces nature and exudes serenity. The self-proclaimed laid-back and rustic atmosphere has you expecting something resembling Raw Kitchen Bars middle-of-nowhere foodie cabin, or PS. Café on Dempsey. In reality, co-owner and chef Luca Pezzeras latest venture shares little in common with these other two restaurants. For starters, District 10 is only a stones throw from a busy road junction, next to a flashy electronics showroom. Occupying the site of a former school, the outdoor dining area sits bang next to a rough brick wall, as if you were eating in a student union canteen. On the soggy Friday night we visited, our first impressions were compounded by an insanely noisy radio blasting bland pop directly overhead, latticework roofing leaking raindrops on our chairs, plates and heads, and a hideous dripping affair next to us like some sort of inverted well, better suited to Underwater World than a restaurant. As my companions drink arrived (but not mine), the laughable starter came too: five pieces of crunchy crostini a couple of millimetres thick, topped with a blancmange-like fishy paste. Devouring rocket leaves to keep ourselves going, we watched in amusement as the wait-staff bustled around us like headless chickens, two of them having a blazing row in a service area ornately decorated with a saggy black bin bag. Our chairs vibrated every time someone dashed across the decking, so the entire meal felt like we were on a particularly uncomfortable funfair ride, sans the fun. The vino may be imported from boutique wineries, and indeed the Zonin prosecco tasted delicious, but it lasted two sips. Our mains suffered from the opposite syndrome: the sirloin steak was more than generous, but not cooked to order, while the fish and chips order was copious but anaemic. I asked for some salt to jazz it up, but the seemingly esoteric request was lost in translation, and it took a second go before the elusive condiment arrived. You cant fault their efficiency; my partners plate was whisked away before Id finished, and while my Stella Artois had taken 15 minutes to be delivered, the bill arrived in seconds flat. So although I was reluctant to return, I was extremely glad I did. In almost every respect our second visit, this time indoors, was a superior experience. The staff led us into the light-filled, spacious dining room dominated by teak tables and chairs, and a huge wine cellar. Things were looking up already, especially with the arrival of two exemplary drinks. A virgin mojito at just $5.20 was so good my companion didnt miss the alcohol at all; a smoky, deeply mellow Fredda Barolo house red ($12) set me up perfectly for the main course. But I should have known from the non-Italian spelling of lasagne bolognaise (its bolognese, fact fans) this wasnt the genuine article, and so it proved. The inside was crumbly instead of meaty and cheesy, and lukewarm rather than piping hot. It tasted like a ready meal from Mustafa Centres frozen section, shoved in the microwave, but not for long enough. They didnt have any trouble drumming up a regional dish, however: the crayfish noodle was well presented and infused with delicately sweet Thai flavours. Although on the small side, the crayfish was compensated by a generous portion of prawns and noodles. If previous courses had their faults, the chefs redeemed themselves with a remarkable crème brûlée, textured to perfection, whose generous lashings of rum packed a seriously heady wallop. Shared between two, this was enough to end the meal on a very high (and ever-so-slightly inebriated) note. The staff are well-intentioned, but essentially clueless, and their hurried style lends the whole set-up an amateurish air. Sport fiends on a beered-up weekender will fit in perfectly at the imposing bar, with its huge TV screen showing football. And theres no doubt that for many, both local and foreign, this is a winning formula; at weekends it does a roaring trade. But choosier diners seeking quiet surrounds and cordon bleu cuisine could find District 10 a costly disappointment. Main courses $12-$24. By Jonathan Evans
content.openingtimes:
Mon-Thu 11.30am-12am (last order for food at 10.30pm)
Fri & eve of PH 11.30am-1am (last order at 12.30am)
Sat 10am-1am (last order at 12.30am)
Sunday & PH 10am-12am (last order at 10.30pm)

content.description: Making that first visit to Good Old Frog Porridge on Outram Road may very well be a life-changing decision. Once youve savoured these tender appendages, there is no turning back. Served piping hot, the succulent meat comes out in an earthen clay pot with heaps of sliced ginger and spring onions in a thick, fragrant pool of dark soysauce gravy blistering dried chillis are optional. This utterly addictive brew is best slurped down with silky smooth congee and a plate of shallot-topped chye sim on the side. Wash it all down with a glass of iced herbal tea. Note: if you purchase four frogs you get one free.

content.vendor-category: Well & Good | Deals of the month

content.description: The bakers are true artists, crafting cakes with flair and creativity that makes them look too good to eat (almost). Owner Jeffrey Galistan says his most popular cake is the Chocolate Etoile, a sinful cocoa creation sprinkled with a half-moon of powdered sugar and crowned with a bouquet of chocolate bark, leaves and flowers.
Spahaven, primely located at Amoy Street, caters to working professionals for appointments during lunch-breaks. Treatments offered include waxes, hair removal, and facials.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 11am-9pm; Sat 11am-7pm. Closed on Sun & Public Holidays.

content.description: From the reassuring presence of the tall French maître d at the entrance to the French-accented English floating through the kitchens peek-a-boo service window, Les Artistes got everything right. The bread basket arrived with warm, chewy homemade bread alongside a rich, earthy duck rillette. Theres not much on the regularly changing menu for vegetarians, but thats the French for you. Why settle for sautéed greens when you could hoe into beef cheeks that have been braised for five hours? The portions themselves were on the small side and, for a bistro, a little too prettily plated. The upside is that everything was cooked with seasoned aplomb. The meaty, rosemary-laced rack of lamb arrived with a shot glass of garlicky, truffled purée that sparkled with the low crunch of sea salt. The gelatinous beef cheek, stained a deep red by wine, is defenceless against the slight prod of the fork. Even the desserts cleaved close to chef Nicolas Joannys less-is-more approach, exemplified by a sweet pear poached and served with a mere scattering of shaved almonds. Simple, but not insultingly so. Costs: Dinner set meals from $48 for three courses, $58 for three courses.

This little art school off Bukit Timah Road lets kids scratch their creative itch with clay-making, mosaic, acrylic and oil painting, and food art classes. They're meaningful gifts for kiddie birthdays, think of these classes as grooming the next Picasso.  Costs Registration: $30 Drop-in Session: $35 Trial session for Canvass Doodler: $20 Trial session for other Canvass classes: $35 Term Fees (13 weeks): $390

8Q is the Singapore Art Museum's newest contemporary art extension. Housed in the former Catholic High School, this space is set to become a place for artists and the public to engage in a lively art exchange. Free admission: Mon-Thu 12pm2pm; Fri 6pm9pm.

Enjoy restaurant-quality food such as schnitzels ($6) and pork knuckles, but at hawker prices at this new eatery in the heart of Chinatown. Serving cold draught beer alongside hearty German fare, the owners also cater to the health-conscious by leaving out any additives or preservatives.
Good for inline skating gear. They've conduct skating classes and speed-skating expeditions as well.

Tucked away in a restored, black-and- white house in the colonial-style Rochester Park cluster of restaurants, this elegant yet decidedly casual eatery and attached alfresco bar has the potential to be one of the citys best.

The food is marketed as South- East Asian-influenced contemporary European cuisine, and usually I would balk at such a wordy description; this type of fused cuisine can, more often than not, lead to a complicated, overseasoned mess. But after two visits Im happy to report that Krishs food is far from confused: its original, and I am confident in saying this is Singapores newest splurge-worthy spot.

I kick off proceedings with the intriguingly named pork belly tikka. The dish arrives and I am greeted with fine slices of marinated pork, kept moist with a tamarind and shaved red onion salsa. The acidic punch of the sauce perfectly cuts through the fattiness of the coriander-, cumin- and garam masala-spiced meat and provides the dish with an unexpected lightness.

A starter of carrot ravioli lives up to the high standard that has already been set; the four pasta parcels swim in a ginger-and-brown-butter emulsion offset by pomegranate seeds. Although decadently creamy, its surprisingly delicate and, dare I say it, light.

The risotto of sweet-green peas and spice-crusted paneer, and the roasted eggplant samosas with balsamic tomato and basil aioli, are both filled with rich flavours and forgive me for repeating myself pleasingly light.

The main dishes did not disappoint. The seared duck breast juicy slices of duck laying atop a curried confit hash with a fennel and tamarind reduction confirmed that things were only getting better. The braised lamb shank sprinkled with rogan josh spices, and served with mint raita and a chickpea mash, is delicious. Although I love the practical choice to serve the shank deboned, the dish suffers from an obvious lack of crunch, since the textures become mushy when served together.

The seared sea bass with Israeli couscous and the French butter sauce beurre blanc suffers a similarly slushy fate, even if the orange-onion chutney with coriander and chilli provides the dish with a crisp texture and citric twist. A crunchier skin may improve the dish, although the fish itself is unbelievably moist.

In addition to being innovative, Krishs menu offers a wide range of prices, including mouthwatering specials essential for attracting repeat customers. Having already dined there twice, Ive spotted a number of return-worthy dishes.

It earns props, too, for the generous selection of reasonably priced wines by the glass: theres a good half-dozen choices of both red and white, all priced from $12 to $16 a glass perfect for diners not wanting to spring for a whole bottle, or those looking for a bit of variety with their meal.

While there are annoying lapses in service wine glasses not refilled, a too-brisk clearing of plates, a lack of detailed menu knowledge and, annoyingly, dishes served at separate times the quality of the food proves too strong for me to stop loving this restaurant.

In fact, Im already planning my next visit. Im sure I can hear their papadum-crusted snapper with a mint-coriander emulsion calling my name. Loudly. Mary Weaver

This eatery, planted on the ground floor of the former Tanglin Post Office, succeeds in its goal to provide a relaxed locale ideal for both singles and families. The concept seems to be working; during weekdays the office crowd takes root, but weekends are abuzz with parents and their saplings clambering over the on-site playground. The food is a bit ho-hum, with some menu items that read well on paper, but fail to meet up with the expectations theyve set. The soft-shell crab had that day-old aroma and the open-face steak sandwich, once wed waded through the lettuce and sliced tomatoes, was overdone. But the ambience helps make up for some of these flaws. Another redeeming factor is the desserts, with the antipodean favourite pavlova being an indulgent finale for two. The wine list is also plentiful, and first-rate fresh juices and smoothies will surely nourish your sagging branches.

Halal Swedish food on Arab Street is a rare sight, and modern, whitewashed Fika certainly stands out in the mostly traditional area dominated by shophouses. The desserts are the clear winner here, while the mains are only so-so; tea-lovers will appreciate the personal pot service and eclectic selection of Gryphon teas. Avoid the unwieldy, open-faced sandwiches and stick with the sweet stuff: a just-right chocolate cake and Swedish pancakes with preserves go down a treat.

Show me a sign, just show me a sign These were the words running through my head as we aimlessly wandered around the ground floor of The Sail, the luxury condominium at Marina Bay, in our search for Rocks. While making my reservation on the phone, restaurant staff had failed to mention I should pack a GPS and a bucket load of patience in order to find the place. Tip: its on the second floor, closest to the big orange escalator. Within seconds were greeted by the friendly wait-staff and Im soon perusing the reasonably priced wine list (glasses from just $10) and the food menu, which unsurprisingly has a strong selection of grilled meats, but a surprisingly strong selection of seafood. Not long after, were tucking into half a dozen grilled oysters with subtle overtones of lime juice, soy sauce and wasabi. Even better is the fresh kingfish ceviche which is bursting with acidity and punch, courtesy of some lime, chilli and shallots. For mains we decide to test out the grill and order a 250gm tenderloin and 350gm sirloin, both 120-day grain-fed pieces of Australian beef. The complementary sauces include béarnaise, togarashi and red wine. Portion-wise, were not disappointed. These steaks are huge. But once again, were shown that size isnt always everything both are a tad overcooked and a little on the bland side. The truffle mashed potatoes and sautéed wild mushrooms were standout sides.
Kingfish Ceviche On my second time around, with two hungry girlfriends in tow, I order some dishes Id been eyeing the previous visit. The sizzling beef maki sits at the top of the list. Served on a hot stone, three slices of tenderloin are rolled up and accompanied by a soy wasabi sauce. The trick is to let them sizzle for as long, or as short, as you like. This dish is a winner. Its tender, fragrant and tasty. For my main, I tuck into the cod papillote provençale which is essentially a fish steamed in a foil bag with onion, tomato and herbs. While the dish is high on the wow factor in terms of presentation, it is lacking on the taste front. The barbecued chilli crab cakes are a major disappointment because, well, they look and taste more like rubbery Thai fish cakes. Luckily, sides of gratinated root vegetables and French fries help to save the day. Rocks has all the makings of a solid restaurant. The decor, service and location are convenient for the after-work and work-lunch crowd, and Marina Bay will only continue to get busier. The menu is hitting the right notes the wood-fired pizzas and the Rocks cheeseburger look particularly third-trip worthy but I have a feeling that Rocks needs to bed itself in just a little more, refine the menu and give the food more oomph. Not to mention investing in proper ground-floor signage.

Tucked away at the end of a quiet road, this cake shop is a hood favourite thanks to its rich chocolate fudge cake made from Belgian chocolate. Customised creations are also on offer fashion a cake complete with cream or fondant finishing in the form of a jeep, poker table, pink garden or whatever you fancy. These cakes (from $38 per kg) and cupcakes (from $2.50 each), and pre-orders, take a minimum of three days, while wedding cakes (from $38 per kg) take a week to whip up.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat 11am-8pm; Sun 11am-6pm. Closed every last Monday of the month.

content.description: How do you know a neighbourhood is becoming more gentrified? When a gourmet deli/butcher sets up shop. Open since July 2008, Hubers is more than just a meat seller, theyve styled this outlet along a more gourmet angle, selling imported dairy products, frozen seafood, salads, fresh breads and even fondue pots. Beyond being the purveyors of prime cuts of meat popular items include the Australian Stockyard Angus grain-fed beef, lamb chops and sausages the staff can also attend to any of your portion cutting, marinating, roasting, vacuum packing needs. And as all the butchers are former cooks and chefs, you know your grub is safe in their hands. Free home delivery for orders over $75.

New to our island of peace and tranquility is Wave House Sentosa. This new attraction brings simulated surfing to our waveless shores. Seasoned surfers can grab their boards and have a go at the FlowBarrel (and its simulated loft wave), while newbies can attempt to find their feet on the FlowRider. For others who would rather stay out of the surf, there is a pool and two beach bars to keep you occupied. Costs: Admission $10 (Mon-Thu), $20 (Fri & Sat), fully redeemable for food, drinks and rides. $30 (FlowRider), $45 (FlowBarrel).
Email brnd_low@yahoo.com.sg for more information

entry.name: Xu Jun Sheng (Long Ji) Chao Zhou Mei Shi

version.name: Xu Jun Sheng (Long Ji) Chao Zhou Mei Shi

content.description: With its myriad buzzing KTV lounges and sleazy nightclubs, Joo Chiat seems to be anchored as Singapores alternative red-light precinct, but the foodies among us know that its distinctive dining culture is part of its inimitable charm. Take the Teochew tze char (stir fry) stall Xu Jun Sheng Chao Zhou Mei Shi, a fluorescent-lit pre-war coffee shop. For 60 years it has been dishing out piping hot Teochew porridge from an unembellished kopitiam at Joo Chiat (incidentally, they recently moved across the street to another unit). On offer are heartwarming classics arranged on a glass counter including slow-braised pork knuckles in a thick, dark brew, and fried-to-order ngoh hiang (meat rolls). But what really steals the show is the star seafood cast: a whole pomfret fish steamed simply with salted vegetables in a light consommé; chunks of cold crab brimming with creamy golden roe; and a crispy wok-fried oyster omelette. Their not too sweet or nee (yam paste) crowned with chunks of golden pumpkin is the best weve had in a long time. Main courses $4-$35.

There was a time when foodies assumed the torpid neighbourhood of Macpherson would never make it on to their must eat radar screen, but it did. Thanks to Ming Kee, which opened five years ago, Macpherson has been drawing a steady stream of food bloggers and gourmets; even a well-known dignitary has graced this eatery, as evidenced by the pictures that neatly adorn the curtain-lined walls. The lure? Rustic, non-denominational Chinese food seasoned with aplomb. As the name implies, the star attraction here is the live seafood displayed discreetly in tanks at the back of the air-conditioned restaurant. The crème de la crème of the seafood is the luscious steamed mussels which look more like giant clams in an addictive, fried garlic-streaked sauce. The claypot Sri Lankan crab tossed with crab roe-studded bee hoon, another popular dish here, was pleasant but slightly overdone. Other items that shine from the extensive menu include the tender fried spare ribs flavoured with a Guinness sauce and the bubbling-hot claypot bean curd with seasonal vegetables. Main courses from $18.
Embraced by nature. SAFRA Yishun Country Club is a place where family and friends can relax, dine or play.

content.vendor-category: Well & Good | Deals of the month

content.description: Just as oysters are rough on the outside but hold polished pearls within their clutches, Le Perle Noir is a pleasant surprise among the dark-windowed sports bars and massage parlours that surround it. Diners can sit on the leafy outdoor patio, or step inside to the much more civilised, wood-bedecked interior. The scallop entrée was perfectly seared and paired with a tuft of bacon-infused arugula and drizzled with an orange whisky sauce. The prosciuttowrapped cod was a real palate-dazzler, resting regally on its bed of mustardy Puy lentils and finished with a brushstroke of macadamia nut pesto. As fusion-filled as the menu is, some of the true delights here are the simplest a mouthwatering grilled pork chop, mussels in your choice of broth, or super-fresh oysters. A bit pricey, but arent all pearls?
content.openingtimes: Daily noon-3pm, 6-10pm; Sun noon-3pm, 4-10pm; closed Tue.

content.description: This 60-year-old casual eatery is jam-packed with plastic tables, the walls are peeling and the detritus left behind by enthusiastic diners on curry-stained bowls may offer nothing more than a sordid sight. But this still does not detract from the lush and homey Malay fare on offer. Standout dishes include the wickedly dense and extravagantly spiced beef rendang; the light but no less spicy tamarind-laced ikan penggang in black sweet sauce with a fresh toss of onions and chillis; the mild-on-heat but rich-in-flavour ayam bakar; and the crisp, moist and onion-streaked fried omelette. Dont miss their house soup, a savoury beef consommé with caramelised shallots and chunks of potatoes and carrots. Costs: Main courses $5
Zhenghua Park is linked to the Western Adventure Park Connector Network by Bukit Panjang and Pang Sua Park Connectors.

Hilltop The Gym focuses on kicking your butt into shape (literally) with muay thai training. Its courses vary in focus and intensity to suit both professional athletes and exercisers just wanting a new, kickin fitness class. They're all instructed and supervised by professional muay thai fighters-cum-personal trainers.
content.public-transport: Near station: Clark Quay & Chinatown | Buses: 53, 143, 174, 186 & 608
content.openingtimes: Mon, Tue & Thu, 10am-10pm; Wed & Fri, 7am-10pm; Sat, 10am-8pm; Sun, 10am-6pm

entry.name: Baan Nak Muay (BNM) Muay Thai Gym

version.name: Baan Nak Muay (BNM) Muay Thai Gym

content.description: Baan Nak Muay (BNM) gym is kicking open its doors to train the arts of muay thai, a rhythmic, traditional martial art from Thailand. It's unique because, unlike other combat sports, it uses all nine points of contact: fists, elbows, knees, feet and head. The gym features a full range of equipment, experienced trainers and workshops for all levels (even kids) to make muay thai suitable 'for everybody'.

Your body is a temple, but sometimes that temple needs a little janitorial maintenance. Body with Soul a sanctuary of wellbeing is opening its doors for just that health services that emphasise a holistic approach to get your body back into tip-top temple shape. Located in the new, posh Rochester Park @ one-north area, the healing facility feels more like a spa than a doctors office its services include consultations with general practitioners, counsellors, physiotherapists and speech therapists, among others. But here health in the whole isnt limited to appointments with a medical degree; it also includes exercise and nutrition. Choose from yoga, pilates, a nutritional café or getting your hands dirty in holistic gardening classes.

This new kid on the block is marketed as a shabu shabu hotspot, but dont be surprised to find the works on the menu sashimi, sushi, kushiyaki. Despite the hefty price tag (beef sukiyaki set dinner starts from $60++ and an order of kaisen nabe, seafood and vegetables mixed in a broth, will set you back $50++), Honjin was almost filled to the brim on the Friday night we dined. Yes, the service could do with a polish and the decor may appear worn, but aficionados of Japanese cuisine know to head to this spot when the craving for hotpot with marbled Wagyu beef hits. And did we mention that kids receive complimentary Häagen-Dazs ice cream to end the meal?

Singapores love of Italian fare has proved a double-edged sword. While there are many options to choose from, finding a good one without a $$$$ price tag remains a challenge. Enter Donna Carmela, a neighbourhood eatery that is turning heads and whetting appetites. Run by the same Sicilian family who opened Mamma Lucia, the pasta menu is the size of a novella, and you will need a few visits to do it justice. Hard to resist are the parcels of ravioli, dressed a myriad of ways, and wine from the familys own vineyards in Verona and Sicily, passionately extolled by manager Simone. For favoloso fare that fills the belly but doesnt drain the wallet, try dinner at Donnas.   Costs: Main courses $15-$25

The Action Theatre is housed within a pre-war two-storey bungalow house consisting of:
One intimate 100-seat studio theatre Two outdoor performance spaces One classroom One book & CD shop

This tiny jewel box of a store is filled with precious gems of chocolate in flavours such as banana split, orange lemongrass, vodka orange and white rose. Owner Brendan Chin not only imports the finest chocolates from Switzerland, he makes several of his own. A box of chocolate gold will cost you $17 for 100g (eight to 12 pieces).

The durian puffs here are famous island-wide spongy golden cake surrounding generous portions of creamy puréed durian that doesnt shy away from delivering full-force flavour. Youll pay only $11 for a box of 20.

Linger over café tables flanked by clear Lucite chairs and jazzy, loungy sounds that slink out of the speakers, and pick from an impressive variety of cheesecakes, verrines (desserts served in a glass) and individually sized dome cakes. Approx. S$3 13 per pax

This is the source of magical-tasting cookies, mooncakes and pineapple tarts. The shop has a generous tasting policy so you can sample the rich, buttery cookies that literally melt in your mouth, or buy sample packs for $2.50 (full boxes run between $14 and $27).

Coffee lovers can experience coffee in the form of quality coffee education, freshly-roasted coffee beans, and coffee machines or accessories to make that perfect cup of java. If you're just too lazy, then grab a cuppa of coffee at their coffee bar.
Highlander Coffee barristers

Here's what you'll get at Orchard Central:
Cluster-concept shopping divvied up into unimaginatively named sections like The Runway and Indulge, just so you can zone in directly on what seduces you most whether it is youth-appeal street cult labels, or extravagant, eye-popping timepieces and jewellery along the 140m Discovery Walk that links the mall to Somerset MRT station Whats a wall for, if not for climbing? Orchard Central boasts Singapores first indoor, five-storey rock-climbing wall The Med at basement 2, a complete level that showcases all things Mediterranean-themed, from sharp apparel to spicy slices of pepperoni pizza. Charming Italian men not included Speed is of the essence when it comes to snagging best buys. Thats why theyve installed three superescalators and six express lifts moving between 500 and 2,000ft/min not that youll notice thanks to the cabin pressure. Still, it does bring shoppers to their floor of choice in double-quick time. And with 12 floors to peruse, swooshing devices like these really help bring in the shopping haul.

Suburban Spanish fare is something youd expect to find in the back streets of Barcelona, not a shophouse bordering Bukit Batok. But in just nine months, Don Quijote has become the casa of choice for lovers of Spains lip-smacking food and wine. The blink-and-youll-miss-it establishment off Jalan Jurong Kechil boasts a bountiful array of delicioso classics, like the sizzling seafood paella Valenciana with its rice in a pan, pinchos morunos (beef on the spit), rollitos de espárragos y beicon (asparagus and bacon rolls) and the pastel de chocolate caliente (hot chocolate cake). Complement it all with a glass or three of sangria and youll be rolling your rs before the bill arrives.

Update: Don Quijote has expanded with a branch in Dempsey Village.
content.openingtimes:
Lorong Kilat Tue-Sun 5-11pm; brunch on Sundays
Dempsey Mon-Thu 6-10.30pm; Fri-Sun 11.30am-2.30pm, 6-10.30pm

content.description: If youre cutting back on eating out but need something delicious to munch, La Noce (The Walnut) is just what youre looking for. Set amid a housing estate in Hillview between two Bukits (Timah and Gombak), this off-the-beatentrack boutique eatery serves up home-style Italian favourites with a Sicilian flair. After running busy kitchens both here and abroad, chef/owner Salvatore Catalano adds the personal touch to his flavoursome, albeit small selection of dishes: savour the home-made gnocchi in walnut cream sauce, and the aptly named Salvatore pizza with artichokes and zesty buffalo mozzarella layered on a perfectly crispy crust. With its quaint, personable feel, and a seating capacity of just 40, La Noce is ideal for a catch-up with friends or a quiet romantic twosome.

One of Singapores brightest boutique hotels enters the ever-crowded brunch fold with a brand new buffet menu Re!Plenish available at weekends from 11am-3pm at weekends. At $38++ per person, it's distinctly more accessible than most other hotel brunches around, but still manages to pack in a wide-ranging selection of pan-continental specialities with fresh sashimi, vegetable and prawn tempura, baked scallops, topshell abalone (one serving per person) and chilli clams taking care of fish lovers' yearnings, while carnivores can try the beef medallion or lamb shank in a red-wine reduction and olive oil.

On a recent stay at Hotel Re!, we loved their breakfast desserts and thankfully there are plenty of sweet delicacies to choose from. Alternatively, theres household favourite Ben & Jerrys on offer. Food is taken in their giant new ballroom called Re!Joice, as per the theme so theres enough room to bring the little uns too.

Adults $38++, children $18.80++.
Long-established camera store. A favourite amongst professional photographers.
El Barrio was featured in Convival Pursuit: Wild West Pubs.
Beaver's The American Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu noon-1am; Fri noon-2am; Sat noon-1am; Sun 5pm-midnight.

content.description: O-Bar & Restaurantwas featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.

Enviro-minded eaters should get moving to this new vegetarian restaurant that uses foodstuffs free of pesticides and chemicals, sourced from Australia, Thailand and the US, and served in a space furnished with recycled materials. We recommend the healthy, greens-filled Sichuan sour spicy noodles.

Main courses $6.50-$9.

It takes a special kind of bravado to successfully decorate a restaurant like Myras Beach Club. As you prop your sandy self up at their spacious bar and survey Myras interior, the odd mix of the small live-music stage decorated with a bullfighting poster, surfboard adorned with flashing fairy lights and zombie-shooting arcade game will have you wondering what misguided delights await you on their menu. Somehow, the eclectic decor works well and the food does not disappoint. The quesadillas are moist without being greasy, and livened up with mixed cheese, jalapeños and fresh cilantro. The burritos offer a more hearty feed, though the beef variety tastes a little low-grade in quality. Mexican natives may get a little hot under the poncho with the absence of guacamole as a side, but on the whole, Myras whips up an impressively authentic menu.

Indonesian chef Gunawan Wibisono, a former protégé of American Iron Chef Morimoto Masaharu, has attempted to create another one of those modern Japanese restaurants with never-seen-before dishes at Dempsey Hills Zento. His creative efforts have not, unlike many rival eateries, been put completely to shame. Any waiter who starts off your meal with a free cup of sake is okay in my books. This turned out to be a smart move on his part, as my good first impressions gradually decreased throughout the night. First off, when ordering the carpaccio topped with ginger garlic yozu sauce, he enquired whether we would like that served with yellowtail or Wagyu beef conveniently failing to mention that the Wagyu choice would double the price listed on the menu. It was a good thing that the razor-thin slices of meat, drizzled with hot grapeseed oil used to sear the top, turned out to be a favourite dish of both myself and my companion; it helped, too, that we were not aware of the add-on at the time. In addition, all the waiters had a habit of hovering like vultures, and while my dining partner was lucky to be facing the wall, I was eating nervously, feeling that the second I put down my chopsticks, my dish would be scooped up before I could savour the last remaining bites. Having said that, we appreciated the over-attentiveness when, upon arriving on a rainy afternoon for our second visit, an umbrella-equipped waiter ran outside to the taxi to provide cover for the walk to the restaurant. Service aside, lets get back to the food. The innovative Wagyu Beef Roll is stuffed with shrimp tempura and topped with thin slices of gruyèredrizzled beef, and Im delighted to say that it was not just the cheese but the entire roll which melted in my mouth. With sushi, its never bad to go the old-school route (read: 40 years after the inception of the California roll, this seems like a fair classification) to see how some of the more traditional rolls compare. This proved to be a wise decision when it came to the Volcano Roll, whose copious lashings of spicy mayo were perfectly cut with sweet eel sauce. During our second visit, we decided to go with a standard lunch sushi set ($35) this one being served straight up, no frills attached. With no sauces or surprise ingredients left to mask the quality of the fish, our eight-nigiri, five-sushi selection did not match up to the high standard set by the more imaginative rolls. Standing on its own, the rice lacked that sticky sweetness needed when creating a bed for the fish. The thick cuts of average fish were also not helping matters. It seems as though its best for chef Wibisono to keep thinking outside the box, since the final result is much more enjoyable to unpack. Its probably best to skip on dessert; the undistinguished green-tea crème brûlée presented a curdled centre and the chocolate lava cake while delicious was not anything new. And its just as well: the bill adds up quickly without, and after discovering how our carpaccio had mischievously doubled in price, we were eager to head out of the door. Costs: Lunch sets $18-$65; dinner sets $58-$120.
