content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 3-6pm; Sun-Sat noon-3pm; Sun-Thu 6-10pm; Fri & Sat 6-11pm.

content.description: Comfortable, cosy place with live music. Drink promotions include happy hour from 7-10pm: 50% per cent discount on liquors such as Absolute, Barcadi and Jack Daniels, and one-for-one on all beers. Live music lineup: Wynne Sandosham (Mon-Thu 9pm-12.30am) Soul Circle (Fri & Sat 9.30pm-1.30am)
Serves American Southwest cuisine in an colonial-style, black and white bungalow with a tropical garden to boot.

Patrons stake out this brightly-coloured shop for its ever-changing roster of gelato flavours. With a rotating cast of 24 to choose from, top favourites include durian, frutti di bosco (a mixture of three berries), bacio (nuts and chocolate) and passionfruit. If youre hungry for more than a scoop (from $3.30 per scoop to $9.80 for a palette of six), take home a tub of 500g ($12.90) or go all out with the one kilo pack ($23.90).

Every neighbourhood needs a local, and Maple Pub has been filling this niche for some time now. It attracts a regular crowd of thirty-somethings who chow down on yakitori sticks, washing it all back with mugs of ice-cold beer. On Tuesdays and Saturdays, free snacks such as chicken wings and fishcakes are served, while Wednesdays and Saturdays see special beer promotions pushed during the happy hour period (4-9pm). Tapping into Singapores love for anything free, the pub also holds a regular lucky draw. For every $100 spent, patrons can win booze goodies ranging from a mug of beer to a bottle of Martell.

Contrary to its name, this little cocktail bar is overflowing neither with people nor with staff. Tucked away on an odd little side street in the depths of Robertson Walk, Flows dark exterior and tinted windows would actually make for a perfect brothel. Open the large glass doors, and youll find that the interior makes the same impression. But this little dark bar is a hidden gem, and were quite reticent to share it, because here youll find a drinkers dream come true. The menu offers lists of whiskies, scotches, gins and cocktails as long as your arm, and its bar staff know what theyre doing. The Long Island iced tea lives up to its name it is long indeed and incredibly strong. Hurrah! And the dry martini deserves a medal as well. Please promise that you wont run around town spreading the word.

What do you get when you cross tom yum soup with a German lager? Tawandang Microbrewery. Yet another
addition to the perennially hip enclave of Dempsey Hill, this Thai-owned restaurant offers an unusual pairing. Three signature German beers are brewed on-site and can be paired with dishes like flaming tom yum goong with river prawns, and papaya salad with salted crab. Those looking to follow a more traditional route can opt for melt-inyour- mouth deep-fried pork knuckle and sausages, topped up with sauerkraut. From Tuesday through Saturday the cavernous restaurant reverberates with the innately nasal but endearing sounds of an authentic Thai band, delivering local ballads and English covers. While its sheer size makes it hard to attract waiting staff, Tawandang has the type of atmosphere you cannot beer to pass up. Main course $10-$25

Nestled in the back of the Tanjong Pagar Plaza HDB, this tiny takeaway bakery is a gem among the local dry cleaners and coffee shops. A single fluffy muffin is enough for breakfast on the go, but with flavours ranging from cheese to double chocolate to blueberry, youll be hard pressed to choose just one. Other sweet treats include chocolate walnut brownies and a hearty strawberry cheesecake. The peach ground almond fruit flan is a standout, a crisp pie crust full of fruit and a moist, tart-like filling thats most definitely not your typical gelatinous custard from a can. Take care not to arrive too late in the afternoon, as once they run out of freshly baked goods, they close up shop for the day.Muffins and desserts: $1.10-$3.50, whole cakes: $16-$30
content.openingtimes: Tue-Fri 8.30am-6pm (or while stock lasts); Sat 8.30am-3pm (or while stock lasts).

content.description: Adding her skills to Singapores crowded bridal designer market is Anja Landgraf, a German-born, locally based fashion designer. Similar to others in the market, her prices start from $3,500 for a simple silk gown to $6,000 for a more elaborate outfit. If youre looking for a gown, her nifty fingers can also stitch up elegant evening ensembles check out her ready-to-wear label glor.

The spectacular views of Marina Bay from the lofty heights of the Fullerton Hotel are only an added bonus to the excellent menu that chef Diego Martinelli has put together. The dishes provide rich flavours with a light, modern touch. The standout starters include steamed mussels in a tomato, chilli and caper sauce; spice-dusted goose liver with a fennel salad; and sea scallops with a crust of black olive and sun-dried tomatoes is an absolute delight. Tortellini stuffed with duck and mascarpone, and topped with a rosemary sauce, is a highlight among the main courses, as was the Wagyu beef tenderloin with creamed celeriac and porcini jus. The grand finale arrived in the form of a melting-heart chocolate and coconut fondant, as well as strawberries sautéed in balsamic vinegar.

Carved out of a Peranakan shophouse, Speakeasys seating capacity amounts to just four outdoor tables, but theres not the merest whiff of exclusivity that such minimal provision might suggest. As you saunter into the bar area, a roaring twenties soundtrack floats above chic panelling and glass-filled cabinets. Ask your friendly host to pour you a wine or beer, or mix you a Prohibition-era cocktail, and settle on a comfy bench next to a friendly tortoiseshell cat. Even the opening hours seem somehow cool: just four nights a week, with $8 cocktails on a Wednesday. Evocatively blending modern pizzazz with retro-chic yet not a mite pretentious, Speakeasy amounts to the ultimate date venue. Were almost loath to mention this tiny treasure; wed love it to remain bar-worlds best-kept secret.

This sprawling local eatery spanning three shophouses and a canalside patio area is fast becoming a one-stop-shop for connoisseurs of flavourful crab and everything else the sea has to offer. Delivered fast and fresh, Big Eater serves up crab cooked 14 ways, including house specialities with salted egg, black pepper and stewed with beehoon. This is complemented by eight styles of succulent king prawns, lobster and more than 20 other chefs musttries. Ice-cold jugs of beer are available and the staff is more than willing to help you net the best selections. Of course if you reach your quota, you can always da bao (takeaway) and tackle it again when the appetite allows. Shelling out close to 200 crabs daily on weekends, youd be wise to book your big catch ahead of time.
content.public-transport: Near station: Tanah Merah, take a taxi

content.description: Situated at the far north-east of Singapore, Compass Point has Metro, Best Denki, Cold Storage, Kopitiam Spectrum food court, Kiddy Palace and POPULAR Bookstore as its anchor tenants. The shopping centre is also Singapores first Learning Mall where you can glean nuggets of information while shopping.

Intune Music School (ITMS) was founded by established musicians for up-and-coming musical talent. Its education programme is in tune both musically and within the industry ITMS collaborates with recording studios, artist management and local venues to give students of all ages a shot at stardom or just personal enhancement.

Conveniently located, but confused as a frog in a sock, Deli-Vege provides a 7-Eleven atmosphere masquerading as urban chic. Sitting gingerly among your new surroundings, enjoy the murals on the wall that offer appetite-suppressing statements about animals pathetic bodies suffering electric shocks while their families are slaughtered. We couldnt help but feel that the decors message was preaching to the choir. While the menu offers a wide range, navigating the menus layout and grammar was an arduous task. The saving grace was in the food and delicious juices, both of which were fresh and reasonably priced. Sceptics can head straight to the black-pepper steak or impressively authentic mock prawns for a hit of guilt-free carcass, while the tempura got a thumbs-up from both judges and the animal kingdom. With better-sized portions than most and a waiter who arrives and departs from your table in eerie silence (okay, terrifying), well be back. Only beware of the spring rolls: they were the only thing left on our plates at the end of the meal.

Taking up residence at the old Bukit Timah Fire Station, this gastrobar has set alight a once sleepy part of the island. Making use of the quaint barracks, first built in the 50s, and bordering Bukit Timah Hill, the café/bar draws an eclectic blend of local and expat customers. While the mains dont break any new ground, the sizeable gourmet pizzas and ample selection of tapas, imported beers and cocktails are sure to arouse an appetite in most. Though the young, less experienced wait-staff has yet to find its feet, the Firestation is a decent locale to chow down with the gang before the night really begins to smoulder. Costs: Main courses $18-$30
Fun theatre space that focuses on kid-centric activities and drama.

Nestled in the back of the Tanjong Pagar Plaza HDB, this tiny takeaway bakery is a gem among the local dry cleaners and coffee shops. A single fluffy muffin is enough for breakfast on the go, but with flavours ranging from cheese to double chocolate to blueberry, youll be hard pressed to choose just one. Other sweet treats include chocolate walnut brownies and a hearty strawberry cheesecake. The peach ground-almond fruit flan is a standout, a crisp pie crust full of fruit and a moist, tart-like filling thats most definitely not your typical gelatinous custard from a can. Take care not to arrive too late in the afternoon, as once they run out of freshly baked goods, they close up shop for the day. Whole flans and cheesecakes have to be ordered at least two days in advance.   Costs: Muffins and desserts: $1.10-$3.50, whole cakes: $16-$30.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Fri 8.30am-6pm (or while stock lasts), Sat 8.30am-3pm (or while stock lasts).

content.description: The opening of the 120-seater Chinese Box gives residents of the uppity Bukit Timah enclave reasons to cheer, offering semi-refined Chinese fare in a restored black-and-white bungalow thats set deep in the bucolic confines of the NUS law campus (next to the Botanic Gardens). Points go to the restaurants heritage (it was opened by the folks behind Tanglin Roads The Magic of Chongqing Hot Pot and Suntec City Malls Chinese Feasts) and its bright orange and red interior. Though variety from the pan-Chinese menu may not raise many eyebrows, pick wisely, for certain star dishes call for repeat visits. We recommend the golden roast duck, silky smooth congee, trio egg and matrimony-vine in superior stock as well as wok hei-infused garlic fried rice and hor fun. Note that congee and noodles are only available at lunch.
Pricey resort food on Sentosa.  Main courses $27-$35

Forgive its location, wedged in the foyer of a boutique hotel and situated on a street full of karaoke bars. The food is fantastic, the wine list well priced, the service warm and attentive, and the ambience perfectly pleasant. The starter of Parma ham with spinach leaves and porcini mushrooms was a perfect example of the simple, rustic fare on offer at Saraceno; the beef carpaccio was similarly delicious with its clean, well-balanced flavours; and the beef cheek braised in red wine, the chef told us, takes him two days to cook now thats commitment. A dessert of chocolate fondant with vanilla ice cream made the perfect ending to the meal, with warm chocolate oozing from a surprisingly light sponge. Other touches such as complimentary olives, home-made breads with punchy olive oil and an after-dinner limoncello liqueur just added to the overall experience. Main courses $18-$38.
True Yoga offers more than 400 classes covering 35 different types of Yoga, Hot Yoga, Dance and Pilates classes each week.See their schedule here.

This exercise lab provides specialist workout programmes and testing to anyone who's interested in losing weight or performing better at their sport.   Costs: fatMELT: $250 Body composition: $100 Fuel efficiency: $250 Lactate: $275 VO2max: $250

The chef specialises in Shunde cuisine (a variation of Cantonese food). There's the usual shark's fin and steamed garoupa. Go for their braised fish maw soup with pumpkin sauce and fried lobster rolls.
Sells practical and fashionable clothing for breastfeeding mothers.

After taking a trip down memory lane at the Mint Museum of Toys, head up to the rooftop for martinis and beer a quick reminder of why its great to be an adult. While the view is largely obscured by the Swissôtel, its a pretty sight at night when the lights twinkle up and down the tower. This quiet hidey-hole of a bar is adorned with vintage enamel advertising signs, fans from the 1910s and 1930s, and a 1920s counter from a Remittance House along Middle Road turned into a bar. Youll get one-for-one deals on lychee martinis ($14) and wines ($12), three-for-two deals of gin and tonic ($8), and tequila shots ($8) before 8pm. Dissolve your inhibitions with the Mr Punch cocktail ($14) a sweet aquamarine mix with a Long Island Tea wallop. But were still wondering: wheres Judy, Mr Punch?
content.openingtimes:
Mon- Thu & PH 4pm-12am
Fri, Sat & eve of PH 4pm-2am

content.description: Housed in a renovated, barn-like building amid the embassies on Tanglin Road, you can sit indoors or on the outside deck with views of the treetops. Black Eames chairs complement the exposed timber floorboards, giving the space a warm, retro vibe. The well-priced menu covers the right bases and although the produce is good, the execution of most dishes is a little too safe, verging on dull. Strange anomalies abound, such as steak frites served with a béarnaise sauce in a shot glass a touch impractical, although the steak itself is delicious. Also, a Caesar salad is not a Caesar salad if its missing anchovies, no matter how tasty the poached egg and parmesan-coated cos lettuce; try the tastier spiced-lamb kofta salad instead.

In troubled economic times like these, value-for-money dining concepts go down especially well. Offering over 50 choices for Singapores global diner, there are safe options such as fragrant lemongrass pork, tender scallops with spiced butter and sticks of chicken stuffed with creamy ricotta. The more adventurous can pick and choose from succulent prawns with finger-licking good walnut pesto, grilled quail with five-spice powder (not recommended for game-meat virgins) and a surprisingly tasty Mongolian ostrich skewer. Those worried about consuming an all-protein meal can hit up the unlimited salad bar (add on $8), while the dessert bar (add on $6) will fulfil all your sugar cravings.

The ibis hotel on Bencoolen Street is Singapores first internationally branded economy hotel. The ibis boasts contemporary, stylish furnishings complete with Wi-Fi internet access and cable channels on flat-screen TVs. Located within the proximity of the Bugis, Orchard Road, and CBD areas, travellers can easily access the cultural, shopping, and business hubs of Singapore. Cost: Rooms start from $148++

Better suited to long-term guests, this serviced apartment was awarded the URA Architectural Heritage Award in 2002. Its filled with delightful Peranakan details like wooden floors, carved screens, furnishings and airy courtyards. Besides offering guests a slice of Straits Chinese culture, a quick walk round this neighbourhood, littered with convenience stores, pubs and dozens of small restaurants, gives an instant home-away-from-home feeling.   Cost: from $1,260 per week

Converted from a set of former stables, this tucked away spot just off Dunearn Road has a placid rural landscape. The two-storey lodge has 40 spacious rooms, a lawn for sun-tanning/picnicking purposes, Wi-Fi and conference rooms for companies looking to take their AGMs off-site. Pony rides for kids, horseback riding lessons and a nearby golf course make this a great weekend getaway. The shops arent too far off either; Turf City is just a quick gallop round the corner.

Its always been a little difficult to categorise Damian DSilvas cooking, especially now that hes moved into new coffee-shop digs. His babi assam tart with tamarind hits and cinnamon is melt-in-the-mouth heaven, the buah keluak is still black gold, while his new creation Chicken 56 is tender-grilled chook in a thick marinade of cardamom, galangal and cumin. Flip the menu and youll find perfectly seared slabs of kurobuta, ribeyes and a crabmeat linguine dense with al dente pasta, clumps of sweet crustacean and chilli its so good you wonder how a Eurasian learned to cook such good Italian.

Okonomiyaki is the Japanese answer to murtabaks, but so much prettier. The foundation is eggs, usually two to three per serving. Wafer-thin omelettes wrap around everything from prawns, pork, mochi rice and cheese to soba, clams and cabbage and sometimes all of those combined. Everything is cooked on sizzling skillets (the choreographed activity behind the glass-fronted kitchen is engrossing), doused with soy, sweet sauces or tomato paste, and then layered with a thick coating of striated mayonnaise before arriving at the table looking like a marzipan torte. Desserts include the gorgeous, marshmallowy greentea mochi and thick red-bean soup. Main courses $12.80-$13.80.

content.public-transport: Near station: Outram Park, Tanjong Pagar

content.description: Dont worry this isnt some seedy pick-up joint. My Type simply serves food specially made for people under each specific blood group. The jury may be out on the medical front, but it still makes for an interesting meal. Besides, the menu is free of processed or GMO ingredients, or trans fat. The O meal includes a generously portioned row of sweet ocean trout sashimi on a thicket of rocket, a moist brick of grilled sea bass and a yummy blueberry smoothie. The A meal, on the other hand, includes snowy scallop discs, roast chicken and jasmine tea jelly. Main courses $26-$38.

Another month, another Harry's. The Sail @ Marina Bay is the chain's 27th outlet across the island, hoping to cater to the business crowd working nearby with added bonuses such as free Wi-Fi and Bluetooth and a 'gastronomic food menu'.
content.openingtimes: Mon - Thurs 11am - 1am; Fri, Sat, Sun and Eve of PH 11am - 2am

content.description: Swanky hair salon Next has just opened its newest venue downtown at McCallum street meaning that you don't have to make the trek to Holland Village anymore.

This mid-priced local street label is hot in both the fashion and club scenes. Several DJs are walking models for the brand, as are a few local party animals. Occasional collaborations with American graffiti artists, such as the San Francisco-based Sam Flores, gives Flesh Imp added street cred.
'Temple of Thanksgiving' is Singapore's first ecologically green temple, rebuilt in 2003.

Making the best of a bad situation, Chia Sek Hoong closed up his unprofitable chicken farm on Clementi Road and, with a secret recipe acquired from a famous Chinese opera singer, launched a restaurant in its place in 1962. Nearly 50 years on, the Chias are still pulling in punters wanting to savour their renowned zi bao ji a chicken dish that was once served wrapped in newspaper. These small parcels of steamed chicken, rice wine, ginger and undisclosed secret herbs and sauces have intoxicated many a food reviewer over the years (their articles line the eaterys walls), and continue to do so now. The tender morsels wrapped in old newspaper come in batches of six, to a towering 60. Other local temptations include the crispy home-made cuttlefish balls and ginsenginfused chicken soup.

Photo: Negima Salmon Yakitori

Just as nobody ever sets out to make a bad movie, I like to think that nobody sets out to open a dull restaurant. But there are moments like a recent lunch at Charly Ts when you have to question some peoples judgment.

The restaurants logo is Food Journeys, which roughly translates to food from around the world. This results in a confusing rojak of choices ranging from roast chicken (a pile of which was just sitting around unattractively at room temperature in a big tray at the back of the kitchen), kebab and Spanish omelettes to chicken soup and basil pesto.

The latters culinary tautology is a dead giveaway that you shouldnt be expecting too much from Charly Ts. Though some effort had been made in tarting up the interiors the giant Iznik tiles on the ceiling were a nice touch no one would ever mistake this place for anything other than what it is: a no-fuss refuelling stop with enough variety to keep the teens, office set and movie crowd from next doors Cathay cinema happy.

But if you want finesse, keep walking past.

The salmon yakitori was a surprisingly juicy slab, perfectly seasoned and cooked, but it was accompanied by a messy serving of garlic-flavoured fried rice. Mazatlan grilled prawns looked interesting enough on the plate, but you battled to taste the Mexican connection especially in the mushy, overcooked texture.

It was difficult, too, to place the chicken soup with its undersalted stock and undercooked chunks of carrots and pumpkin. No country of origin sprang to mind, although it did bring back vague memories of a home economics class.

While the steak kebab was tender, juicy and strangely flavourless, the accompanying roast baby potatoes were first rate both in taste and texture but who orders a main dish for its sides?

As for sweets, everything from the lonely pair of chocolate muffins to what looked like a cheesecake was clingwrapped behind the glass counter. They looked neither fresh nor appetising. We ended up skipping dessert, which, for restaurant reviewers, is almost a no-no since were meant to try everything. But after that meal around the world, I just wanted off that culinary plane. Daven Wu
Approx. S$58 68 per pax

Authentic Thai food in a pristine white, modern setting.

Approx. S$20 30 per pax

Any Europhile tired of faltering takes on Western hospitality will find their pot of gold here: a speciality restaurant and alfresco bar co-managed by a Sicilian and a Neapolitan. If you think the seafood menus impressive, wait till you see the cocktail list. The 41 choices seemed daunting, but we got diligently to work on this tough journalistic assignment, uncovering a host of deceptively strong doozies in varying shades of pink. Sailors dont do a happy hour, but happy day thats the kind of bar we frequent. At the milder end, the margarita felt a tad mixer-like; the Cranberry Cooler resembles an experiment with bubble bath, and tastes less like amaretto than kids cough medicine. Speaking of cranberries, the rum-laden Zombie has a lovely lemony aftertaste; but if youre after a real quick fix, sip on a near-perfect Long Island iced tea, or the Boston Beach Party: a gin-, Cointreau-, vodka and rum-enhanced humdinger that unsurprisingly packs a major punch. Theyre all sweet, sometimes cloyingly so, but you wont need to stay long before you find your tongue loosening: in fact only our innate sense of modesty prevented us from requesting a Quick Screw. The wait-staff are an accommodating bunch, and attentive almost to a fault. Downers? Were not all Toto and James Blunt fans, thanks and is it really necessary to broadcast footie on TV at every riverside bar? But you wont get a more congenial setting than this and considering the swanky hood, the drinks price tags are as generous as their alcohol content. Jonathan Evans  Cocktails $7-$12; house wine by the glass $7.

Here youll spy some truly esoteric French cognac hidden among a wide range of non-alcoholic drinks. This spots worth a peek just for the completely random juxtaposition of liquor with hawker facilities. Kopi with your whiskey, sir?

This was the fi rst shop of its kind on Serangoon Road, and has the biggest range of drinkables and medicinal spirits around. The bottle-stocked façade of this liquor/medicinal shop may spark some curiosity and lure you in, but beware of the less than warm welcome youre likely to receive as well as what appears to be a no-fi xed-price policy.

Overlooking the green sanctuary of the Botanic Gardens from the top floor of a restored bungalow, the latest addition to the chain plays the sophisticated older sister to its more casual counterpart on Orchard Road.

Black Angus succulent cuts of meat and refined service take Singapores steakhouses to a whole new level, adding up to an experience worthy of its idyllic setting.

Sink your teeth into the complimentary peppery steak soup a meal in itself before tucking into the slow-roasted beef ribs or the 300g tenderfoot filet mignon seared over an open flame. With the only grouse being a hefty bill at the end, you may want to save your visit for special occasions of a refined carnivorous nature. Marc Checkley

HDB estates are the last place youd expect to find a decent pizzeria. But below a block of flats off Farrer Road, Indian chef Sunda prepares more than 150 traditional pizzas on his own every weekend, and knows the 30 varieties like the back of his floury hand.

With not a shred of Italiano in him, Sunda only discovered his inner crust after taking a culinary sabbatical in Sicily. You wont find Hawaiian or meat lovers cooking in this oven; instead there are signature specialities like the Grosseto, with crispy bacon, porcini mushrooms and tomatoes drizzled in the warm yolk of a poached egg.

Equally inspired is the Perugia, with eggplant, zucchini, artichokes, sundried tomatoes and capers. The crusts are thin and crispy, and generously embellished with fresh toppings. Those dining in can bring their own wine; corkage is not charged. Marc Checkley

What can $6 buy you these days? At Lams Abalone Noodles (also affectionately called Ah Lam), it buys you a bowl of bak chor mee-style noodles served with minced pork, crunchy bits of deep-fried pork lard, pungent slabs of pork liver and a sliver of fragrant grilled tee po (dried flat fish) topped with braised and skewered abalone cubes.

For $8, you get a robust helping of herbed-up abalone broth double-boiled in a vast, glazed ceramic cauldron. When it comes to affordable abalone for the masses, Ah Lam is an institution. A word of warning: its located in a narrow kopitiam at a busy intersection, so dust and car fumes come as standard when dining here. Eve C

Its usually a good sign if the house wine listed is not Jacobs Creek, has a lively bouquet and is affordably priced: of Mags three house whites, St Claire is a refreshing New Zealand sauvignon blanc ($13/glass) with wafts of grapefruit and lemon a worthy representative for its worldly cellar of over 200 labels. Also notable is its evenly cooked main of ovenroasted lamb, served with a buttery, cheesetopped potato gratin. The starter of duck breast, smoked with tea leaves and coffee, is too small a portion to be entirely comforting, but the flavour was spot-on. The chocolate fondant cake is more like fudge wrapped in a crêpe fine for those ready to indulge in whatever oozes. Two-course set lunch $38++; dinner $48++.

While Pasta Incs affordable prices shouldnt go unnoticed, its the Little India location that caught our attention. Located in a shophouse along Jalan Besar, this Italian hideaways cosy booths are covered with white tablecloths, and the restaurant glows under the understated light of a chandelier. Lightly battered and thinly sliced, the Veal Scaloppine di Vitello is pan-fried with butter-sage and topped with Parma ham, all resting underneath a blanket of melted mozzarella. The classic fettuccine alla carbonara brings nothing new to the table, but the chopped pieces of bacon and onion and the creamy white wine sauce do not disappoint. Best part? The meal can be finished off with a mango lassi from down the street. Main courses $16-$28.

Heritage recently moved from its road-front location off Sixth Avenue to a dimly lit, black-and-white dining chamber in the touristy Copthorne Orchid hotel. While the suburban location may not appeal to the hip dinner crowd, the North Indian cuisine is first rate. The chicken makhani, boneless tandoori-baked chicken, is served in a dense tomato- and spice-accented sauce; and a rarely seen crab biryani, fluffy grains of basmati rice tossed with vegetables and crab pieces and served with a side condiment of raita (yoghurt dip) both grace the menus pages. Vegetarians can indulge in the simple yet profoundly flavoursome lentils in cumin seed-flecked thick gravy, or the refreshing chopped and spinach-coated paneer chunks. With the lure of generous servings, wallet-friendly price tag, graceful staff and a solid kitchen, it wont be long before discerning foodies sniff their way to our favourite North Indian restaurant of the moment.

To sin or not to sin? Eileen Tay and her devilishly delicious, sugar-filled creations, crafted in an out-of-sight pâtisserie off Holland Road, provide the answer. Essentially a café attached to her culinary workshop, you can watch the trained artisan at work, while downing a mug of hot Illy coffee and sampling the freshly made goodies. Youll be besotted by the delicately moist cupcakes ($3.50), like Lamour Rose, Rocky Mountain and the name-says-it-all Chocolate Overload. For seconds, try the almond croissants, morsel-sized cream puffs or zesty cheese scones. Transgressions dont end there; the French macarons ($2 each) in avant-garde flavours like lemon raspberry, passion jivara and oozing molten salty caramel will require a confessional or two.

A café in Balestiers hostel-central is an appropriate choice for students, especially when the establishment offers cups of strong Italian coffee (from $3.20). A fluffy foccaccia sandwich with plump home-made meatballs and a tropical fruit tea (made with bagged black tea, a tinge of passion-fruit syrup and very little sugar, $4.20) would do wonders for those under-nourished pupils. Caution: those looking to avoid the freshman 15 should pass on the greasy pub fare pre-battered fish and chips, deep-fried chicken wings and spongy thin-crust pizzas spell L-A-ZY although well admit, sometimes these are all you crave when cramming for that big exam. Main courses $8.90-$12.90.

The pool table, game machine and $5 beers attract a young crowd, but football fanatics of all ages will appreciate that Premier League games are being projected straight onto the wall and budget boozers with a soft spot for old-school hip hop will be happy with the tracks. Cement floor, retro stools and low leather couches provide a chill atmosphere, and while the flow may not quite be free, its damn cheap. Drink $5 draft beer.

Braving the residential enclave on Stevens Road, Al Borgo opened its doors last year in a vacated petrol station. Here, the former chefs of Borgo and Pasta Fresca namely Mimmo Lamura and Domenico Truglia are dishing out regional Italian comfort food from a modest kitchen framed by peep windows. During our visit this neighbourhood trattoria was full of walk-in diners drawn in by curiosity. Rustic flavours that warmed our hearts included the spaghetti in a rich tomato base flanked by clams, mussels and shrimps, served piping hot in parchment paper; Contadina pizza crowned with four cheeses, salami, mushrooms, peperoni and red capsicum; and a lamb stew doused in a red wine-laced crimson tomato sauce.

Teochew eateries are a dime and a dozen in the Lion City but Ah Orh remains one that we will revisit at the drop of a hat. Its allure cant be attributed to the far-flung location on the ground floor of an HDB flat at Jalan Bukit Merah, although we admit that there is a certain charm to its vibrant receptioncum- kitchen decked out with canned food. The roaring wok churns out recipes that have been passed down over the years from its first anchor at Hong Lim Green in the 1950s, to its current venue in the heartlands. The ba bao cai (eight treasure vegetables), a mound of melt-in-the-mouth white cabbages and black moss bathing in a savoury brown broth, is a must, as is the oil-fluffed oyster omelette topped with generous morsels of the mollusc. Meanwhile the mussels tossed in a wok, with sprigs of Chinese celery and curry leaves in a piquant paste, are out of this world.

25-year-old Deyana Goh opened her 'shop' in March 2010, proudly selling hard-to-find books that she gets from suppliers overseas and her travel hunts. Ms. Goh sells from her living room, by appointment only.

Read our story on Gohd Books here.

content.vendor-category: Well & Good | Deals of the month

content.description: If a sundowner on Sentosas Tanjong Beach is what youre after, and youre cool with cocktails served up in plastic cups by a grungy and bare-chested (actually, scrap that, nearly nude) barman/DJ, then this is the spot for you. Lo & Beholds latest drinking hole, The Shack, is a timber-covered shipping container-turned-bar, with a covered pergola, one bench seat and a few old oil barrels for tables. The bar itself is simple and small. The venue is just temporary, holding the place while Lo & Behold builds Sentosas next big restaurant- cum-bar behind it, right on KM8s gravesite. If youre hungry, theres a packet of crisps or two to choose from, and dont forget to show up sporting flip-flops and swimmers. Come prepared with low expectations and youll be pleasantly surprised.
content.public-transport: Near station: HarbourFront, then Sentosa Express

content.description: Helios, Nanos and Chromos are not terms youd ever link with five-star-fare, but one formula that passes the litmus test is Infuzi, simmering away in the scientific environs of Biopolis. Serving modern European cuisine with a dash of something special, chef Freddie Lee and his team have been quietly perfecting their menu since the restaurants inception in 2004. The result is a collection of seasonal, handcrafted dishes that are a joy to behold as well as to indulge in. The pan-fried duck liver with a balsamic reduction, served with roasted pear, may no longer be on the menu and the Maine lobster pasta may be out of season, but the ever-changing menu is sure to replace it with something equally delicious. The wine selection flows freely from the cellar, befitting the restaurants European influences; you can also bring your own favourite vintages to the table (corkage applies).

Its a little lame to say, if you cant go to Bali, then bring Bali to you but hey, thats exactly what the owners of this quaint and idyllic restro-bar set out to do. Amidst the abundant shrubbery and willowy trees, there are rustic, Balinesestyle wooden pavilions with bale rooftops, which you can clamber into with friends, and pretend you are on an exotic getaway together. While the wait-staff are young and eager, they are also a little clueless at times, but when they finally bring the correct bottle of wine along with an impish grin, all is easily forgiven.

Dont be put off by the school-canteen vibe,or by the fact that the serving counter is so tiny. The nosh is excellent and incredibly good value. Unless youre Indian, the names of the dishes will probably mean nothing to you, but just about everything deserves a second helping including the sambal fish,a densely flavoured chicken curry, creamy dahl, and a wonderfully aromatic butter chicken. Wash it all down with masala teaor lime juice.
Golden Village Tampines has 8 screens and 3D Digital halls.

This is a multi-storey 344-seater theatre with digital audio and 2D/3D projection systems where movies are flashed onto a five-storey high screen. Most titles screen for several months. Please check the website for times and prices.

This Italian trattoria is already a hit with the neighbourhood set at Serangoon Garden. Chef-owner Salvatore Buono keeps things simple with well-executed dishes like carpaccio, portobello mushrooms in herbflecked cream, and linguine al cartoccio heavy loops of al dente pasta with fat mussels, baby langoustines and squid rings. Try the Buono, a slab of thin-crusted pizza that could feed two its base slathered with a light cream sauce and sprinkled with arugula and chunks of homemade sausages. Read our review of Buono here.

Though it is touted as the world’s first museum devoted to the rare Tibetan gemstone Dzi, the best part of this museum is its extensive section on the history and culture of Tibet, showcasing more than a thousand artefacts including giant prayer wheels, clay tablets, bronze amulets, paintings and sculptures. The museum’s shop is also worth a browse, for interesting Tibetan Buddhist historical relics, authentic Tibetan handicrafts and rough gemstones.

entry.name: Nei Xue Tang - A Buddhist Art Museum

version.name: Nei Xue Tang - A Buddhist Art Museum

content.description: Spread over three floors of a four-storey conservation building which is an attraction on its own right, Singapore’s first house museum is home to more than a thousand Buddhist artifacts from China, India, Tibet, Japan, Thailand, Cambodia and Afghanistan. Other exhibits include a wide selection of gold, silver, bronze, jade and crystal Buddhist amulets and talismans, as well as artworks by acclaimed Singapore artist Tan Swie Hian.
content.public-transport: Near station: Outram Park or Tanjong Pagar.

content.description: This gallery consists mainly of works by South Indian comtemporary artists.

The SG Private Banking gallery houses itself in the Alliance Française, regularly exhibiting a wide range of international art and collaborating with galleries overseas, including Lotus Gallery from Vietnam. Alternatively, join Singapore's Francophile cineastes for Ciné Club every Tuesday evening at 8pm for an ongoing series of French movies both old and new.

Clean white walls make an excellent blank canvas for the numerous ceramic vases, Zen-type lamps, plush cushions and artwork sold inside. And while the eclectic stock of items is sourced from Thailand, Vietnam and Europe, Haier Living’s uniquely shaped lamps and sofas are designed by a group of in-house designers who can make-to-order according to your needs

entry.name: Open space in front of People's Park Food Centre

version.name: Open space in front of People's Park Food Centre

content.description:
Boat Quay is popular with tourists and city-boys alike from the nearby banks and trading offices. Harry's branch here is very much a traditional pub on the ground floor with live bands on many nights. Upstairs is a much smarter lounge area. Happy hour from 11am to 9pm everyday. 
Crazy Hour (not applicable on public holidays) Mon - Fri 5-7pm.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thurs: 11am to 1am, Fri & Sat: 11am to 2am, Sun: 11am to 1am

content.description: A hidden gem of a live music venue behind The Substation. Timbre is open air, but covered, and features live music every night. Timbre have recently expanded to Timbre @ The Arts House opposite Boat Quay.

This watering hole is a hit with the boys for its double-shot drinks at no extra charge. Yes, double shots! Slow weekday nights see people chilling on the day beds in the (oddly) green-lit courtyard, while on weekends the joint is jam-packed, standingroom only. The dance tracks and kick-ass Long Island Teas are guaranteed to keep you happy and buzzing all night.

address.street: 2 Emerald Hill, Peranakan Place, 180 Orchard Rd
2 Emerald Hill, Peranakan Place, 180 Orchard Rd

content.description: Orchard Road is not normally known for its quality bars, barring those situated on the Emerald Hill stretch, a cluster of five watering holes and one club. Alley Bar is by far the classiest of the lot. Located in a restored shophouse, it has made a name for itself with an unpretentious vibe, tasty menu of bar grub try the dim sum dumplings and potent cocktails.
A bohostyle café-cum-lounge that sees guest DJ gigs by the likes of funk and soul collective PushinOn. Its quirky, vibrant and altogether not quite Singaporean.

entry.name: Why Not - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED

version.name: Why Not - THIS VENUE HAS CLOSED

content.description: Packed to the rafters on weekends with lithe and youthful Chinese boys, this M-pop club is filled with people dancing to the techno beats. Expect stares if you are anything but male and Oriental-looking. KTV nights on week days ensure only warbler wannabes show up.
content.openingtimes: KTV nights Mon-Thu 8pm-3am; Disco nights Fri 11pm-3am, Sat 11pm-4am.

content.description: Dance the night away at one of the most popular salsa bars without worrying about getting picked up or ogled. Run by NTUC Clubs (hence the value-for-money drinks), Mojito and Cuba Libre jugs are at $20 all night while a 5-litre tower of Tiger is $48. Latinos, a live band from Colombia, performs nightly. Tuesdays are beginners nights and ladies night happens on Fridays. Mon-Sat (before 9pm): free. Mon-Thu: non-members $8, members $6, includes one drink. Fri, Sat & holiday eve: non-members $15, members $10, includes two drinks. Union Square was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.
Known for its rotating nights of rock, punk and metal, Gashaus is launching a new DJ night as well, Heart of Darkness (Wednesdays). Gashaus was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Two parts bookshop, one part music store, this cosy hideout has every base covered when it comes to homegrown talent. Give music CDs by local artists like Electrico, Dick Lee and Tanya Chua a listen, or walk down memory lane while your fingers flip through the pages of books like Rickshaw Coolie: A Peoples History of Singapore (1880-1940) by James Francis Warren.

Its safe to say that when Sticky Rice opened, it raised the glamour quotient of the residential suburb of Serangoon Gardens. The Thai restaurant has been designed to within an inch of its life, complete with smoky mirrors and dramatic splashes of blood-red lacquered panels. The set lunches (under $10) are a bargain. On weekends, the place buzzes as the owners fashionista friends tuck into crispy soft-shelled crabs served with a thick shower of pomelo pearls and translucent chopped garlic, and sweet mango desserts. Sticky Rice was featured in our recent Comfort Food - Basic Instincts - Where to Eat feature.

This lovely little restaurant is alittle tricky to find, as its tucked behind the hawker stalls lining Smith Street, but its worth the hunt. Nepalese food in someways is similar to Indian (and the restaurant sells that cuisine as well), with pungent spices and flavourful rice. For vegetarians, the palungo kosaag is a knockout: spinach sautéed with cumin seeds ($6.50). Carnivorous types should try the pro kukhura ko masu, which is a Nepalese chilli chicken dish. Or go for the momo ($8), which looks like a Nepalese version of fried Chinese dumplings, filled with minced meat and veggies. Its listed as an appetiser, but one serving can really fill you up.

Opened by Werner Hochbaum in 1988, this favourite in the East is now run by the second generation of his German-Singaporean family. And though some of the dishes are just shy of $20, you can chow on delicious grilled bratwurst and potato salad for $8 – or go right for the good stuff: a range of German beers is just $7.95 for 330ml.

Wiener Kaffeehaus has recently relocated, see here for more details.

To enter this little shophouse is to step into another world lined with romantic Art Nouveau timber panelling, wall lamps, marble-topped tables and sparkling glints of Klimt artwork, its old Vienna come to life and transplanted to the tropics. The fiaker gulasch a large serving of tender beef cuts, fried egg, sausage and a huge bread dumpling is terrific. Or just come for the house-ground coffee, a slice of the dense, chocolately Sachertorte and daily newspapers from around the world.

The interior decoration, haloed with fluorescent light, is decidedly spartan and uninviting, but who cares, because the food here is fantastic. Peranakan owner and chef Helen Sugiano Sim hails from Indonesia and so her menu is overlaid with an additional layer of intense flavour. Everything from the buah keluak to the sambal kangkong and golden, coconut-infused chicken curry is worthy of multiple helpings. Watch out for the layered kueh lapis which is flown in from Sim’s aunt’s kitchen in Indonesia. It’s sinfully good.

At Quentin Pereiras eponymous new digs, the menu brims with luscious Eurasian dishes cooked according to recipes handed down by his late grandmother. Intense and distinct flavours mark every course without a hint of hesitancy in the assembly of spices and execution. The patchri halflogs of purple-skinned brinjal slathered in a deep mahogany paste of tamarind, sugar, onions and ginger melts in the mouth, as do the bostador prawns succulent, ruby-red crescents dressed in a sharp blend of turmeric, belachan and chilli.

entry.name: Brown Sugar Café - HAS MOVED LOCATION WATCH THIS SPACE

version.name: Brown Sugar Café - HAS MOVED LOCATION WATCH THIS SPACE

content.description: Bistro cafe of modern classics.

address.street: 55 Serangoon Garden Way, Stall 46 Serangoon Garden Market and Food Centre
55 Serangoon Garden Way, Stall 46 Serangoon Garden Market and Food Centre

content.description: It helps to know that this somewhat nondescript hawker stall is no longer at Newton Circus, but such is the cache of the name that it’s travelled all the way to its new digs in Serangoon Gardens. Diehard fans swear by the intense smokiness of the inky char kway teow, the fat strands silky with black sauce and studded with the sharp undertow of cockles.

The period bungalow could do with a little renovation the floorboards tremble as the waitresses pass and the lighting is dreadful but Hong Kongtrained owner and chef Ang Song Kangs nostalgic Cantonese fare is a treat. Any meal should include the silky tofu served in a sauce of dried scallops and shiitake mushrooms; an addictively crisp brinjal crowned with pork floss; and round discs of lotus root fried with black pepper. Portions come in the usual three options, but the smallest is enough to feed three to four comfortably. We hear the PMs wife has been spotted here.

A typically Singaporean level of customer attention awaits you at Kampong Glams contender, where you might find yourself greeted effusively by up to five wait-staff before getting to sup your frothy solace.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thu, public holidays 11am-11pm; Fri, Sat & eve of public holiday 11am-1am

entry.name: shots. a café on ann siang hill.

version.name: shots. a café on ann siang hill.

content.description: A photo gallery-cum-café offering with a location and staff that are beyond reproach. Sit down, linger, and enjoy the reading material comprising nothing but photographic magazines.
At this pan-Asian franchise your lovingly leaf-topped cappuccino gets served up in an angular, eminently photographable cup.
The well-intentioned, rather scatty service can frustrate, but your patience is rewarded by a cappuccino thats as rich, classy and immaculately presented as the local residents.
Though this is a select bean retailer first and tasting spot second, its owners has gone to some lengths to generate a seriously comfy ambience at Papa’s oddly located bolthole.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Fri 9am-7.30pm; Sat 9am-9pm; Sun, public holidays 9am-7.30pm. Closed for roasting on Mondays.

content.description:
Tucked away in the basement of the Screening Room, Malt Vault is a cosy new jazz bar thats home to over 150 different whiskies, some so exclusive you wont find them anywhere else. Our guide is engaging Scotch enthusiast Mike Soldner. There are other whisky-themed bars in Singapore, so whats special about the Malt Vault? We specialise in rare single-cask single-malt whiskies that arent available in most bars. In fact some of our whiskies are not available anywhere else in the world, as weve bought the cask from the distillery. Rather than offering instantly recognisable whiskies from the established distilleries across Scotland, we offer a unique opportunity to sample single malts in their purest form, straight from the barrel. You couldnt get any purer without sticking your head in the casket. Whats the difference between single-cask single malts and regular single malts?
Single-cask whisky is taken directly from the cask and kept at cask strength, whereas regular single-malt whiskies are watered down and filtered before bottling. The result is that single-cask whisky has its own singular taste and character. We offer single-cask whiskies here from some of the major distilleries like Macallan or Glenlivet that taste very different to their regular single malts. Youre the only man behind the bar. How do you explain the different whiskies to your customers? Since opening last year, Ive mainly concentrated on marketing to whisky enthusiasts, but Ive seen a growing number of customers who want to learn about the different whiskies on offer. For me its fantastic to introduce people to the different characters and tastes of the whiskies. I enjoy giving tasting tours of the whisky regions, from the rich Speysides [north-eastern Scotland] to the smoky Islays [Inner Hebrides]. I like the conversion process, its fun. Do you offer anything other than whisky at Malt Vault?
We have a selection of Scottish beers, including Belhaven Best on tap, but were not a normal bar. I do a few whisky cocktails, including a popular Highland Cream, but the emphasis is on enjoying whisky in its purest form. Mixing with ice is frowned upon and Coke forbidden! We also have live jazz on Friday and Saturday nights, and guests can order food from the excellent restaurant upstairs.

Australasian Arts Projects is a regionally focused arts production company newly established in Singapore to entertain, inform and educate the general public about art, artists and artistic practice from around the region.

Think authentic peri-peri (the Swahili name for chilli) chicken, and locals and foreigners alike will chorus Nandos Chicken for its distinct peri-peri marinade and tangy sauces that come in four spiciness levels, ranging from lemon & herb to extra-hot peri-peri. But look no further than Bugis Junction for the latest grilled chicken offering in town albeit one that has garnered a cult following the world over.

Once past the snaking lunch-/dinner-hour queues, diners enter a warm, dimly lit and cosy if rather cramped interior decorated with cockerel-themed artwork created by local artists.

Their signature Peri-Peri Flame grilled chicken ($13.90 for a quarter-chicken) certainly does not disappoint with its golden brown colour and succulent juicy texture sans fat, emanating the aromas of the grill and marinade to offer a tantalising dining experience.

Reflecting Nandos Portuguese heritage, the Cataplana ($18) is a unique dish consisting of a chicken thigh grilled in a choice of peri sauce and sautéed with sliced capsicum strips, courgettes, onions and ripe tomatoes, left to fuse atop a bed of spiced rice in an authentic clam-shell Cataplana dish for a special treat.

Other specialities include the chicken livers ($6.90) and the range of sidelines (from $3.25) like their crowd-pleasing peri chips. Nandos offers a great-value tasty chicken meal with resonances of its humble origins in a Johannesburg suburb. Now if only there was a tad more space in the restaurant. Jonathan Tan

Set in a bright white shophouse with Kermit-green accents, this self-styled gourmet bistro bar sports a welcoming decked courtyard with a grill sitting in the corner. Jolly Frog churns out free sausages, bacon and chicken on Fridays from 6pm to 8pm, which may just pique your thirst for a beer or two. Who needs peanuts when theres meat to be devoured? The small space was mostly full during our three visits, but the mood was decidedly low-key. People were perusing magazines or sitting with their laptops, while sipping a glass of wine or sampling items from the Australian- themed menu. The most coveted seats in the joint are the four wooden picnic-style tables on the deck. Inside, the narrow first-floor dining room is a pleasant place to sit as well. Displayed behind the long communal tables, chalkboards highlight recommended items on the menu such as their deliciously cheesy croque monsieur. We couldnt resist tasting another house speciality, the eponymous Jolly Frog cocktail made with Kahlúa, brown crème de cacao, vodka, frozen lime and fresh lime and this unusual combo made for a surprisingly refreshing tipple. The richness of the Kahlúa was cut with the limes freshness and the crunchy crushed ice. Besides the long list of cocktails, a decent selection of ciders (from Wychwood and Brothers) and reasonably priced wines round off the drink selection. During each visit, service was friendly but unpolished. Rounds of mixed drinks arrived at our table at a snails pace and one at a time, so my drink was nearly finished when my companions arrived; conversely, appetisers arrived all in one hit. None of these slip-ups was significant enough to detract from the appealingly chilled atmosphere, or the simple but enjoyable food and drink. Particularly fine bread and coffee ensure Jolly Frog is also a worthwhile brunch spot, good for soaking up the shenanigans of the night before. Try the aptly named Big Breakfast: eggs, sausages, bacon, grilled tomato, seriously delectable sautéed mushrooms and a pile of lightly dressed arugula come with thick slices of toast, scarred with grill marks. A purveyor of both the hangover and the cure, this Frog has just enough princely characteristics to keep us charmed. 81 Neil Rd (6222 9227, www.jollyfrog.com.sg). MRT: Tanjong Pagar. Main courses $9.90-$21.90; cocktails $12; house wine by the glass $12; beer $9.90 (30 per cent off from 5-8pm).

A chic ante-room for sweet-toothed night hawks, Holland Villages 2am:dessert bar offers sleek, modern desserts paired with a carefully selected wine list. Try the smoked white chocolate with hibiscus jelly and cinnamon beads, or the alpaco chilli chocolate. As per its name, it stays open until 2am.

The sweet and slightly sticky red char siu is what most queue for, but we were more impressed by the thin, translucent yellow noodles. Cooked so evenly that the springy strands separated out beautifully, the noodles sat on the plate simply in a tablespoon of broth that turned pink from the combination of chilli and generous slices of roast pork. Almost completely fat-free, the meat was a little dry, but its nectar-like marinade was worth the wait. On the side was a small bowl of the sweet, fresh broth with two soft, tiny salty dumplings. Celine Asril

INTERVIEW WITH THE HAWKER: Lee Meng Joo, 51
Mr Lee and his wife used to sell raw chickens, but the ongoing avian flu crisis caused them to switch profession. A customer suggested selling wanton noodles. What is the secret to the iight, refreshing tasty noodles?
I dip them into stock after theyve been cooked thats the only base I use for my noodles. Im one of the few left in Singapore who makes stock wanton mee. So the noodles soak up the stock?
Yes. Make sure you wait for three to four minutes before you start eating thats when the noodles have soaked up enough essence. Just enough time for me to walk to my table and order a quick drink.
Exactly! What about your famous roast char siu?
We make premium char siu. Its a high grade of roast pork. It is from an old recipe which has now become a rarity in Singapore char siu hawker circles. I doubt you can find it anywhere else. Like this? Try these...
Bai Lin Zha Wanton Mee House, #01-53 Sunshine Plaza, 91 Bencoolen St
Fei Fei Wanton Mee, 62 Joo Chiat Place, Sin Wah Coffeeshop (6345 7515)

This story first appeared in 'Step up to the plate' (TOS Apr 2010)
content.openingtimes: Sat-Thu 8.30am or until char siu is sold out
Tue-Fri 11am-830pm, Sat & Sun 11am-530pm, closed on Mon & public holidays

content.description: This store sells quirky souvenirs made in Singapore and was included in our 100 Best Shops feature in 2010.

content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat 12pm-8pm, Sun 12pm-5pm, Closed on public holidays

content.description: Still working to shake off zhi char stall looks, Seafood Kitchens food is already steps ahead. Non-spicy, Chinese herb-infused wu jia pi crab (approx $45 for four people) and Indonesian curry prawns cooked with slices of coconut ($24) are more reminiscent of hotel restaurant fare than hawker-style pickings. Until end of June 2010, 20 per cent discount for all bills.

Love molten chocolate cakes and mini things? Bite on these: 1.5-inch cakes (thats 3.8cm for us metric sticklers) that come in eight moreish flavours, from orange to peanut butter. You can, of course, opt for 3 Inch Sins regular 3-inch (7cm) versions. $5 for one regular or three mini cakes.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 12pm-9pm, Sat, Sun & public holidays 11am-10pm, closed on Tue

content.description:
Its always refreshing to stumble upon an independent restaurant in Singapore, so we had high hopes for this casual newcomer along Bukit Timahs main stretch. Unfortunately, the inconsistent food quality and poor service leave much to be desired.

Lukewarm seems to be the temperature of choice, and the dishes are marred by small-yet-significant imperfections the white-wine sauce served with the snails, ham and chorizo is flat, and the house paella is both drenched in olive oil and lacking in the spice department.

A slight redemption in the execution of this national dish can be found within special squid-ink paella. Moist and perfectly oiled, the rice creates a fluffy bed for the well-sized chunks of squid, along with a balanced combination of garlic, paprika and chilli.

Sadly, this is not enough to save the day, but in the interests of supporting small businesses and gastronomic independence, we sincerely hope the countless kinks will be ironed out. Charlene Fang

Tapas $4-$13.90; paella $30-$38.

The location Bonifacio has chosen to set up shop is somewhat surprising; the charming shophouse along Kreta Ayer Road is not a typical stomping ground for the Filipino community. However, it stays true to the roots of Filipino cuisine, serving up homey and tasty yet calorie-laden portions, albeit with a modern touch.

The KKK (ignore the disconcerting name, its nothing to do with men in white pointy hats) is a starter of four tiny parcels of deep-fried kangkong puffs crowned with Mexican-inspired mango and tomato salsa; the lush chicken binakol soup is served with chicken chunks, sliced coconut and strangely chye sim (flowering Chinese cabbage); hotplate-grilled boneless milkfish is topped with cubed onions and tomatoes.

The smart red and beige banquettes, dark wood laminate floors, friendly yet professional staff and menu of reasonably priced dishes all add up to a venue pitched at both locals and Pinoys. Eve C

The Tiong Bahru precinct is best known for the wet markets highly sought-after chwee kwee, and for its conserved Straits Settlements architecture. But Singapores oldest neighbourhood estate also has a sizeable crop of zhi char eateries if you know where to look.

One of them is Ting Heng Seafood Restaurant, along Tiong Poh Road, an airy, fluorescent-lit alfresco dining area. By virtue of its opening hours, Ting Heng tends to be a magnet for the night crowd.

The menu of sharply priced seafood and Chinese delicacies including Alaskan crabs, live lobsters, sharks fin and abalone also makes it a favoured venue for local towkays (Chinese bosses).

But a homey meal can still be had without breaking the bank if you order smartly: intensely flavoured wok-fried beef searing in a hotplate with thick slices of spring onions and ginger, stir-fried chye sim aromatically infused with garlic oil, and hor fun in a thick and robust gravy perfumed with seafood.

The pomfret fishhead steamboat would make for a nice addition if it werent for the ridiculously meagre fish slices, served in a large pot and costing $48. Eve C

First off, lets talk chips. The concept of this new mini-chain of chi chi, Scandinavian-style café-cum-restaurants should be obvious from its downhome name. All the mains, of which there are ten, come with two different cuts of fries in four promising-sounding flavours: curry, salt and vinegar, sour cream and onion, and garlic and herb. So whats the verdict? Disappointing. Fries are flavoured with that dry, synthetic shaker-style seasoning you can pick up in your average food store. The shoestring-cut sour cream and chive order arrived dusted with what looked and tasted like the sediment from the bottom of a tube of Pringles. The garlic and herb was suitably crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside, but had no discernible taste of garlic. Rather lamely, a roasted clove had been set among the chips, as if, like a strain of influenza, its flavour would be catching.

Anyone expecting freshly made dips, then and why wouldnt you anticipate a little fuss, given the tacit promise of the restaurants name? will be left cold. Our neighbour certainly was: Excuse me, he said optimistically to the waitress, youve forgotten my curry sauce. She clasped her hands together and gently shook her head, artfully steering our smiley malcontent back to the reality of a sauce-less, no-frills, really quite average side order. Any complaints you may expect to hear in a restaurant should not be with its staple. Oddly then, the chips are not this restaurants strongest suit. But while the list of main courses isnt without its quirks spaghetti bolognese and chips, anyone? theyre generally well executed, especially for the modest price tags. Char-grilled Karubi beef was the most ambitious, served perfectly tender and stringy in a light-brown barbecue sauce that didnt merge well with the dull coleslaw.

The lamb burger, however, was a hit; the gently spiced, moist patty topped with a tangy dollop of cream cheese, tomato relish and sautéed onions. All made in-house, the desserts have a retro French bent and prove a huge draw: hot banana and butterscotch pudding was sweet without being overly cloying and the mille crêpe, layers of French-style pancake, sandwiched a light, nutty chocolate cream that made a neat, not-too-heavy finale to the meal. The other major flaw is the playlist. Someones decided that the chic, minimalist interior, with its whitewashed walls and charming, Parisian bistro-style chairs, is not enough to pull the young, budget-conscious hip crowd. Deafening, R&B-infused club bangers quash any chance of our making use of the small library thats been set up at the back.

There was some respite with the comparatively soothing coo of Mariah Careys One Sweet Day, but as we left, one of the waiters bopped his head to the dance-floor stomp of Beyoncé and Lady Gagas Video Phone.

Have a happy fries day! goes the scripted goodbye. See you again! He will, because whatever flaws there are with the food, the super value for money and decent-enough roll call of comfort food make this a hard place not to like. Shame about the fries, though. Alexander Barlow
content.openingtimes:
Holland Village Sun, Tue-Thu noon-11pm; Fri & Sat noon-1am
Joo Chiat Road Tue-Sun noon-10pm

content.description:
Ed's note: Effective 1 Aug 2010, Next Door will change location to 699 East Coast Rd, S (459061).

Since opening in 2008, this unassuming café on Arab Street has quietly established itself as a popular hangout to down quality pints, and with over 50 varieties of beer on offer you can see why. Two outstanding examples are the caramel-like Asahi Black, a dark lager brewed from three roasting malts, and the wickedly good, oak-aged Green Goblin cider.

Complementing the assorted ales are finger foods, salads and mains with Mediterranean flair. The buffalo mozzarella salad and crispy wood-fired pizzas tempt your palate, while the tender chicken breast, delicately seared in a ginger orange sauce, raises the stakes. An organic date and walnut cake, sweet but not sickly, was another hit. With board games on hand and a pint never far away, Next Door may be your new local.

Petopia, a centre for holistic pet wellness, has opened. Much more than just a doggie daycare, this pet utopia tends to all furry care needs, from styling to alternative treatments and healing spa therapies. They even provide premium hotel facilities.

Babuyo goes a step further with natural furniture pieces and rare antiques from Central Java and Burma. Sourcing from small, family- owned companies, owner Marie Babuyo hand-selects her pieces to represent the rich and diverse Buddhist and Hindu cultures across the South-East Asian region.
content.public-transport: Near station: Chinatown or Tanjong Pagar

content.description: Singapore is now home to this leading Taiwanese high-street brands first overseas flagship store. The label will debut at Marina Bay Sands with three collections (right) City, Casual and Party and will be replenishing its stock every week.

Billing itself as a spor ts-cum-beer bar, the Timbre group has opened this alfresco nightspot in a plum spot between two boutique boltholes the swanky new Studio M Hotel and the longer-established Gallery Hotel. There are dozens of beers available including a range by Archipelago. Well have to get back to you on whether they plan on mixing up cocktails with Horlicks, though.

Inspired by Tokyos cheap afterwork drinking and snacking joints, Five is hooking people up with $5 drink specials on Asahi beers and wine. Pay a bit extra to sip on a Sake-hito (sake + mojito) or a Choya-tini (Choya Shiso, dry vermouth and orange juice).

With three extensive menus to browse, the brisk service at this shophouse next to Selegie Road can come across as pushy. Fortunately, intentionally or not, concessions for this shortcoming are made.

House wines are carefully selected at the time of our visit, the house white was a rare import from Croatias Galic (pronounced gahleech) Winery ($14). This refreshing, slightly tart floral sauvignon blanc is an excel-lent balance to the nummy, honey-like fig compote served alongside the chunky Foie Gras Terrine ($24).

The joue de boeuf (beef cheeks in red wine, $26), selected from the easel chalkboard menu set up alongside the table, is a less composed dish the meat is soft almost to the point of mush but its flavourful, red-wine-braised base will definitely have you going santé! Celine Asril

I have grown weary of that ubiquitous formula followed in the latest avant-garde restaurants. It will take more to impress and satisfy me than a scoop of savoury sorbet or a dollop of that youve seen it once-flavoured foam. While both of these party tricks make it onto Private Affairs modern-European-with- an-Asian-touch menu, happily for us, chef Paul Ng has a few other inventive methods tucked up his apron sleeve. After building up his portfolio at eateries like Les Amis and Pierside Kitchen, Ng has set up shop in Joo Chiat. Here an up-and-coming dining scene thrives just a few doors down from several seedy KTV lounges, where private affairs of another sort ensue. Inside, the dark hardwood floor glows underneath sparkling, ever-so-chic chandeliers. Theres no need to blindfold your beau on the way to the restaurant; theyll have no idea where youre taking them and certainly no idea whats in store until the food has been placed on the table. But even then, be warned: compared with the college-level chemistry lessons you would receive at Ferran Adriàs El Bulli or Wylie Dufresnes wd-50, this six-course meal came with little or no explanation from Ngs staff, whom Id compare to junior high substitute teachers. Theyre there just to make sure things get done, but have little or no knowledge of their subject. When I enquired about the oxtail blanquette it was covered in a thin, unrecognisable gel the waiter pointed out the ever-so-obvious mushrooms and fled before I had the chance to follow up on my question. The waiters giggling after our questions made me feel like a putz for showing curiosity or even for being there to indulge in these wacky concoctions in the first place. Service aside, chef Ng prepared several stand-out dishes. Presented on on a black-slate serving board, the pan-fried foie gras succeeds in bringing together four unlikely accompaniments beets that have been transformed into a crunchy coral, camomile jelly, aragame oil and a pomegranate vinaigrette. The Hokkaido scallops received high marks from both my dining partner and myself, arriving perfectly tender, seasoned with smoked miso powder atop corn noodles. The star player in the lobster bisque one of the chefs signature dishes is the tricolore cannelloni wrapped around a salmon and lobster salad. The lush roll lies in the bowl before the soup is ladled at the table, ensuring its consumed at the perfect temperature. The seared tuna, however, falls short. I felt gypped when the white soya lime sorbet (surprise surprise) and mirin yuzu foam (yawn) both melted and disappeared quickly on the plate. On my next visit I would consider replacing my main course with extra starters; the beef cheek lacked any real crunch and its smoky aroma reminded me of hickory barbecue sauce bought from a store. The kurobuta pork was served alongside avocado gnocchi, blood orange and fermented black garlic, and saved the rather dry meat, making it somewhat more palatable. The desserts made up for many of the bumps along the way. The chocolate florentine, with Baileys powder and pistachio couscous, is served alongside a scoop of mouthwatering white chocolate ice cream. The thick passionfruit purée and basil gel in the pistachio cheese sandwich also testify to the chefs sweet success. Some say the point of molecular gastronomy is to make diners think, in which case Private Affairs succeeded with flying colours. Unfortunately, by the end of my meal, the apparent lack of communication between kitchen and dining room meant that not all my thoughts were positive. Alexandra Karplus

Located in Singapore's newest arts hub, Yavuz Fine Art is on the third level of what used to be the Catholic High School. The gallery has two exhibition halls the larger one is for smaller exhibitions, while the small room houses its permanent collection.

Located on the ground floor of a classic art deco-inspired Tiong Bahru HDB, White Canvas Gallery's cement-washed industrial interiors play host to works by emerging artists in the region. Laid out like a living room, the gallery has couches where you can comfortably sit beside exhibiting artists.

This promising new addition to Joo Chiats restaurant row certainly looks the part: its black-and-white corner shophouse location, checkerboard flooring, colonial decor and airy whitewashed interior tick all the design boxes.

But in the kitchen, the creative heart of any restaurant, something is missing. Thats not to say the Asian-influenced European fare is bad; its just that you get the feeling that the restaurant is like its appearance a bit bistro by numbers. The very reasonably priced four-course set meals make a good light lunch. The pan-seared lamb is cooked to order and arrived perfectly medium-rare, the meats juicy flavour accented nicely with a clear tarragon vinaigrette, and plated alongside dainty stems of asparagus and sliced potatoes. The pristine poached fillet of line-caught snapper with a plum-tinged ginger lime sauce had similarly strong touches, and came topped with additional strips of ginger fried to a wonderfully crunchy golden finish. There is an obvious cohesion in the dishes, but come dinnertime, the cracks start to show and one cant help but feel that Black Earth might have reached the extent of its creativity. The evening meal was exactly the same as lunch, meaning a similarly tangled jumble of temperatures and flavours; the warm vegetables and strip of char-grilled marinated sirloin are topped with chilled pickles and drenched with cold black peppercorn sauce.

As with the other mains, every bite contained different degrees of sweet, salty, sour and spicy; and it doesnt help that the sirloin, toughened by the splash of cold dressing, was already dry to begin with.

The only impression made by the pan-seared salmon flavoured with lemongrass in a lime cream sauce is that it looked and tasted just like the lunchtime snapper, except this time it had donned a tart cream sauce as a rather gauche piece of eveningwear.

The wines ($8-$10 per glass) are served over-chilled; the desserts are uninspiring and appear thrown-together (strawberries with fresh cream, dates with yoghurt, or fresh mango with ice cream, $6-$7.50). Despite having piled too much on their plates, promise still lurks somewhere within the gastronomic confusion of Black Earth. If they choose to moderate their menu a tad, were sure their creative juices would be allowed to flow a little more freely. Celine Asril
content.public-transport: Near station: Paya Lebar, Eunos | Buses: 33

content.description:
If, as demonstrated by Khmer Delight, Cambodian cuisine means juicy cubes of beef stir-fried to a perfect medium rare (lok lak), soft fillets of steamed fish smothered in a generous paste of coconut milk and spices (amok), and delicate salads made with prawns and the flowers of the banana plant, then weve got our bags packed and are ready to hop on the plane to Phnom Penh.

The downside to this self-proclaimed only Cambodian restaurant in Singapore is that the traditional lok lak served with slices of tomato, cucumber and a subtle lime-based pepper sauce comes with oversized cubes, and the fish amok curry can get heavy on the palate; the rice is also a little mushy. After a gentle tweak from the chef and her Cambodian aunt, this restaurant will be great. Celine Asril

Upstairs, diners are ushered into a private tent of sorts with a low table and plenty of cushions to throw around; Arabic ballads mixed with the jovial hubbub of conversation, and the slow-turning Ottoman-styled lamp above, add to the cosy mystique.

At $25, the three-course set menu is a worthwhile choice. Fervidly dip away at the home-made hummus and baba ganoush with warm slices of pita and garlic loaf; wash it down with the harkhadae (hibiscus juice) a unique thirst quencher.

Sadly, the one-sauce-fits-all slathered over the lamb kofta, butter prawns and chewy tenderloin kebab leaves all the main courses tasting similar. Its warm service and relaxed surroundings make Amirahs a great place for friends to meet, but leave the culinary experience for another locale. Marc Checkley

Forget Tom and Dick; Harrys is the one taking centre stage with the opening of a boutique hotel on the Design Hill, Ann Siang Road. The Club is the well-known bar chains first attempt at expanding past the drunk after-work crowd and on to high-end travellers. In addition to the 22 art-filled rooms, the converted row of shophouses is also the setting for a new rooftop bar they do say its best to go with what you know.
From $195++.

Housed in the former Singapore Badminton Centre where the Thomas Cup was hosted a number of times in the '50s, this 24,000 sq ft spa is popular with ladies going out in a group, and men who come for the hearty complimentary food like Penang kway teow, laksa and lamb chops. Entrance comes with the use of steam room, jacuzzi and sauna. The spa has a strong WiFi signal and a relaxation lounge with TV-outfitted reclining chairs. Read our review of G Spa's Sea Masculin Facial.

Leonard Drake is a professional skin care and body wellness centre that restore and maintain your skin at its optimum level. Essentially, you'll get facials, advanced facials, facials for every age group and gender, and treatments for your body, eyes, neck and chest.

content.public-transport: Near station: Paya Lebar | Buses: 2, 13, 21, 24, 51, 67, 54, 154, 155, NR7

content.description:
Simmering away in a quiet corner of Dempsey, this tandoor restaurants atmosphere is as warm as the aromatic curries brewing in the kitchen. Specialising in North Indian favourites like lamb rogan josh (slow-cooked meat served with Kashmiri spices) and chicken korma (a yoghurt and nut gravy), it also offers a varied wine list and a number of fine ales to douse the heat.

The sizzling tandoor platter is a hearty starter, with selections of reddusted tikka and tender spiced kebabs. Another excellent entrée is the vegetable shashlik, mushrooms, broccoli and peppers stuffed with cottage cheese and yoghurt. The vindaloo curry is rich and creamy, albeit not as spicy as requested, and the grilled zafrani salmon flourished with coriander, mint and saffron-infused yoghurt is a modern alternative for the health conscious.

End the Indian affair by retiring to the Scotch Corner for a tipple or two. With its relaxed atmosphere and personable service, the aroma of The Clay Oven will linger well after youve headed home. MC
content.public-transport: Near station: Take a taxi | Buses: 7, 105, 123, 174

content.description:
There are some dishes that never go out of style, fish n chips being one of em. And when you get a craving for this age-old favourite you can opt for the cheap as chips, fast-food variety or go for the halibut, and pay hook, line and sinker for a meal.

Thankfully this cosy bistro on Greenwood Avenue anchors itself somewhere in the middle, offering fresh selections of the oceans finest without landing a weighty bill.

The fish, nearly 30 varieties of them, come in four grades; from $18.95, through to the exclusive catch of the day ($29.95), flown in direct that morning.

The fillets can be prepared four ways, the most popular being pan-seared or battered. The latter is a bit hit and miss: the batter can come off stodgy, masking the taste of the fluffy white alfonsino. The marlin (New Zealand swordfish), however, comes off light and crispy to the last bite. A garden salad and ample serving of chips (not hand-cut) are served alongside.

Alternative selections include the lip-wetting Chilean red miso black cod, and were also intrigued by the foie gras and scallop served atop sultanas, fig, port and buttery brioche. Just one caveat: this is a seriously popular dive with Greenwood locals, so its best to call ahead to net yourself a table. Marc Checkley
Observatory and IMAX film theatre located in the Science Centre.
